IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) is a major cause of early onset dementia, and mutations in the progranulin gene causes FTD with TDP-43 pathology. We will utilize a mouse model to evaluate TDP-43 pathology and function in the context of progranulin insufficiency. Using these mice, we will investigate the role of TDP-43 dysfunction in a key brain region that influences social dominance behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Arteries have natural protection against autoimmune disease, but in the case of giant cell arteritis (GCA) this protection is lost, the patients develop arterial inflammation, and are threatened by blindness, stroke and aortic aneurysm. This project examines defects in the immune system of GCA patients, so-called immune checkpoints, which cause the expansion of disease-inducing immune cells and seeks to define common targets in anti-cancer immunity and in vascular inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Women and infants face substantial risks of illness and death during pregnancy and after birth. Group antenatal care is an innovative model that has effectively addressed many of these mental and physical health challenges, both in the US and globally. The purpose of this study is to understand how community building, or how the experience of being in a group intervention during pregnancy, contributes to mental and physical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Non-typeable Haemophilus influenzae is a bacterial pathogen that causes lung and ear infections and severe exacerbations in individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. This project will uncover the post-translational modifications and function of a recently identified virulence factor that plays a significant role in human cell invasion during infection. Understanding the molecular details by which this virulence factor functions will provide opportunities for development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 45% of pregnancies are unintended, demonstrating an unmet need for comprehensive contraception. This project is relevant to public health because it aims to generate new small molecule hits and insights for a highly validated contraceptive target, the sperm-specific CatSper calcium channel, using an innovative functional expression system that allows for high-throughput cell-based screening and mechanism of action studies. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it will contribute to the development of a new class of contraceptives and the improvement of reproductive health in men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The exonuclease TREX1 plays a key role in antitumor immune surveillance and autoinflammatory disease by digesting cytosolic DNA to suppress innate immunity. This project will characterize novel structural features in TREX1 to investigate how TREX1 accesses DNA substrates in cells and how TREX1 ectopic localization in the nucleus can induce disease. Successful completion of the project will thus establish structure-function relationships of novel TREX1 elements, as well as elucidate the molecular etiology of TREX1 mutations in cancer and autoinflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative High-gradient diffusion MRI holds great promise for capturing the earliest microscopic gray matter abnormalities present in Alzheimer’s disease before their overt manifestation on conventional MRI. In this project, we will use the sensitivity of high-gradient diffusion MRI to map alterations in cellular microstructure in patients with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease and provide validated diffusion MRI measures of cortical and subcortical gray matter degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria programmed to make anti-cancer drugs will grow inside tumors but not normal organs, which means they can be used to specifically deliver drugs to tumors and metastases and reduce side effects. However, bacteria don’t colonize human tumors very well, and we don’t really understand why. We will use many strains of bacteria with mutations in different genes to see which genes affect colonization of tumors, which will let us make anti-cancer bacteria that are even more specific to tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD), a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in older adults, causes significant cognitive impairment, but current therapeutic efforts have not provided clinically meaningful improvements in cognition. The proposed research will use plasma proteomic methodologies to identify novel plasma biomarkers predictive of early cognitive decline in older adults without clinical dementia or stroke. Findings from this proposal will aid in identification of novel therapeutic targets for prevention and treatment of cognitive decline and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Under most circumstances, people's brains derive nearly all their energy needs from the sugar glucose, but when people drink alcohol, their bodies convert most of the alcohol to acetate, which over time and quantity can lead the body to adapt to the acetate. Acetate is also a key source to make a stress-related chemical called cortisol, which has effects on behavior and even the size of key brain areas. We will measure possible associations between drinking style (light, binging, or dependent) to see if the ability to consume that acetate is related to cortisol, shrinkage of certain regions of the brain, and behavior, which raises possibilities of certain nutritional supplements to help people get through detoxification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) (sometimes called “forever chemicals”) are a group of synthetic and persistent chemicals detected globally due to their transportability, chemical stability, and widespread use in industrial processes and consumer products. PFAS appear to cause negative health outcomes, including dyslipidemia (an imbalance of blood lipids, such as cholesterol), an important risk factor for heart disease. Volunteer firefighters have an increased risk of on-duty cardiac-related mortality, however, their exposures to PFAS and the relationship with dyslipidemia are not well understood and will be examined by this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains one of the most significant and impactful global health diseases today. We will study essential regulatory features of the Plasmodium parasite as creates sporozoite stage parasites in oocysts found on the mosquito midgut. Specifically, this proposed work will focus on the development and composition of the basal complex during the early, mid, and late stages of sporogony.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental exposure to traffic related air pollution is a risk factor for wheezing, asthma and other respiratory diseases and particulate matter can evoke specific immune responses that can adversely impact human health. In this proposal, we are determining if traffic emitted ultrafine particles disrupt natural pro-resolving mediators and resolution mechanisms for inflammation and lead to increased susceptibility for chronic inflammatory disease as well as increased susceptibility to allergen induced asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health since it focuses on evaluating potential, modifiable factors (distance to care and residential environment) for childhood cancer survivors to improve the quality of survivorship care opportunities and later life health outcomes. Reducing barriers to survivorship care opportunities may improve the quality of life and life expectancy for childhood cancer survivors. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NCIs mission to support cancer research to advance scientific knowledge and help all people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial-selective autophagy (mitophagy) is an essential cellular process needed to promote cell survival, but the genes that play a role in this process are not well understood. I am studying a novel regulator of mitophagy at the mitochondrial surface that physically interacts with lipid transport protein VPS13D, a gene implicated in age-associated movement disorders that regulates mitochondrial clearance. Studying this process will benefit our overall understanding of mitophagy, and provide novel insight into therapeutics to combat defective mitophagy diseases like Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite their potential, protein biologics, and in particular, cytokines, often exhibit poor “peak-and-valley” pharmacokinetic profiles, rapid degradation, systemic immune activation (due to their on-target, off-tumor effect), resulting in dose-limiting toxicities, impaired efficacy and poor patient compliance. To address these defining challenges, and advance biotherapeutic development beyond the state-of-the-art, Pearl Bio has developed a proprietary technology platform to enable precise, multi-site functionalization of next-generation biologics to catalyze new protein drug design capabilities. In this project we will generate a set of functionalized IL-15 therapeutic candidates that are (a) lipidated to tune half-life and (b) endowed with novel tumor targeting modalities for enhanced binding specificity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Automation is key for usability in a clinical setting to help reduce user interaction, provide repeatability and reproducibility, and maintain cleanliness. This project will automate an FDA-registered system for microsizing autologous adipose tissue for the use in regenerative medicine, as well as for dissociating tumor tissue into single cells for cancer diagnostics. This project will provide a valuable role in developing a fully automated system for the use in multiple medical procedures in the regenerative medicine field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Obesity is a pervasive disorder linked to serious medical complications and reaching epidemic proportions in the United States. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of thrombospondin/a2d-1 signaling in the ventromedial hypothalamus facilitating feeding control and glucose and lipid metabolism in a body-weight independent manner. These investigations will inform new avenues for the treatment of obesity-associated metabolic disorders and mechanisms underlying metabolic dysfunction in individuals treated with gabapentinoid drugs, known to inhibit a2d-1 function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy is a fundamental biological process with broad impact on human health, including a number of age- related diseases, such as neurodegeneration, cancer, infection and immunity, inflammation and allergy, metabolic diseases and diabetes, muscle atrophy, as well as the aging process itself. The realization of the broad impact of autophagy in human health is in part the result of vigorous scientific exchange facilitated by previous Gordon Research Conferences (GRC) on autophagy. The 2024 GRC meeting on autophagy will be instrumental in communicating the newest molecular insights of the role and regulation of autophagy in aging and age-related disorders, as well as highlight the allied processes of lysosomal secretion and lysosomal membrane repair.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deepening our understanding of how fetal versus adult hematopoiesis will provide insight into how developmental context influences hematopoietic stem cell function. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will expand fundamental knowledge on the selective forces driving the ecological development of the preterm gut microbiome, as well as the basic biological functions of IgA in controlling pathobionts. Using longitudinally collected preterm infant stool samples from a prospective cohort study, the proposed research will identify signature patterns of preterm gut microbiota development, how pathobionts evolve to induce necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and the role of breast milk IgA in influencing these outcomes. Findings will reveal new insights into IgA modulation of the microbiota, which has important implications for the development of microbiome- and immunoglobulin-based therapies against NEC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An understanding of the complex microbial signaling networks in the human microbiome has led to many insights in health and disease, and yet, little is known about the impacts of archaea or archaeal signaling in and on our bodies. My study will elucidate a novel signaling pathway in the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii. Discoveries in cell-signaling in archaea will begin to unravel the intricacies of signaling among all three domains of life, lead to applications in antibacterial medicine, and reveal a more cohesive understanding of the healthy human microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tears (RCTs) are the most common shoulder injury and are often surgically repaired. Unfortunately, rates of retear are high and have been clinically correlated to rotator cuff muscle fatty infiltration and fibrosis—the origins of which remain unclear; however, likely involve an interstitial population of mesenchymal cells known as fibroadipogenic progenitors (FAPs). Utilizing murine models of massive RCTs, genetic lineage tracing/reporter analyses, as well as sophisticated bulk and single cell RNA-sequencing assays, functional measures, and lightsheet microscopy we will determine the precise cellular and molecular role(s) for FAP/s in the RCT-associated muscle atrophy pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, there is a gap in understanding how transcription is utilized to aid in DNA repair and maintain genomic integrity. The Integrator complex is known to associate with RNA Polymerase II and utilize its RNA endonuclease activity to regulate transcription at nearly all RNAPII loci. My research has uncovered a surprising interaction between a critical DNA repair protein and Integrator, and this proposal will elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings between these two important nuclear processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative Podocytes are highly specialized cells that are critical for the filtration of blood into urine. Podocytes are unable to regenerate after injury, therefore podocyte loss is a critical component in the development of kidney diseases. I observed novel intercellular bridges forming between injured podocytes and neighboring parietal epithelial cells in injured mouse kidneys, therefore, I will investigate the role of intercellular bridges as a method of direct communication between injured podocytes and parietal epithelial cells in kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Chromatin modifying enzymes are frequently mutated in cancers that lead to dysregulation of important cellular functions. Among them, the histone methyltransferase MLL1 has both loss of function mutations and copy number gains in cancer. Elucidating how MLL1 contributes to tumorigenesis highlights its multifaceted roles in tumorigenesis and facilitates development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The cell membrane tension dictates the shape and many downstream properties of cells and the organs made of cells; thus, membrane tension is important in disease but difficult to measure. Here, we propose to build a contrast agent that can map and measure the cell membrane tension using an optical or ultrasound signal. This contrast agent will help guide the detection and treatment of important diseases and be a tool for in vivo research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis is the major cause of mortality in cancer patients today, with over 90% of cancer deaths being due to metastasis, and there are very few treatment options available for treating metastatic cancer. In my preliminary work, I discovered a novel mediator of metastasis: the human INAFM2 protein, which may present a future druggable target. The aims of this grant are to fully confirm INAFM2’s role in cancer metastasis by using mouse models and to determine INAFM2’s biological function and molecular mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hypermobile Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (hEDS) is a genetic disorder that causes symptoms affecting multiple body systems including the joints, skin, gastrointestinal tract, and heart. Despite its prevalence of 1 in 500 individuals, there are currently no reliable tests or treatments available for hEDS. The completion of this proposal will provide new understanding of the disease, opening new avenues for future studies and the potential for therapeutic approaches that will make a significant impact on the lives of those affected by hEDS and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Psychosocial adjustment following cochlear implantation represents a critical outcome that includes social (e.g., adaptability), emotional (e.g., depression), and behavioral (e.g., aggression) competence and functioning in daily living. The overall objective of the research project is to predict variability in psychosocial adjustment in prelingually deaf, early-implanted cochlear implant users by identifying underlying mechanisms of risk and resilience. Findings will have direct clinical implications for the early identification, diagnosis, and treatment of at-risk psychosocial outcomes in pediatric cochlear implant users by identifying specific assessment and intervention targets to promote effective coping responses to stress in order to enhance psychosocial adjustment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed under this F31 fellowship will assess the role of KCC2-mediated synaptic plasticity in the VTA during naturalistic reward learning and will characterize the circuitry involved in this process. This will allow for the establishment of KCC2 modulation as a novel form of synaptic plasticity during reward learning and will demonstrate the potential of KCC2 as a target for intervention to treat neuropsychiatric disorders that are characterized by aberrant reward learning such as obsessive compulsive disorder and schizophrenia, among many others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The acute cardiovascular care of spinal cord injury, including blood pressure regulation, is not backed by sufficient evidence to form hard guidelines. This research seeks to use ultrasound to understand how spinal cord injury affects vessels in the spinal cord and their ability to compensate for variation in blood pressure. This study will also attempt to use blood pressure maintenance to optimize the distribution of blood flow around the injury and maximize healing, with the potential for eventual translation into human spinal cord injury patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to better understand how our sense of smell works by studying odorant receptors (ORs) in humans. We will investigate how ORs bind to different odor molecules and how they are activated to send signals to our brain. By uncovering the fundamental properties of OR function, we hope to gain insights that could lead to new therapies for smell-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to demonstrate a new multi-spectral light source with remarkable illumination uniformity we call Efficient Uniform Color-Light Integration Device (EUCLID) and its potential impact in a broad range of biological microscopic and mesoscopic imaging applications. EUCLID employs a diffuse-reflective, adjustable hollow cavity for uniform mixing of light from discrete sources with high efficiency and provides a simple method to compensate for spatial non-uniformity introduced by optical components in the imaging system. We propose to apply EUCLID to multispectral mesoscale imaging of neuronal and hemodynamic activity and neuromodulation in the cortex of awake mice implanted with crystal skull windows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent studies have identified an association between genetic variants in a new set of genes and the development of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), a common genetic heart condition that causes sudden cardiac death and congestive heart failure. This application will focus on a subset of these genetic variants that are involved in controlling the folding and degradation of proteins in the cardiac muscle cells. We will determine the impact of these new genetic variants on the clinical outcomes of patients with HCM and also perform experiments to understand the mechanisms behind how they cause or exacerbate disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Membrane proteins represent ~30% of the mammalian proteome and over half of all drug targets, but are nearly always studied in physical contexts that do not model their relevant membrane environments – and this is limiting understanding. We seek to understand the role of the native membrane environment on epidermal growth factor receptor, a membrane protein that plays crucial roles in cellular and lipid metabolism, differentiation, motility, and proliferation in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Huntington’s disease (HD) is a chronic, fatal neurodegenerative disease associated with vast impairments in executive functioning; however, the presentation of executive dysfunction in HD is highly variable across disease progression and the underlying mechanisms driving these declines are poorly understood. Building on seminal findings of key contributors to executive dysfunction in other disease populations, the proposed study aims to extend these findings by examining the association of chronic stress, inflammatory cytokines, and a standardized marker of disease burden with executive functioning in a sample of adults with HD. This study will improve the field’s understanding of the specific processes driving one of the cardinal features of HD, executive dysfunction, and has the potential to inform treatment targets for supportive care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) Diabetes mellitus results from insufficient or ineffective insulin production by the pancreatic β-cell and affects millions of people worldwide. In recent years, the importance of macrophages for β-cell expansion in pathological conditions, such as obesity, has been highlighted; pregnancy has also been identified as a period of robust β- cell expansion, despite β-cell proliferation under steady-state conditions being low. Therefore, this proposal aims to characterize islet macrophages throughout gestation and investigate their requirement in β-cell expansion during late gestation providing insight into potential targets to increase insulin production. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Projective Narrative The first ever International Indigenous Dementia Research Network Annual Conference series addresses a critical need to advance knowledge, discovery and scientific collaboration in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) in Indigenous populations. There is currently no equitable venue for academics and communities studying dementia in Indigenous populations to come together and share scientific and Indigenous knowledge in a way that is comparable to other disciplines or disease-focused research areas. To remedy this situation, we will implement a 5-year annual conference series with the long-term goal of creating a sustainable, supportive, worldwide network of scholars committed to knowledge exchange and collaboration to advance research, knowledge, and mentorship in community-based, culturally appropriate ADRD research with Indigenous populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most genetic variants associated with disease are single point mutations which are potentially correctable via systems that exchange a single DNA base (base editors). However, the capacity of this approach is limited by editing promiscuity at neighboring bases which constrains target selection to a narrow range of mutations where nearby off-target edits would not negate the effect of the edit or induce additional pathogenic mutations. This proposal addresses an unmet clinical need for the advent of precision editors using a two-pronged approach that extends existing technology and creates an entirely new kind of editing enzyme with intrinsic properties that prevent off-target edits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL Age is a major risk factor for increased susceptibility to infectious diseases, including respiratory virus infection such as influenza and SARS-CoV-2. This Center will define the contribution of airway epithelial cells to age- related dysfunction of the tissue-resident immune system, particularly in the context of lung responses to viral infections. These discoveries could form the basis for next-generation therapeutics to treat lung diseases, an outcome of great public health importance given the range of infectious and other age-related immune diseases that originate in, or secondarily impact, the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Epigenetic regulation through the post-translation modification of histones is critical for normal neuronal function and epigenetic regulators have been implicated in neurodevelopmental disorders including autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This project will study an uncharacterized epigenetic regulator, Setd2, in the context of neurons to determine its role in regulating neuronal function and explore how loss of Setd2 can lead to circuit dysfunction in a novel mouse model. Results are expected to aid the understanding how epigenetic dysregulation can lead to ASD, identify convergent pathways of different causes of ASD, and identify therapeutic targets for SETD2-related neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Brain oscillations and the genes associated with them are promising but poorly understood targets for future neuromodulatory therapies for cognitive disorders like Alzheimer’s disease. SMAD3 expression is associated with memory-enhanced oscillations and gene expression, but it is unknown exactly how SMAD3 influences cognitive processes in the brain. By silencing SMAD3 in human brain tissue in vitro, then characterizing how SMAD3-controlled gene networks influence synchronized neural activity in the same tissue, this project will make major progress toward the ultimate goal of developing neurotherapeutics for cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human nuclear pore complex is a !110 MDa protein complex that controls macromolecular transport between the nucleus and cytoplasm. We propose to develop a spatiotemporal integrative model that describes the assem- bly pathway of the human nuclear pore complex. We believe our work will elucidate the molecular mechanism that drives the formation of the nuclear pore complex, and will provide a computational framework to study the dynamics of other large macromolecules in the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) occurs when the lung is injured severely after, among other conditions, respiratory infections, trauma, or sepsis. 40% of patients with ARDS do not survive, and there are no current treatments, though they are urgently needed in preparation for the next respiratory pandemic. We plan to engineer cells that can deliver treatments predicted to help lung cells regenerate directly to the injured lung in hopes that these cells can someday be used to treat patients with ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine the disease altering properties of high intensity aerobic exercise through the systematic examination of 250 individuals with Parkinson’s disease (PD) who participate in a 12-month community-based cycling program compared to a historical control group of 125 individuals with PD with identical outcome metrics. The role of genetics in exercise and disease progression will be examined by developing a prognostic model in which genetic burden, determined through the calculation of a PD polygenic risk score, is a key factor. Identifying the potential role genetics may have in modulating the disease altering potential of exercise will advance PD understanding and accelerate development of a personalized medicine approach to PD exercise prescription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This fellowship application seeks to discover the immune cell population that is responsible for initiating the biological process that allows tumors to spread into distant organs, with the ultimate goal of developing a therapeutic strategy to treat metastatic disease. I will utilize state-of-the-art technology and computational analysis to identify these immune cells, and develop a therapy that reprograms them away from undertaking this undesirable role. Advances from the proposed study will broadly impact cancer patients since metastatic disease is a major cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many musculoskeletal diseases including Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy are characterized by the accumulation of extracellular matrix (ECM) components, termed fibrosis, which is widely viewed as irreversible. The proposed research aims to elucidate the mechanism by which fibrotic ECM organization affects mechanical properties and regenerative capacity of skeletal muscle, as well as the efficacy of Collagenase Clostridium histolyticum in treating muscle fibrosis. The results of these experiments will provide a greater understanding of the interaction between fibrotic ECM architecture and deficits in muscle function, as well as provide a potential therapeutic for reversing fibrosis in DMD and other musculoskeletal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Identifying risk factors for prescription opioid use and cannabis use in emerging adults is key to preventing substance abuse disorders. Emerging adults who use cannabis are frequently prescribed opioids in medical settings, but the potential harms and benefits of co-use in the context of acute pain are unknown. The long-term goal of this research program is to identify malleable risk and protective factors that impact opioid and cannabis co-use in emerging adults receiving opioid prescriptions in the outpatient setting, which will directly inform preventative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate prediction of a highly variable clinical course is the key to effective management of localized prostate cancer, a disease that annually affects millions of lives. The germline genome has been shown to play a critical role in prostate cancer clinical outcomes, suggesting enormous potential for risk stratification applications. I will establish the utility of germline genomic biomarkers to enhance standard of care management for this disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Hazardous drinking is a large and growing problem for Veterans across age groups. Many Veterans with hazardous drinking and other mental health problems seek care in the Emergency Department (ED). This study is a randomized controlled trial (N=450) of an alcohol intervention starting in the VHA ED with peer support personnel delivering brief alcohol advice, combined with a continuing 6-session program of post-ED strengths-based peer mentorship to facilitate reductions in alcohol use and to link Veterans with alcohol problems to needed primary and specialty care including other needed services such as homeless outreach and case management where needed. If successful, the proposed study will provide key data on the effectiveness of using peer support specialists in the VHA to help Veterans with hazardous drinking who may have difficulty engaging in needed care that potentially improve their mental and physical health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Despite progress in reducing the extent of injury after perinatal hypoxic-ischemic brain injury, there are presently no approved therapeutics to both reduce the extent of secondary injury and promote regeneration. The goal of this proposal is to use a mouse model of perinatal hypoxic-ischemic brain injury to test the therapeutic efficacy of a cytokine that we hypothesize will both preserve injured neurons and stimulate the replacement of damaged neurons and glia from the resident neural stem cells of the subventricular and subgranular zones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Tobacco smoking is a major etiological agent in the development of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) which is a disfiguring disease that can strip away the patient’s voice and certain basic needs such as eating and drinking. Although smoking cessation is the only intervention proven to reduce tobacco-related cancers, the results of this application will provide critical mechanistic insights toward the design of future chemoprevention trials targeting addicted smokers who are unable to quit as well as non- or former smokers who are exposed to carcinogens through environmental exposures (food-borne carcinogens, second-hand smoke).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Rapid evolution of influenza and other viruses, such as SARS-CoV-2, to escape immunity prevalent in the population challenges development of vaccines with long-term protective efficacy. This Project seeks to resolve key questions concerning immune-response mechanisms and to apply them to immunogen-design approaches. It will study human responses to vaccination and conduct immunization experiments in non-human primates and mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health One of the major drawbacks in using currently available epigenetic perturbants, such as histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors, is that they often affect the transcriptional levels of thousands of genes at once, which greatly hinders their use in treating most human pathologies, at the exception of a few blood cancers. We hypothesize that to widen the use of epigenetic perturbants as potential therapeutics, a new generation of inhibitors needs to be developed with much more specific effects on the transcriptome, corresponding to a paradigm shift from “multigenic” to “oligogenic” HDAC inhibitors. In this application, we propose to develop a novel strategy to identify “oligogenic” HDAC complex inhibitors, investigate how these new compounds affect the transcriptome, and understand the molecular mechanisms underlying these activities, which might in turn help developing a second generation of epigenetic perturbants with improved therapeutic properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Since cardiovascular and respiratory diseases including heart attack, high blood pressure, obesity, metabolic disease, stroke, asthma, and emphysema are major health problems in the USA and world-wide, it is necessary to train scientists as integrative thinkers capable of pushing the frontiers of mechanistic, organismal physiology knowledge to better understand disease processes. For nearly 25 years of continuous T32 funding, we have had a strong track record of training predoctoral students in multidisciplinary didactic instruction and modern physiological research in order to prepare students to conduct physiological research using novel techniques and methods and teach future generations of physicians and scientists how the human body works in health and disease. For these and other reasons, we request funds to support eight predoctoral students each year for the next five years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor-initiating cells are a rare subpopulation of tumor cells that have intrinsic resistance to standard cancer therapeutics. This proposal seeks to clarify the relationship between tumor initiating cells (TIC) in the primary tumor and metastasis-initiating cells (MIC) at metastatic sites capable of forming macrometastases, and to identify TIC vulnerabilities that can be exploited to prevent tumor progression. We anticipate the findings from this work will reveal a transcriptional program that is unique to tumor-initiating cells, which can be leveraged to eliminate cells that escape the effects of cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The landmark PREDIMED trial has demonstrated that Mediterranean dietary interventions significantly reduced the risk of major cardiovascular disease (CVD) events by approximately 30%, compared to a control diet. The goal of this competing renewal is to examine the effects of the Mediterranean dietary interventions on changes in urinary levels of metabolites and develop a multi-fluid (urine and plasma) multi-metabolite signature that significantly predicts future risk of CVD. The study has the potential to discover novel pathways through which diet influences CVD risk and facilitate the precision nutrition research agenda outlined in the 2020-2030 Strategic Plan for NIH Nutrition Research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic cardiomyopathy is strongly associated with the development of mitochondrial dysfunction and the effective elimination of damaged mitochondria is crucial to limit the progression of diabetic cardiomyopathy. Using patient-specific human induced pluripotent stem cells and novel transgenic mouse model, this research proposal aims to delineate novel molecular mechanisms that regulate mitochondrial clearance during diabetic conditions and contribute to discovery of therapeutic intervention that could prevent diabetic cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer immunotherapy and fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) can augment natural immune response against several tumor types, but not all patients respond, thus it is important to understand the reasons behind this clinical observation in order to achieve better outcomes. We have observed, in mouse studies, that naturally occurring differences in the mitochondrial DNA can drastically alter gut microbial composition and immune responses against melanoma, both mediated by the mitochondrial generation of reactive oxygen species (mROS) in immune cells. We now propose to determine if this mitochondrial modulation of tumorigenicity is applicable to other cancers, the immune cell type responsible, the metabolic basis of the mitochondrial- microbiota interaction, and the importance of immune cell mROS in modulating the efficacy of FMT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurons project extended axons that can reach a meter in length; these axons must be maintained in a functional state over a lifetime. One essential mechanism that maintains axonal health is autophagy, or `self-eating', the process by which cells turn over dysfunctional organelles and aggregated proteins. Defects in autophagy are sufficient to cause neurodegeneration in diseases such as ALS and Parkinson's disease. Here, we will investigate the molecular mechanisms regulating the dynamics of autophagy in the axon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative The events of September 11th, 2001 traumatized many of the men and women who aided in rescue and recovery operations at Ground Zero were exposed to an extraordinary array of stressful experiences. In 2014, we began the only cognitive monitoring study of World Trade Center responders and have since identified associations between WTC exposures and cognitive symptoms consistent with preclinical Alzheimer’s disease. In this renewal application, we propose to build on our existing research framework to examine the extent to which PTSD instigates changes in blood-based biomarkers indicative of an Alzheimer’s disease neuropathological cascade.

PHR: Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart rhythm disturbance in the world, significantly affects the lives of the afflicted by causing symptoms that range from palpitations and fatigue to stroke, congestive heart failure and death. Current treatment options are limited by poor efficacy and substantial toxicity. This proposal focuses on developing novel a gene therapy to prevent or reverse the damage that atrial fibrillation causes to the heart and thereby eliminate the ability of the heart to remain in atrial fibrillation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is a multi-level intergenerational study of the relationship between parental mental disorders and their children’s subsequent experiences of marriage, contraceptive use and childbearing. The results will greatly advance understanding of the individual, family and community factors that influence whether parental mental disorders in childhood have persistent consequences for the long-term family experiences of their children. It will provide the scientific evidence required to design and target more effective interventions to support parents to promote the long-term health and wellbeing of children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE) Despite improved screening efforts and therapeutic advancements over the past decade, lung cancer continues to be the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide and the second most prevalent cancer type in the United States, presenting an ongoing medical challenge for which scientific investigation can translate into significant clinical benefit. Some cancers, including lung cancer, have been shown to be susceptible to a novel, oxidative-stress dependent form of cell death, termed ferroptosis, so enhancing ferroptosis may be an alternative therapeutic strategy to target tumors that are resistant to conventional therapy. Using cutting-edge, preclinical mouse models that closely mimic human lung cancer, this work will determine if induction of ferroptosis impedes tumor development and investigate how specific common cancer mutations protect against ferroptosis to promote tumor growth, with the goal of providing deeper insight into a novel mechanism of cell death that can be harnessed for future cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Timely management of dementia remains a challenge for primary care providers despite their central role in the care of patients with dementia. The goal of this proposal is to adapt and implement a practical intervention to facilitate high quality, comprehensive post-diagnosis care for dementia in traditional primary care settings. The proposal will support the career development of Dr. Halima Amjad who aims to develop practical patient- and clinician-centered strategies to improve the care of older adults with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) leads to acute cardiac dysfunction, known as cardiorenal syndrome type 3 (CRS3), which is associated with increased mortality and has no specific therapy. Our overall hypothesis is that AKI deleteriously affects normal energy metabolism and that the deficiency of metabolites necessary to maintain cardiac energy production is the underlying mechanism behind cardiac dysfunction after AKI. Completion of the Aims of this proposal will identify readily available therapies to improve cardiac function after AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative People who inject drugs (PWID) are at risk for HIV, and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) could be an effective means of HIV prevention. PrEP uptake is low among PWID because of numerous barriers, one of which is stigma due to multiple intersecting characteristics such as drug use, race/ ethnicity, sexual identity, gender, poverty, HIV, and PrEP (i.e., intersectional stigma). This study aims to determine the relationship between intersectional stigma and PrEP willingness and uptake, as well as associations with other service use (i.e., healthcare, drug treatment, pharmacies, or syringe exchange programs) over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Black adults experience disproportionate alcohol-related mortality and morbidity, and depression symptoms among Black adults are associated with more alcohol use and problems. With the ultimate goal of informing alcohol interventions for Black adults with depression, the proposed study aims to elucidate the momentary reciprocal associations between depression symptoms and alcohol use and problems among Black adults as well as the influence of racial stressors and symptoms in acute risk for alcohol use and problems among Black adults with varying severities of depression symptoms. This training and research represent a logical extension of the Applicant’s research program and will facilitate the acquisition and integration of knowledge on co- occurring depression and alcohol use and problems; micro-longitudinal methodology and data analytic techniques; minority health and health disparities; and grantsmanship and dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An inability to maintain genome integrity is associated with a loss of cellular homeostasis and several human diseases including cancer. Histone H2A variants are emerging as key components of chromatin that function in genome integrity that are often dysregulated in cancer. Our goal here is to identify how histone H2A variants collaborate with PARP1 and KDM5A to promote DNA repair and genome integrity pathways, including how their dysregulation may be targeted therapeutically using radiotherapy and PARPi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although acyclovir was approved by the FDA for use against herpes simplex infections back on March 29, 1982, latency has precluded curing herpes infections. Latency, which occurs in neurons, also poses a major challenge to the development of prophylactic or therapeutic vaccines. Despite many years of hard and clever work, the regulation of latency and reactivation still eludes us. This proposal tests an integrative model in which the efforts to silence the infecting virus by the infected cell are successfully counteracted by the virus in most cells. However, these efforts are not counteracted in the neurons to be latently infected, such that the persistence of the virus in the latent state is secured. Reactivation of latency would then occur when this silencing of the viral genomes is locally disrupted in the domains of the nuclei of the latently infected neuron where the latent genomes sit. This proposal tackles a major unaddressed gap in our knowledge of the pathobiology of herpes infections, thus opening a new path to explore towards the development of better therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optimizing one’s behavior to obtain benefits while avoiding threats is critical for survival and is disrupted in many psychiatric disorders. In this project I will characterize the makeup and dynamics of brainstem noradrenergic circuits that coordinate behavioral responses for both achieving positive and avoiding negative outcomes. Results from these studies may help identify new treatment strategies for neuropsychiatric disorders including PTSD, addiction, and depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Nutritional and dietary modifications are key components to the management of many pediatric chronic conditions yet are often difficult for youth and families to accomplish, causing significant morbidity and reduced life-expectancy. Clinical investigators with knowledge of behavioral, biomedical, nutritional, and clinical trials sciences are critically needed to develop empirically-tested prevention models and clinical interventions that improve dietary adherence, nutritional status, and long-term health and quality of life outcomes for youth. Graduates of this fellowship program will be national leaders who are team scientists and will have a significant impact on research in child behavior and nutrition and relevant health outcomes for many years to come.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Child Behavior and Nutrition

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: US adults have become increasingly sedentary – which greatly increases risk for cardiovascular disease and mortality - thus necessitating a need to elucidate simple, cost-effective methods to mitigate its harms. This study will use state of the art measures and analytic procedures to prospectively evaluate the purported benefits (improvement in cardiometabolic risk factors) and risks (vascular damage to the lower limbs, musculoskeletal pain) associated with standing and its pattern of accumulation in the highest risk group in the US - African Americans living in the stroke belt. Findings will improve our understanding of whether standing should be endorsed as an alternate activity to sedentary behavior and provide key foundational information critical to the success of future trials and ultimately public health guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The directed movement of protein-associated membrane-bound compartments is a fundamental process required for the proper functioning of all eukaryotic cells, particularly those with long projections such as neurons that extend into and out of the spinal cord. Many neurodegenerative diseases including hereditary spastic paraplegias can be caused by defects in organelle transport. The proposed research will determine how membrane trafficking and homeostasis in the central nervous system are appropriately regulated, enhancing our fundamental understanding of these processes, which should facilitate the future identification of therapeutic targets for disease intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to understand the role of genetic risk for cannabis use in predicting mental health, brain development, and cannabis use behavior in two adolescent populations. Aims 1 and 2 will identify the differences in behavior and brain development that arise from genetic variability, and Aim 3 will incorporate these measures into a prediction model for adolescent cannabis use. Results of this work will be of particular importance to public health and policy discussions surrounding the increased prevalence and legalization of cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Conserved cell signaling pathways such Hedgehog and Hippo pathways play essential roles in embryonic development and adult tissue homeostasis in species ranging from Drosophila to human. Deregulation of Hedgehog and Hippo pathway activities has been implicated in many types of human cancer. Understanding how Hedgehog and Hippo pathways are regulated and how these and other signaling pathways are integrated to control embryonic development and adult tissue homeostasis should not only provide novel insights into the etiology of human disease but may also provide new avenues for therapeutic treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Alterations in receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) signaling cause a wide variety of diseases from bone diseases to defects in wound healing, to cancer. There are many types of RTK, including several subsets that are very poorly understood. Applying methods that have yielded valuable insight for other RTKs – and have identified new therapeutic approaches – our proposed research aims to understand how poorly understood RTKs (notably those regulated by WNTs) are regulated, adding important knowledge that we hope will reveal new therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer mortality is expected to increase by 42% to 442,926 deaths worldwide by 2030 with 87% of cervical cancer deaths occurring in low and middle income countries. Patient navigation programs enhance access to care, promote self-efficacy, and sustain patient engagement with care, and have been shown to improve cancer outcomes, particularly among marginalized groups, rural populations, and impoverished communities. This research will contribute to the critical gap in the scientific literature describing the adaptation of cervical cancer patient navigation strategies to optimize programs across local contexts in low- and middle- income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Anesthesiologists take care of patients in multiple clinical areas, including the operating room, the intensive care unit, the pain clinic and the preoperative clinic. In all of these settings, they have the opportunity to improve care and outcome of patients with a wide range of disorders. To continue leading the way in advancing our understanding of diverse diseases and developing better interventions in the perioperative period requires highly trained and skilled practitioners dedicated to research in anesthesia. Integrated training programs such as the one proposed are essential to produce these future leaders of our field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The brain and gastrointestinal system mutually communicate through the vagus nerve to influence a wide range of behavioral and physiological functions, including emotional affect, cognition, feeding behavior, digestion, metabolism, and immune function. The proposed multi-PI research program applies novel translational approaches in a mouse model of early life stress (ELS) to reveal the transcriptional and connectional features of developing vagal sensory and motor neuronal subtypes, and to investigate enduring ELS-induced disturbances to vagal neural phenotypes and functions. Experimental outcomes will provide new insight into the role of vagal neurons and circuits in mediating the lifespan impact of ELS on behavior and physiology, with potential clinical implications for vagal nerve-targeted therapies to treat emotional, cognitive, and physiological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: THE ACADEMY OF NATURAL SCIENCES OF PHILADELPHIA
PHR: Seeds to STEM proposes a bilingual culturally appropriate program that educates low- income Black and Latino children ages 3-5, their families, and preschool teachers about childhood nutrition, early STEM and literacy, and kindergarten readiness. It has an innovative focus on food access and serves populations in under-accredited early childhood care and learning centers, including home-based childcare providers. Seeds to STEM will be piloted in two major cities (Philadelphia, PA and Los Angeles, CA) and its three product deliverables will be distributed nationwide via a website and multiple professional dissemination networks.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative We propose a new TB-HIV Training Program (TBHTP) at the University of Nairobi and the Kenya Medical Research Institute in collaboration with the University of Washington to conduct training in TB-HIV co-infection research. To address the persistent problem of TB as the leading cause of death in people living with HIV infection, we developed a program to enhance training and local capacity in a high TB endemic country and train the next generation of leaders who will discover novel research and public health strategies to combat the TB epidemic.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to AHRQ’s mission “…to produce evidence to make health care safer, higher quality, more accessible, equitable, and affordable, and to work within the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and with other partners to make sure that the evidence is understood and used.” It will employ a range of systems improvement approaches to generate evidence to improve patient safety, healthcare quality, and accessibility for transgender patients– thus making healthcare more equitable for this vulnerable patient population. Through an innovative partnership with the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH), the evidence generated through this research will be translated into a TRANS-SAFE certification program for healthcare organizations, ensuring that the evidence is understood and used at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria contain a number of distinct RNA-based immune systems to protect them from attack by viruses and viruses have evolved ways to fight back and escape destruction by these immune systems. Our studies will define the molecular mechanisms that underlie these sophisticated bacterial immune systems as well as the viral systems that obstruct immunity. The information that we gain will expand our ability to exploit these natural systems as powerful research tools with far-reaching biotechnological and biomedical applications including diagnosis and treatment of human genetic disorders and combatting viruses and bacteria and that cause human disease and the spread of antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to assess the extent to which environmental and neighborhood-level exposures are related to time-to-pregnancy and infertility risk in Black women. This will be the first study focused on structural determinants of infertility in Black women. This work seeks to identify explanations for the racial disparity in infertility by focusing on risk factors of particular relevance to this group, identify opportunities for intervention, and promote a more equitable and inclusive framework for fertility research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cognitive impairment in Parkinson’s disease (PD) is extremely prevalent, affecting more than 80% of patients over the course of their disease, yet few treatment options exist for these disabling symptoms. Dysfunction in prefrontal cortex and subcortical areas likely contributes to PD cognitive impairment, however, very little is known about the activity of and connectivity of these two brain regions. Here, we propose to investigate cognitive networks in PD and to deliver low-frequency deep brain stimulation (DBS), a stimulation pattern with promising early results on cognition, while assessing the effects on a cognitively demanding inhibitory control task and prefrontal-subcortical electrophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary sarcoidosis is a condition that ranges in severity from mild and self-limiting--meaning it goes away without chronic therapy--to life-threatening with end-stage irreversible organ damage. There are no reliable “tools” available to the clinician that provide useful information about a patient’s future risk of having progressive lung disease and without these tools, clinicians cannot make the best care decisions for their patients. This study was designed to address these unmet clinical needs by creating and testing these “tools” using blood test results and clinical information from several groups of people across the United State who have sarcoidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicidal ideation is strikingly common among people living with HIV worldwide, leading to higher burden of disease for both mental illness and HIV, poor HIV care engagement, increased transmission risk, and loss of life. In this K08 Career Development Award, Dr. Knettel proposes to develop and pilot test a 3-session, nurse- delivered telehealth counseling intervention to reduce suicidality and improve HIV care engagement among people living with HIV in Tanzania. By completing the proposed research and training plans, Dr. Knettel seeks to create a scalable intervention model to address a critical public health challenge, while gaining the needed skills to transition to independence as an academic researcher.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Temporal lobe epilepsy is among the most prevalent and least therapeutically responsive variants of epilepsy. It is characterized by a set of debilitating symptoms, including seizures, cognitive problems, and emotional disturbances. These symptoms combine to impose a significant health burden, which could benefit from improved treatment options. This proposal focuses on determining how a hippocampal circuit, the dentate gyrus, may contribute to temporal lobe epilepsy and may be a viable therapeutic target to ameliorate the devastating symptoms of this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glial cells play critical roles in nervous system function, and their dysfunction can lead to a range of diseases from neurodevelopmental disorders to neurodegeneration and even cancer. Significant progress has been made in understanding neuron-glia interactions at synapses and axons, but how glia support neuronal cell bodies remains poorly defined due to the lack of genetic access to only those specific glial cells associated with the soma. By utilizing powerful, in vivo molecular-genetic approaches in Drosophila to study this universal phenomenon, our work will lay the foundation for mechanistically interrogating how glial interactions at neuronal cell bodies regulate CNS health and disease across species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Nearly half of patients with heart failure die within 5 years of diagnosis. A number of medicines for heart failure target a protein called PKG which resides in heart muscle and in blood vessels. Turning on PKG preserves heart muscle strength but often causes excess and unsafe drops in blood pressure. We discovered that a protein called MLK3 cooperates with PKG to improve failing heart muscle but does not carry out the PKG blood pressure reducing effect. This project will determine how MLK3 protects heart muscle without affecting blood pressure, so that this knowledge could be used to develop new treatment strategies for heart failure which avoid excess low blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: FOX CHASE CHEMICAL DIVERSITY CENTER, INC
PHR: Chagas disease is caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi (T. cruzi) and spread by Triatominae, or "kissing bugs". It is endemic in South America but has spread to people living elsewhere due to immigration of infected individuals and also travel to endemic regions. While current treatments are relatively toxic, we have found a new class of small molecules that kill multiple stages of the T. cruzi life cycle without apparent toxicities, thus affording hope for the discovery of a safer and more effective cure for patients who suffer from this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chemotherapy remains a standard neoadjuvant therapy for triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), but chemoresistance is the major cause of the chemotherapeutic failure of TNBC patients. Herein, we found dual serine/threonine and tyrosine protein kinase (DSTYK) is responsible for the chemoresistance of TNBC. Therefore, we will illustrate the function by which DSTYK promotes chemoresistance and try to explore an exosome-mediated strategy for neutralizing DSTYK’s function and attenuating the chemoresistance in TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance As the proportion of older adults in the population continues to expand, magnifying the relative impact of their decisions, it is increasingly imperative to better understand changes in decision making across the life span before and throughout all stages of significant cognitive impairment related to Alzheimers Disease and related dementias. Increasing interdisciplinary research combining psychology, neuroscience/neurology, medicine, and economics has tremendous potential for increasing translation of science for real-world impact to better understand and alleviate the burden of Alzheimers Disease and related dementias. The long-term goal of this network is to conduct integrative and multidisciplinary research that contributes directly to interventions aimed at improving health and well being in the daily lives of aging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is an aggressive disease with dismal survival rates. We propose to evaluate a PET tracer to quantify a targetable and potentially prognostic feature of PDAC, oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), in preclinical studies. Since OXPHOS activity is associated with progression of certain high-risk, premalignant lesions, accumulation of 18F-BnTP, a potential biomarker of OXPHOS activity, may illuminate indeterminate lesions requiring immediate intervention and allow optimization of therapeutic regimens targeting OXPHOS activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Integrating Chemistry and Evolution to Illuminate Biology and Enable Novel Therapeutics Project Narrative  Our laboratory has led three research programs at the interface of chemistry and evolution. We developed an approach to the synthesis and discovery of bioactive small molecules that combines powerful aspects of biological evolution with synthetic organic chemistry; we developed base editing and prime editing, two genome editing technologies that collectively enable introduction of all possible point mutations, insertions, and deletions at targeted DNA sequences in human cells without cutting the DNA double helix; and we have applied these technologies to treat animal models of human genetic diseases by directly correcting the mutations that cause the diseases. This MIRA renewal seeks to advance these three research programs towards novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precise control over gene expression programs is critical for cellular differentiation, and when control is lost, outcomes can be tragic, ranging from developmental disorders to cancer. Therefore, understanding how chromatin and epigenetic marks control gene expression will be highly beneficial for preventing and treating diseases in which cellular programming defects are central. This project defines how interplay between chromatin elements and transcription factors regulates gene expression programs and cell-type specification during vertebrate development.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults have experienced significant increases in opioid use disorder (OUD) or overdose (OD) in the last decade despite a decrease in the number of opioid prescriptions, dictating a critical need for research to identify factors beyond prescription opioid use that may contribute to the conditions. The proposed research, which is responsive to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality’s special interest in research to address substance use disorders, will provide evidence on the associations of poor pain control, multimorbidity, and the interactions of opioids with comorbid drug use with risk for OUD or OD in older adults. Findings from this proposed study will inform interventions to address the dual crises of chronic pain and OUD or OD in older populations.

PROJECT_TITLE: Pain, Multimorbidity, Opioid-Drug Interactions and Risk for Opioid Use Disorder or Overdose in Older Adults

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  High blood sugar, cholesterol, and fat increase a person’s risk of developing heart disease. We treat each of these changes individually, which means that our treatments are not as effective as they could be. In this project, we will create a computer program to help us understand how altered blood sugar and fat interact to change the function of our blood vessels and lead to heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a debilitating condition that often affects people in the prime of life resulting in right heart failure with severe impairments in quality of life and exercise capacity. In this project, we will directly measure peripheral oxygen (O2) utilization at the skeletal muscle and mitochondrial level during exertion in people with PAH for the first time, and then conduct a randomized clinical trial of leg-muscle focused exercise training to improve muscle O2 utilization and exercise capacity. As a result of this work, we will be able to determine the mechanisms and independent role of skeletal muscle abnormalities in PAH related symptoms, as well as their ability to respond to a novel and easy to implement leg-muscle exercise program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The discovery of ligandable RNA-protein interactions is vital for deciphering the cellular functions and molecular mechanisms of regulatory RNAs that act through the formation of dynamic ribonucleoprotein complexes, but remains a formidable challenge. This proposal aims to exploit reactivity of proteinaceous lysines at RNA-protein interaction interface by leveraging quantitative chemoproteomic technology and heretofore unknown mechanism of action exerted by phloroglucinol meroterpenoid natural products. The success of the proposed research will deliver innovative chemical tools and proteomic methods that enrich our understanding of the pathophysiological functions of RNA-protein interactions and identify the basis for their therapeutic effects in human diseases.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Baylor College of Medicine, in collaboration with the University of Texas School of Public Health, the University of Eswatini, and the Eswatini Ministry of Health (including national HIV and Tuberculosis programs) will conduct training in HIV/AIDS research methods with a focus on pediatrics (infants, children, adolescents) and tuberculosis co-morbidity. Leveraging dual Emaswati-US mentor teams, we will conduct long-term US based and in-country research training in four essential programmatic areas including epidemiology, biostatistics and bio-informatics, behavioral science and health promotion, and health systems management and policy. Our goal is to strengthen clinical and translational research capacity in Eswatini while simultaneously producing high-quality researchers who will successfully transition to independent funding and lead national efforts to end the HIV/TB co-pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is an injury to the developing brain that accounts for millions of years lived with disability worldwide and can be modeled in mice by transient late gestation prenatal hypoxia. Epigenetic modifying genes, like the histone variant H3f3b, are upregulated in the corticothalamic neurons of mice exposed to prenatal hypoxia. To gain insight into how epigenetic regulators may modulate outcomes after hypoxic insult, I will test if H3f3b protects developing neurons from more severe injury after prenatal hypoxia and if prenatal hypoxia persistently disrupts the epigenetic trajectories of corticothalamic neurons.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn metabolic disorder caused by a metabolic deficiency in the hydrolysis of phenylalanine to Tyrosine, and the only currently available treatment options for this disease are largely focused on dietary management and supplementation of missing enzymatic components. The prevailing view of this disorder is primarily concerned with mutations in the gene coding for the enzyme responsible for this metabolic process, phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), but fails to acknowledge the functional role of long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) in this inborn metabolic disorder. Based on genetic evidence that mutations of the lncRNA HULC and mouse lncRNA Pair lead to PAH enzymatic deficiencies, potential treatment strategy utilizing specially designed HULC mimics might restore the enzymatic activity of the 11 PAH mutations most commonly attributed to PKU, thereby demonstrating the biological importance of lncRNA-mediated molecular events in human genetic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every year more than 795,000 people in the United States have a stroke with currently around 4.7 million stroke survivors, and approximately 20% of the survivors go on to develop cognitive impairments and dementia later in life. This research project will seek an improved basic scientific understanding of the how the complex biological interactions between vascular and demographic risk factors (e.g., disadvantaged neighborhoods), baseline brain and cognitive health, and adaptive or maladaptive brain changes following an ischemic stroke, underlie the biology of vascular contributions to cognitive impairments and dementia (VCID). It will also seek development of diagnostic and prognostic tools based on non-invasive high-quality MRI biomarkers which may aid in positively altering disease progression and reducing the burden of illness on patients due to post ischemic stroke VCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE P-glycoprotein is the cell's cleaning machine, pumping harmful substances to the outside of the cell. It is among the seven most important transporters responsible for regulating drug absorption and disposition that now require documentation of drug interactions for approval of any new drugs by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). By learning more about how P-glycoprotein recognizes the chemicals that it carries out of the cell, scientists may redesign drugs to prevent P-glycoprotein from interfering with their valuable effects in the treatment of many diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are developing a novel technology for indefinitely preserving donor kidneys for transplant in an extremely low-temperature, vitrified (glass-like) state and subsequently rewarming them on-demand using nanotechnology. This method for cryopreserving or “banking” kidneys prior to transplant will allow a new paradigm for transplantation that improves donor/recipient matching, allows for better patient preparation, facilitates tolerance induction protocols, and increases organ utilization; all while improving kidney durability and patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Gene-diet interaction analysis seeks to understand how each person’s response to diet is dependent on their genetic makeup. This project is a combined research and training program that combines new statistical methods and data types to better identify these interactions, focusing on the Mediterranean-style diet pattern and its impact on the risk of metabolic diseases like type 2 diabetes. Its results will help researchers, by validating improved scientific methods, and clinicians, by providing a foundation for genome-guided dietary recommendations to prevent metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to develop robust analytical technologies that can provide structural information for biologically important proteins and molecular machines, such as those involved in neurodegenerative disorders and aging (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease). New methodologies to elucidate the sites of protein modifications will be developed, with the knowledge gained on modification sites to be used to enhance our understanding of the cellular mechanisms for a range of biological processes, including Alzheimer's disease. This is a particularly pressing goal in view of the rapid aging of our nation’s population and the rising costs of care for patients with neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent suicide is a major public health crisis, with evidence of increasing rates in youth across the past decade, but we lack robust predictors of future suicidal behavior. We will examine neural measures of reward valuation as prospective predictors of suicidal behavior and responses to interpersonal stress in a large high- risk sample of adolescents followed for 6 months after acute psychiatric treatment. This study will advance understanding of pathways to suicidal behavior in adolescents and inform methods of identifying adolescents most in need of immediate intervention to prevent suicide.
