IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Patients who are at high-risk for developing ovarian cancer have limited options to lower their risk without enduring surgical menopause and multiple unfavorable health-related outcomes. Atovaquone, an orally available anti-malarial medication, blocks oxidative phosphorylation by interfering with mitochondrial electron transport and slows ovarian cancer growth in vitro and in vivo. It has the potential to prevent cancerous transformation in the ovaries and fallopian tubes of high-risk women, eliminating the need for premature removal of their gynecologic structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Neovascular age-related macular degeneration is a leading cause of blindness worldwide. We use novel approaches to understand the causes of fibrosis and test potential therapies to prevent it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Severe malaria due to Plasmodium falciparum kills over a million people a year. Resistance to existing antimalarial drugs has created an urgent need for new drugs. Ongoing antimalarial drug development depends on improving our understanding of the basic biology of this pathogen. Our proposal investigates uses antimalarials to investigate the biology of an essential metabolic pathway, the MEP pathway, and will further our understanding of how antimalarial susceptibility is mediated by the HAD family of parasite proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the state-of-the-art method to assess consumers’ preferences for new products, discrete choice experiments (DCEs) have been increasingly applied to study the impacts of potential policies on tobacco use behaviors, particularly in the areas of product standards and messaging development (e.g., communication and campaigns). The overarching goal of this project is to conduct systematic reviews and synthesize DCE evidence on product standards and messaging development, further combining existing DCEs with Nielsen Retail Scanner data and nationally representative surveys to improve the accuracy of policy impact prediction by mitigating hypothetical bias in DCEs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory dysfunction after spinal cord injury is the primary public health concern. The proposed study is designed to test a novel therapeutic strategy to fight this complication by using respiratory training in combination with electrical spinal cord stimulation applied transcutaneously in patients with chronic spinal cord injury. This knowledge will help to reduce the burden of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses the critical need for an effective treatment for cocaine use disorder, for which there are no approved drugs. Successful completion of this project will lead to the development of the first oral treatment for cocaine use disorder that reduces cocaine craving and addiction. Given the millions of people worldwide with CUD and the tens of thousands of cocaine-related deaths each year, this new treatment will have enormous public health benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelin regeneration often fails in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and human neonatal hypoxic injury leading to Cerebral Palsy (CP), and contributes significantly to ongoing neurological dysfunction and disease progression. Here we identify primary cilia as a critical new signaling module that controls the oligodendrocyte progenitor cell (OPC) response to white matter injury, identify how the cilium controls OPC behavior and the ciliary controlled signaling mechanisms within OPCs, and map the proteome of OPC primary cilia during development and remyelination in vivo. This grant will show that primary cilia signaling is a key effector of biological change in OPCs, and will identify potential therapeutic targets for debilitating conditions such as MS and CP, where white matter injury repair can be dysfunctional.

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gamma oscillations are produced in the primary motor cortex during reaching or exploratory movements and disrupted by disease. This proposal uncovers how gamma oscillations coordinate neurons in primary motor cortex and determines their behavioral relevance. Understanding this is important for interpreting their dysfunction in clinical populations and devising better therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics (CPT) Postdoctoral Training Program at UCSF is to train the next generation of clinical pharmacologist researchers so that they may pursue independently funded careers as academic investigators or clinical pharmacologists who can translate advances in biomedical research to the discovery, development and use of pharmacological therapies. We achieve this goal through a rigorous program structure of mentored research training accompanied by didactic coursework and participation in a biweekly seminar series. Throughout the course of the training program, trainees are exposed to a wide variety of research topics and interests leading to the development of a well-trained and diverse group of clinical-scientist investigators who will serve as tomorrow's leaders in clinical pharmacology research and practice in academia as well as the pharmaceutical, biotechnology industries and regulatory agencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Genetic mutations characteristic of myeloid neoplasms can be detected in the blood of up to 80% of healthy individuals over age 50 using sensitive genomic sequencing, a phenomenon termed clonal hematopoiesis (CH). While CH does increase the risk of blood cancer development, it does not predestine an individual for future disease progression, and as such, major unresolved questions are what factors promote expansion of these mutant clones in certain people and can these mechanisms be exploited to prevent disease progression in “at-risk” individuals? Here, we will investigate the role of inflammatory signals in providing a selection pressure for preferential growth of clones with DNMT3A mutations and identify novel points for potential disease interception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Motile cilia are microtubule-based organelles that produce a driving force for cellular locomotion or fluid flow. In humans, defects in motile cilia can lead to infertility, chronic respiratory disease, and even reversal of the orientation of the bodily organs. This project aims to reveal the detailed workings of the mechanoregulatory network that controls ciliary motility, which will help us to better understand the molecular basis of cilia-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) initiative is a prominent research effort to identify differences in brain functions that place people at risk for mental disorders, but many of these functions are difficult to define and measure, have ambiguous links to neurobiology, and do not have selective relationships with specific disorders. The proposed project seeks to evaluate whether efficiency of evidence accumulation (EEA), a precisely defined brain process that has been well-characterized in computational modeling and neurophysiological research, can move the RDoC initiative forward by improving measurement of complex brain functioning and better explaining its relationship with a wide array of mental disorders. Insights from this project could be used to accelerate neuroscience research into the causes and treatments of psychological disorders and refine diagnostic criteria in mental health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The research proposed here is directed towards understanding the protein machinery responsible for the biogenesis of the cell envelopes of Gram-negative bacteria and mycobacterium tuberculosis. These multi- layered envelopes are essential for survival and provide intrinsic drug resistance. A better understanding of the lipid transporters that assemble the cell envelope may lead to the discovery of inhibitors that could ultimately be developed for therapeutic uses to treat drug-resistant infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low serum bicarbonate levels, even within the normal laboratory range, are strongly associated with increased risks of endothelial dysfunction, cardiovascular disease, worsening kidney disease and death. The current proposal will investigate whether bicarbonate administration in patients who have received a kidney transplant will improve the health and function of arteries and the transplanted kidney. Overall, the proposed research will provide important new scientific evidence upon which physicians can base recommendations to kidney transplant recipients to decrease the risk of developing cardiovascular disease and worsening kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Inactive lifestyle leads to a variety of diseases, including metabolic disorders, cardiovascular dysfunctions, and mental illness, and the sedentary behavior caused by diseases exacerbates pathogenesis. Irisin was identified as an exercise-induced hormone that benefits multiple tissues/organs. Elucidating the molecular basis of irisin- mediated effects via its integrin receptor may reveal a novel mechanism of hormone-induced integrin signaling, and therapeutically, it will assist drug and antibody development to treat sedentary individuals to prevent disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of the proposed study is to examine the neuromuscular mechanisms underlying the therapeutic effect of hippotherapy and determine whether repeated exposure to a pelvic perturbation force would be effective in improving trunk postural control and gait of children with cerebral palsy (CP). The results from this study will lead to innovative clinical therapies aimed at improving trunk postural control and locomotor function in children with CP. We anticipate that this paradigm will be extremely useful for improving trunk postural control and locomotor function in children with CP through robotic hippotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Deficits in brain processes associated with executive functioning (i.e., decision-making) are postulated to contribute to appetite dysregulation and subsequent obesity. Theoretical models propose explanations for these associations, but it is unknown if: A) underlying differences in brain regions associated with executive function cause weight gain, and/or, if: B) diet-induced neuroinflammation causes changes to brain structure in regions associated with executive function, particularly during developmental periods (e.g., childhood, adolescence) when the brain is undergoing changes in executive function and appetite regulation. During periods of critical physical growth and brain maturation (e.g., birth to adolescence), the current proposal will investigate the temporal and directional cause vs. consequence associations between executive function and obesity development, while also examining potential moderating and attenuating effects of factors know to increase obesity risk and executive functioning development, such as sex, puberty, social and economic disparities, and infant nutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Minimally displaced femoral neck fractures have traditionally been treated with internal fixation, however, preliminary data suggests treating these fractures with arthroplasty may yield better outcomes. While promising, data supporting the use of arthroplasty is limited, and clinical practice would benefit from a definitive trial that clearly defines the optimal surgical treatment for patients with a minimally displaced femoral neck fracture. We propose an 18-month planning period to finalize the patient-centered trial protocol, establish trial infrastructure, and prepare clinical sites for initiation for a multi-center randomized controlled trial designed to address this need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While newer antihyperglycemic agents have reported cardiovascular benefits, little is known about how to choose among an expanded range of medication choices for older patients. The proposed research aims to understand the comparative effectiveness and safety of these agents in older adults in routine care while applying, developing, and disseminating state-of-the-art analytical and causal inference methods. The findings will improve the evidence base for decision-making available for clinicians treating older patients, promote effective and safe drug therapy, and ultimately improve the care of older patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive vascular disease with high morbidity and mortality. The proposed studies will define the role of vacuolar protein sorting (Vps34) in regulating increased proliferation and survival of pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cells in PAH; will provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that are important in the pathogenesis of PAH; and will explore whether Vps34 could serve as a target pathway for pulmonary vascular remodeling- focused therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Craniosynostosis is a congenital craniofacial disorder caused by genetic mutations and environmental insults such as antidepressant drugs. This proposal investigates how gene mutations interplay with maternal usage of antidepressant drugs, leading to craniosynostosis, and whether MSC implantation can rescue related skull and neurocognitive defects. The knowledge gained from this study will improve our understanding of gene- environment interaction in craniosynostosis and guide our therapeutic efforts in MSC-mediated tissue regeneration in treating craniosynostosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With hundreds of genetic tests becoming available for clinical use, adding genomic sequencing for all newborns at birth to predict and prevent future diseases is becoming a possibility. Our research aims to extend the Precision Medicine Policy and Treatment (PreEMPT) Model – a sophisticated computer model capable of simulating short- and long-term clinical benefits and estimating the cost-effectiveness of integrating different genomic sequencing strategies into clinical care for newborns for a wide variety of heritable conditions – to evaluate outcomes through adulthood and testing of siblings of newborns with mutations. We will also evaluate targeted strategies for newborn genomic sequencing with the goal of reducing race-based medical care disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Immune cells are instrumental in the fatal neurological disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), but how and why remain to be established. Herein, we propose to use a state-of-the-art technology to elucidate the characteristics of immune cells in ALS. If successful, the generated information will have far-reaching implications for the development of biomarkers and treatments for ALS and related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell migration is a fundamental property of most cells and contributes to development, wound healing, immune responses and a host of other processes. This project focuses on two poorly understood processes in cell migration: nuclear positioning and endocytic recycling of integrin adhesion receptors. Deciphering the contribution of these processes to cell migration will provide new basic information to understand cell migration and may help identify new strategies for intervention in cases where cell migration becomes unregulated, such as cancer metastasis and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in two women and one in five men will suffer an osteoporotic fracture after age 50, causing pain, diminished quality of life, and costing $20 billion/year in the United States. Physical loading of the skeleton and weight-bearing exercise can increase bone density, but is not as effective in older people and animals. This project will address this issue by testing new drugs that can potentially work together with exercise to increase bone density and strengthen osteoporotic bones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this Training Grant is to prepare qualified postdoctoral trainees in Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolism for scientific research careers that significantly impact on the health-related research needs of the United States. This training program will utilize Stanford University’s world-class faculty and resources in the fields of basic, translational and population health research in endocrinology with a primary focus on diabetes. Trainees who graduate from this program will be well-prepared to independently lead (within an academic or industrial setting), create and apply new scientific discoveries that enhance public health in areas of diabetes, obesity, bone health and hormone-dependent cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the clinical standard assay for the assessment of kidney function, however existing estimation techniques are imperfect. The goal of this work is to therefore develop, validate and evaluate novel, non-ionizing, non-contrast renal functional MRI markers of blood flow, blood oxygen and GFR using advanced modeling, data acquisitions and image reconstruction approaches. We will evaluate our techniques in a large population of African Americans as a first step towards demonstrating efficacy in all patients with kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The complexity of splicing, a key step in the expression of nearly all human genes, remains daunting, and yet intervention in splicing for treatment of diseases is already bearing fruit. Recent success repairing splicing to treat spinal muscular atrophy and awareness that cancer mutations in splicing factor genes influence tumor progression has exposed new opportunities for basic research on the spliceosome as a pathway to treatments. Given the fundamental conservation of the splicing machinery, this work promises to stimulate new approaches to engineering splicing that will improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Improving access to evidence-based mental health treatment is critical to improving outcomes for children who experience maltreatment. This study will develop and pilot strategies to improve multidisciplinary team functioning and facilitate implementation of a mental health screening and referral protocol in in rural Child Advocacy Centers. The proposed training and research will prepare the investigator to advance NIMH Strategic Objective 4.2 – “establish research-practice partnerships to improve dissemination, implementation, and continuous improvement of evidence-based mental health services” – and has the potential to positively impact public health by improving the capacity of systems in rural areas to meet the mental health needs of vulnerable children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human parental care is compromised under conditions of adversity and/or chronic stress, which in turn compromises neurobehavioral development, including the expression of later life maternal behavior, in the female offspring. Little is known about the neural mechanisms contributing to early adversity-induced disruptions in mother-infant attachment, including how these are transmitted across generations. This application will examine the impact of early life adversity (i.e., induced by resource depletion in rat dam’s nesting environment) on maternal behaviors and mesolimbic dopamine function in the adult female offspring and test a mechanistic role for the stress hormone corticosterone by employing an integrated approach (e.g. environmental perturbation, behavior, pharmacology, in vivo electrophysiology) in order to provide the initial insights into the dopaminergic mechanisms contributing to environmentally-driven alterations in mother-infant attachment, which may facilitate better treatments for improving functional deficits in maternal care during/following adversity exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to gain a greater understanding of basic biological mechanisms in autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) as a path to discover new therapeutic targets. We propose to use cutting-edge genomic technologies to investigate how loss of function of two top ASD risk genes affects protein synthesis and specific neural cell types in the developing brain. Our central goal is to advance our knowledge of novel targetable pathways downstream of ASD genes with potential therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Severely burned patients are highly susceptible to developing life-threatening nosocomial infections due to a significantly weakened immune system, exposure to pathogens during prolonged hospitalization, and emergence of antibiotic resistant pathogens. The information gained in this project will advance current knowledge on the mechanisms by which TLR agonists trigger innate immune memory leading to enhanced antimicrobial responses and resistance to infection. New understandings may be harnessed to develop immunotherapies which enhance immunity and broadly protect severely burned patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although previous randomized controlled trials (RCT)s demonstrate that low-dose aspirin (LDA, 81-100mg/day) reduces the risk of colorectal cancer (CRC), a recent RCT reported that initiating LDA late in life had no benefit on CRC incidence and was potentially detrimental for mortality. Taken together with our compelling preclinical data that aging and age-related processes, such as inflammaging, promote a decrease in the colonic intestinal stem cell (cISC) pool that is normally sensitive to aspirin chemoprevention, we propose to examine the impact of LDA at single cell resolution on colonic epithelium, patient-derived organoids, and urinary PGs in an RCT of older adults and in novel in vivo experimental models to dissect the role of inflammaging on PG signaling in cISCs and colon tumor incidence and progression. These studies could have a significant influence in shaping population guidelines for LDA in chronic disease prevention and the development of precision biomarkers to optimize the risk-benefit profile of LDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PI, White, M.C. R35 GM 122525 Project Narrative  This program is discovering catalytic reactions that selectively perform the atomistic change of C(sp3)– H to C–O, C–N, and C–C in complex molecules, which has been demonstrated to alter their biological function and efficacy as therapeutics. Using these reactions, we are pioneering the area of late-stage functionalization where atomistic changes are made directly on drugs and natural products, circumventing lengthy, individual de novo syntheses, which present a significant technological challenge to drug discovery. To broaden the application of late-stage functionalization, we are inventing catalysts that have a higher tolerance for pre- existing reactive functionality and effect novel site-selectivity; control over three-dimensional outcomes; and C(sp3)–H cross-couplings with O- , N- , and C-containing complex fragments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies aim to reveal subtype-specific molecular elements of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) ion channels, which play a major role in brain function and development. These studies are relevant to public health because dysfunctional NMDARs are implicated in neurological disorders such as depression, and schizophrenia, as well as Alzheimer’s diseases. Understanding the mechanisms by which subtype-specific reagents bind and regulate functions of NMDARs will support the development of therapeutic strategies for these neurological disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  To address the current opioid crisis, a new class of potent non-opioid analgesics has been developed in the investigators’ laboratories. These future drug candidates are designed to target brain circuits involving a family of proteins called glycine receptors. The proposed investigations aim to elucidate the dual roles of the α3 subtype of glycine receptors in alleviating chronic pain and at the same time inhibiting the reward circuits in the brain, thereby reducing the risk of drug dependence and abuse potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An important and often lethal complication after allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (allo-HCT) is graft-vs-host disease (GVHD), in which the donor immune system attacks the patient's tissue. We propose to evaluate a rationally designed oral-ecobiotic capsule that delivers a defined composition of pure bacterial strains, which aims to reduce GVHD and offers advantages of predictable and reproducible pharmacology and would be immediately scalable in future studies. Findings will inform future research not only for the reduction of transplant-related complications including GVHD, but also for other conditions in which GI injury occurs such as chemotherapy and/or radiation-induced toxicity and nonmalignant inflammatory GI conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Combination therapy has shown great promise in addressing the rapid emergence of drug resistance, but the development of effective drug cocktails is lagging due to the challenges in both design and production processes. We propose to address these challenges by identifying drug cocktails produced by individual biosynthetic pathways of microbial origin and overproducing these naturally evolved cocktails using a metabolic division of labor strategy.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because cholangiopathies, which often affect extrahepatic bile ducts, are poorly understood and, therefore, have no effective treatment options. This project will unveil cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying extrahepatic bile duct responses to injury and inform potential strategies for treatment of cholangiopathies and prevention of their complications. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission that pertains to improvement of people’s health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The auditory system is remarkably plastic and can flexibly response to acoustic cues depending on task demands and context allowing for many auditory behaviors such as communication, language acquisition, and learning. This proposal aims to investigate the neural basis of flexible auditory learning using in vivo electrophysiology, behavior, and optogenetics to understand how the auditory system flexibly gates the behavioral relevance of sounds in dynamic environments. The results from the proposed experiments will provide critical insights into improved diagnosis and treatment of hearing deficits caused by disease or injury and will inform targeted therapies for central auditory processing disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: Impaired placental function is the root cause of preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction, and fetal morbidity and mortality, but the underlying causes of placental dysfunction are not well characterized. Improper signaling of the chemokine CXCL12 (L12) leads to placental dysfunction, but the mechanisms leading to and the potential consequences of altered L12-dependent signaling remain unclear. This proposal will advance the comprehension of L12-induced actions in early placental development to improve pregnancy success and elucidate novel therapies to treat pregnancy complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal uses in vitro, in cellulo and in vivo strategies to understand the mechanism of action of a new class of small molecules, modified polycyclic compounds (MPCs), to address the unmet need for therapeutics for Myotonic Dystrophy (DM), the most common cause of muscular dystrophy. A design-model-test cycle will be used to understand the mechanism(s) of action of these new compounds, systematically refine their efficacy and test their therapeutic potential in patient-derived DM cells lines and animal models. The successful completion of this project will provide a new class of small molecules, a better understanding of their mechanism of action and in vivo data from multiple animal models supporting their future therapeutic potential – all critical steps towards future clinical studies for this complex and devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Parkinson's disease (PD) are progressive neurodegenerative diseases that destroy brain cells over time. Markers to detect changes in AD brain and to identify groups at high-risk for AD are lacking, as are markers that can distinguish AD from PD. The proposed studies will establish specific biomarkers for AD and PD by combining the physical features, surface marker profiles, miRNAs, and proteins in CSF EVs, and establish the neurologically relevant gene targets of AD EV miRNAs in human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: It has been long known that different types of RTK exhibit great diversification in receptor activation and regulation. To better understand the diversification in RTK activation, we propose to determine the active structures of MuSK, TAM and c-MET receptors, three unique RTKs that are predicted to use distinct mechanisms for receptor activation. Solving the active structures of different members of RTK family will reveal similarities and differences in molecular mechanisms underlying the activation of RTK.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common chronic liver disease that is linked to obesity. NAFLD has no approved medications, due to incomplete understanding of the underlying molecular mechanisms and its progression to steatohepatitis (NASH) and fibrosis, which are the major causes of morbidity and mortality. This project takes a translational approach by focusing on kisspeptin, a liver factor we have determined critically controls liver fat and NAFLD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Task-based functional MRI (fMRI) is a non-invasive clinical tool for presurgical localization of eloquent brain areas (e.g. motor and language areas) to prevent post-surgical deficits for patients with brain cancers, epilepsy, or other focal pathologies undergoing surgical resection of the lesion. However, task-based fMRI fails in patients who cannot perform the tasks and in brain areas with impaired neurovascular coupling induced by the lesion. The proposed research aims to create robust and vetted clinical software solutions that will enable emerging fMRI methods, including resting-state fMRI and cerebrovascular reactivity mapping, to greatly increase the patient population who can benefit from presurgical fMRI and to improve confidence in functional localization for surgical planning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE There are large unexplained inter-individual differences in systemic allostatic load and stress reactivity, which may in part be explained by mitochondria. Here we study the effects of chronic dysregulation of mitochondrial function – mitochondrial allostatic load (MAL) – on multisystem stress regulation in humans. This project will establish the influence of MAL on baseline AL as well as multisystem stress reactivity profiles, defining novel psychobiological pathways by which mitochondria may contribute to the maintenance of health and resilience, and to disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Early life environmental exposures can alter the developmental trajectory by disrupting the homeostasis of one or more systems, and in doing so produce identifiable biochemical signatures characteristic of the disease process or outcome. We are proposing a new paradigm that will detect disease years before current clinical and biochemical tests. By doing so we may be able to predict and even prevent diseases decades before any clinical signs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cyclic AMP (cAMP) signaling is central for skin pigmentation and has a significant impact on skin cancer and melanoma risk. Whereas the canonical melanocyte cAMP cascade controls pigmentation by activating pigment gene expression via established mechanisms, we recently identified a second cAMP cascade that is distinct from the canonical pathway and controls pigmentation by regulating melanosome pH. Using novel in vitro and in vivo approaches for the investigation of cAMP, we will identify the upstream and downstream mechanisms of cAMP-dependent regulation of melanosome pH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The poor understanding how red blood cells are produced poses a critical barrier to the development of artificial blood production systems, and of safer and more effective treatments for anemias and polycythemias, which affect millions of people in the U.S. This proposal aims to delineate molecular mechanisms that regulate erythropoiesis in erythropoietic stress and in polycythemia. Results from these studies will significantly improve our understanding of erythropoiesis and will shed light on the etiology of hematological malignancies and facilitate the design of novel therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To date, there are limited data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccination in women who are pregnant or breastfeeding. The goals of this study are to assess the effect of COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy and after delivery on lactation and select infant outcomes. The results of the study will complement ongoing vaccine safety surveillance and will help women and their clinicians make more informed decisions about COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy or while breastfeeding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Breast cancer is the most commonly occurring cancer among women globally, while cardiovascular disease has become a leading cause of death among breast cancer survivors. Commonly used breast cancer treatments are known to cause cardiotoxicity, but the majority of studies have not examined the growing population of young and emerging adult breast cancer patients. The objective of this study is to develop a personalized model of psychosocial factors, traditional CVD risk factors, and molecular markers that predicts risk of cardiotoxicity among YEA breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Receptor-induced Ca2+ signaling controls a wide array of physiological functions including proliferation, metabolism, and secretion. Replenishing the PIP2 lipid at the plasma membrane and Ca2+ stored in the endoplasmic reticulum that are consumed to generate Ca2+ signals during receptor-induced Ca2+ signaling is critical to the homeostasis of receptor-stimulated cells. Our proposed studies will provide new insight into the mechanisms underlying homeostatic regulation of PIP2-Ca2+ signaling and will lay the foundation for advances in treating diseases associated with deficiencies in proteins that regulate the PIP2-Ca2+ signaling system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunction of the inner lining of blood vessels that form the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is implicated in progression and perpetuation of inflammation-associated diseases in the central nervous system, including multiple sclerosis, stroke, traumatic brain injury, dementia, encephalopathies, and brain metastases, that impact the lives of 9 million individuals in the United States and carry an annual cost burden of 300 billion dollars. This study will investigate how changes in the composition of the perivascular extracellular matrix, a dense meshwork of proteins that immediately surrounds the blood vessels, contribute to BBB dysfunction and will focus primarily on the two small leucine-rich proteoglycans (SLRP) decorin and biglycan, which have been observed at abnormally high levels in the perivascular matrix of patients with multiple sclerosis. Understanding the roles of these SLRPs in BBB dysfunction as well as the mechanisms by which they act may allow for the development of novel therapeutic targets for use in the treatment of a wide variety of CNS diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) is the bacterial infection that kills the most people worldwide, especially in India, which has the highest burden in of drug-resistant tuberculosis in the world. Delays in adequate treatment due to slow diagnostic tests and the usual one-size-fits-all treatment strategy lead to new drug resistance, terrible treatment-associated side effects, and high mortality. In this observational cohort study we will assess the individual and combined impact of tools already in practice at our hospital to quickly test for drug resistance and measure drug levels in patients early in treatment to determine if this combination improves response to treatment, decreases the time that people can spread the disease, and reduces side effects commonly associated with TB treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  This project will perform whole-genome RNA sequencing from blood 1 and 3 days after stroke to develop gene profiles using machine learning that predict the outcomes at 90 days after stroke in a derivation cohort; and use the expression of these genes in blood from a separate validation cohort as the input into the same machine learning algorithm to predict 90 day outcomes of the validation cohort with >85% sensitivity and specificity. Gene expression will also be correlated with major clinical variables that are associated with stroke outcome, and utility of clinical variables for prediction of outcome compared to that for the gene expression profiles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative At a single-cell level, mycobacteria grow and divide asymmetrically, producing subpopulations of cells that can survive antibiotic treatment. We have recently discovered that deleting a single gene collapses this heterogeneity. Here, we propose to investigate the function of this gene, with future work aimed at developing better tuberculosis therapies that can target asymmetric growth and division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The training of the next generation of knowledge creators in digestive diseases will require concerted efforts to harness the explosion of information that has been created by advances in genomics, functional genomics, network analysis, stem cell biology, the human microbiome, and other technologies. Now more than ever, a planned approach to the research career development of physician scientists – one that must incorporate solid scientific environment, mentorship, didactic curriculum, monitoring, and inter action – becomes critical to maximize likelihood of success. To preserve a training environment that, despite a challenging funding environment, has continued an exceptional track record of producing leaders in academic gastroenterology, we have retained preceptors from a stellar group of fundamental, translational and clinical scientists who have adapted and incorporated these recent advances while also having actively participated in mentoring.
PROJECT_TERMS: Digestive System Disorders;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Digestive Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ménétrier’s disease is an acquired premalignant hypertrophic gastropathy caused by EGF receptor (EGFR) signaling activation in which the EGFR neutralizing monoclonal antibody, cetuximab, is the first effective medical therapy. My identification of Notch signaling downstream of EGFR signaling in Ménétrier’s disease has led to the design of present studies that will dissect the role of EGFR and Notch signaling in two cardinal features of the disease (loss of parietal cells and foveolar hyperplasia) and optimize pharmacological blockade of EGFR and Notch signaling to improve the treatment of affected individuals. The results of this study will enlighten the detailed pathogenesis of Ménétrier’s disease and lead to the development of clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke affects more than 795,000 Americans each year, kills approximately 140,000 and costs the US $34B peryear; large vessel occlusion (LVO) strokes account for almost 40% of ischemic strokes but cause 95% of mortalities and 62% of long-term dependence. Mechanicalthrombectomy (MT) has emerged as standard of care treatment for LVO stroke but MT is only available at specialized hospitals. DDFPe decreases stroke damage by about 85%, with potential to improve outcomes in stroke patients allowing time for treatment with MT. SPAN is a new program that will test promising agents to improve outcomes in stroke; we propose that SPAN test DDFPe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: At least one-third of patients who receive treatment for major depressive disorder do not attain remission and there is a growing agreement that increased inflammatory activity contributes to the persistence of depressive symptoms in many of these patients, presenting the opportunity for novel treatment approaches. Omega-3 fatty acids reduce signs of inflammation and may have benefit for treatment of depression, especially in combination with other antidepressant drugs. This study will test whether omega-3 fatty acids added to ineffective antidepressant treatment increase compounds that resolve inflammation and whether the increase in these compounds is associated with improved antidepressant response.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Limited information exists pertaining to the physiological relevance of innate immune regulation and the key players driving their phenotypic response following TBI. Completion of these studies will advance our understanding of the novel mechanisms regulating innate immunity and how peripheral-derived monocyte/macrophages dictates neurovascular injury and recovery in the pathophysiology of TBI. Exploiting new ways to promote the pro-resolving phenotype of innate immune cells represents a novel restorative intervention aimed at improving TBI outcomes and expanding novel targets for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pontocerebellar Hypoplasia Type 1b (PCH1b) is a devastating inherited neurological disorder that preferentially affects specific regions of the brain, the pons and the cerebellum, causing children born with this condition to have dramatically reduced lifespans. The mutations that cause PCH1b occur in a gene that encodes a critical component of a molecular machine that is important for the regulation of gene expression. The proposed studies exploit the fruit fly (Drosophila) as a model system to provide insight into molecular mechanisms underpinning PCH1b.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE IgE-mediated food allergy affects 1 in 13 children in the USA. There is no FDA-approved treatment, and allergen immunotherapy treatments are not disease modifying in most patients. The maintenance of allergen- specific IgE, and allergen-specific T cells that support IgE, are poorly understood. We propose to study the maintenance of allergen-specific T cells and their role in IgE class switch in blood, lymph nodes, and mucosal tissues from individuals with IgE-mediated food allergy. Outcomes of this work will support the generation of immunotherapy approaches that alter the course of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lifestyle interventions including physical activity appear to confer important protections to the brain that may delay the onset of symptoms of dementia. Dance movement is a form of physical activity that is promising as a potential activity to help maintain brain health, because it improves cardiorespiratory fitness and balance while providing cognitive challenge and social engagement, all important for maintaining brain health. This proposal seeks to fill key gaps in our basic understanding about the effects of the number of times per week people engage in dance movement on cardiorespiratory fitness and cognition that are essential for planning larger, definitive trials.

PHR: We aim to develop a quantitative risk model for oral cavity cancer patients, 25-37% of whom will experience debilitating post-treatment recurrence. PHR: Project Narrative The proposed HNSCC tumor hallmark targeting and transformable nano-theranostics offer great promise in effectively overcoming the sequential biological barriers for significantly improved imaging sensitivity/specificity and drug delivery efficiency to HNSCC. They have tremendous potentials to be used in precision image-guided treatment for effective detection and elimination of early HNSCC lesions, particularly the aggressive subtypes. The team of experts in head and neck surgical oncology (Dr. Farwell) and medical oncology (Dr. Lam) as well as veterinary surgical oncology (Dr. Steffey) will provide comprehensive clinical expertise to facilitate the clinical development of the proposed novel transformable nano-theranostics that will ultimately benefit many patients with HNSCC.

PHR: Project Narrative: We know that as we age, there is an increased risk of obtaining certain diseases such as vision impairment, dementia, and stroke. Preliminary evidence suggests that visual impairment is associated with post-stroke dementia and cognitive impairment. Investigating the specific types of vision impairment that influence the stroke-dementia relationship as well as the causes, may improve best methods for early diagnosis, preventative strategies, or specific services for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Differentiated service delivery (DSD) is an evidence-based implementation strategy to improve retention in care and viral suppression for people living with HIV in resource-constrained settings. The proposed project seeks to develop a DSD model for PMTCT that is user-centered and designed to enhance retention and viral suppression in the PMTCT population. Thus, the proposed project is relevant to the NICHD’s high-priority research focus on adverse pregnancy and infant outcomes related to prevention and treatment of HIV, as well as the broader mission of the NIH to seek fundamental knowledge to enhance health and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  For HIV-1 infected individuals on suppressive antiretroviral therapy, latent HIV-1 infection of resting memory CD4+ T cells is the major barrier to a cure. Elimination of these latently infected cells by is being pursued as a strategy to cure the infection. This proposal details the establishment of a centralized NIAID resource which will provide qualified assays to accurately quantify latent and expressed HIV reservoirs in research and clinical trials samples from the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver transplantation improves the quality of life and may be lifesaving for patients with end-stage liver disease, but improved outcomes for pre- and post-transplant patients requires better therapies and assessments of clinical outcomes, improved donor availability and increased access to medical care. The long-term objective of the Transplant Surgery Scientist Training Program, consistent with that of the Ruth L. Kirschstein National Research Service Award (NRSA) Institutional Research Training Grant (Parent T32), is to train the next generation of physicians – especially surgeons - and scientists who can leverage scientific advances across many academic disciplines to advance the field of transplantation through team science. By fostering and supporting the training of inter-disciplinary liver transplant-related research, we can improve the health of patients with liver diseases, consistent with the mission of NIDDK.

PROJECT_TITLE: Transplant Surgery Scientist Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hospital to skilled nursing facility (SNF) care transition for older adults remains persistently medicalized, failing to be guided by patients’ own preferences for their recovery, and does not incorporate elements that support preferences related to independence, returning home and function, or factors that allow participation in family or community activities that provide a foundation for personal purpose. The objective of this proposal is to develop and test a SNF preparation tool (SNF-PT) that facilitates communication and implementation of patient preferences into SNF transition plans. Ultimately, the information learned from this proposal will lead to the development of interventions to improve the care transition outcomes and experiences of older adults discharged from the hospital to SNFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to provide a complete and integrated picture of what every single gene in a human being does, thus allowing us to better understand the genetic and cellular workings of human health and disease. We do this by developing the Gene Ontology, a computational resource that collects biological knowledge into a large network structure that connects genes with the roles they play. Researchers, clinicians, and sophisticated computer programs use this network to interpret the massive amounts of biomedical and genomic data being generated in experiments and in studies designed to gain key insights into human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) are part of a devastating neurodegenerative disease spectrum for which there are no biomarkers and only limited treatments, stemming from a poor understanding of its pathogenesis. Here, we propose to integrate novel computational methods with spatially resolved transcriptomic and proteomic analyses of clinically deep-phenotyped post-mortem ALS-FTD brains to determine the specific molecular underpinnings of functional impairment in this disease. By integrating our analysis across different types of data (single cell RNA-seq, spatial transcriptomics, multiplexed imaging and proteomics), our ultimate goal is to unveil how disease-associated pathology is linked to dysfunction in specific cell types in ALS-FTD, which may in turn foster precision medicine-based treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how cells attach to one another and move between one another is important for understanding many common birth defects, and many of the same processes that are tightly regulated in embryos are misregulated in cancer cells as they lose their connections to one another and invade the body. This proposal examines how actin – a protein essential for cell movements – works alongside proteins that regulate cell adhesiveness to build strong connections between cells and to help them avoid injury, and how signals regulate the actin machinery that allows cells to change position in the embryo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Limb girdle muscular dystrophy R1 (LGMDR1) is a common muscular dystrophy due to loss of function of a muscle structural gene called CAPN3, which causes progressive weakness and disability, has no treatments, but is amenable to approaches to gene replacement therapy or therapies with other muscle therapeutics. Validating a robust measure of muscle function and a measure of muscle composition (muscle fat fraction) will help the LGMDR1 community prepare for forthcoming clinical trials and ensure the clinical trials do not reject potentially useful drugs due to poor planning or lack of robust clinical outcome tools. We propose to validate the NSAD and quantitative muscle MRI by performing a 24-month study of 100 individuals with LGMDR1 at 12 sites in an existing LGMD Clinical Research Network to help hasten therapeutic development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CENTER OVERVIEW The mission of the Diabetes Research and Training Center is to promote new discoveries and enhance scientific progress by supporting cutting-edge basic and clinical research on the etiology of diabetes and its complications with the goal of rapidly translating research findings into novel strategies for the diagnosis prevention, treatment and cure of diabetes and related conditions. PHR: Public Heath Relevance/Narrative MYCN is a major driver of childhood cancers including neuroblastoma. However, currently no drugs have been approved against the MYCN oncoprotein. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The leading cause of death in patients who have epilepsy, but do not have good control over their seizures is sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP). It is currently unclear why some seizures result in death when so many others do not. Identifying how two transmitter systems, serotonin and adenosine, interact during seizures may provide insights into why seizure-induced death happens and what can be done to prevent it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as it aims to overcome a major mechanism of antibiotic resistance by Gram-negative bacteria -the exclusion of antibiotics by the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) outer membrane. Our proposed studies seek to understand how a bacteriophage fuses its bacterial phospholipid membrane with the LPS of its Gram-negative host. This research will have the potential to overcome the antibiotic exclusionary properties of the LPS by generating phospholipid derived vesicles capable of targeting specific strains of Gram-negative bacteria for delivery of antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blockade of the inhibitory checkpoint programmed-death 1 (PD-1) can be an effective immunotherapy for cancers, but many patients do not respond, and the mechanisms that drive resistance are not well understood. We will investigate how the intrinsic properties of tumor-specific T cells and the overarching influence of T cell receptor affinity determine T cell responsiveness to PD-1 blockade. This work has the potential to identify new strategies for overcoming therapeutic resistance to PD-1 blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sleep loss, acute or chronic, is experienced by many and is a problem in our modern society. Sleep deprivation leads to excessive daytime sleepiness, emotional difficulties, poor job performance, an increased risk for a number of physical and mental health ailments and overall lower perception of the quality of life. Therefore, as proposed in this application, understanding how the brain responds to sleep loss and localizing the relevant target areas and neuronal subpopulations will inform therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proton-pumping vacuolar ATPase (V-ATPase; V1Vo-ATPase) is a multisubunit enzyme complex that is responsible for vital cellular functions in all eukaryotic organisms and which is linked to several devastating human diseases such as renal tubular acidosis, osteopetrosis, diabetes, neurodegeneration, cancer, and microbial and viral infections. This proposal requests funds for obtaining high-resolution structural information for active holo V-ATPase and its autoinhibited proton channel subcomplex in lipid nanodiscs to study inhibitor binding and for elucidating V-ATPase's unique mode of regulation, for elucidating biochemical properties of specific isoform containing human V-ATPase, and to develop single-domain antibodies directed against yeast and human V-ATPase subunit isoforms as a novel tool for studying V-ATPase's structure and regulatory mechanisms. The long-term goal of the project is to gain a molecular understanding of the enzyme's role in human disease, and to identify novel ways to modulate the activity of disease causing V-ATPase in a subunit isoform and tissue specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemical Synthesis of Complex Natural Products for Translational Science The goals of the continuing MIRA research program (R35GM118173) are to 1) develop novel synthetic methods and expedient approaches to important, unstudied classes of bioactive natural products and to 2) explore fundamental questions of compound mechanism of action in clinical and translational research collaborations. The relevance to public health of the planned studies entails identification of novel, biologically active agents for use as pharmacological therapies for human cancers as well as viral, fungal, and bacterial illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  In this proposal, we will investigate the hypothesis that sex-differences in RV function in PAH are in-part mediated by an inhibitory action of estrogen on microtubule dynamics. We will employ state of the art microscopy and computational analysis to define how estrogen regulates microtubules. Then, in translational studies we will determine modulation of the estrogen-microtubule interaction impacts right ventricular function in pre-clinical PAH using advanced hemodynamics and molecular phenotyping of the RV microtubule cytoskeleton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defective patterning and morphogenesis of human skin appendages—including hair and skin glands—leads to common heritable and acquired disorders that have profound effects on health and well-being of affected indi- viduals. This project introduces a novel and unusually accessible system, skin development in zebraﬁsh, for elucidating the molecular cues and fundamental cell behaviors that drive early stages of skin appendage mor- phogenesis and govern their spatial distribution in the skin. By imaging live dermal cells in intact animals while manipulating functions of biomedically relevant gene products, this work will provide novel insights into the fundamental biology of the skin and open new avenues for elucidating etiologies of hereditary and acquired skin appendage disorders. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal develops a novel method for carrying out multiplexed measurements on large numbers of single cells. The methods developed will allow researchers to leverage new comprehensive “atlases" of tumor cells for a wide range of studies from evaluating the effects of new drug treatments, to identifying tumor cells that predict patient outcomes. Within this advanced development grant, we move from established technical capabilities to two mature fully-working methods for single cell analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance: Thromboembolic events secondary to rupture or erosion of advanced atherosclerotic lesions are the underlying cause of most heart attacks or stroke and are the leading cause of death in the United States and worldwide. Whereas there is general agreement that atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease, multiple large clinical trials of drugs that globally inhibit inflammation have failed to get FDA approval due to them having modest or no beneficial effects on the incidence of a fatal or non-fatal heart attack or stroke, and an increase in lethal infection because patients are immuno-compromised. We postulate that a major reason for the failure of global anti-inflammatory agents is because they inhibit not only detrimental chronic pro-inflammatory responses that exacerbate atherosclerosis, but also evolutionarily conserved beneficial acute inflammatory processes necessary for resistance to infection, resolution of inflammation, and tissue injury-repair processes important for enhancing the stability of atherosclerotic lesions and reducing the chance of rupture or erosion. Studies in this proposal will use novel mouse models and analysis methods to determine if selective inhibition of interleukin- 6 (IL-6) trans signaling, which is believed to be a key mediator of the transition from acute (beneficial) to chronic (detrimental) inflammation, promotes formation of more stable atherosclerotic lesions and a reduced probability of lesion rupture or erosion but without impaired immuno-competence. If so, results would be of major significance in that they would suggest that human clinical trials should focus on testing selective IL-6 trans inhibitors not global inhibitors of IL-6 responses as is currently the case with a recently initiated large Phase 3 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because small-molecule tools that enable the study of autophagy modulation in the fatal, genetic disorder, Niemann-Pick Disease Type C (NPC), will provide a better understanding of the role of autophagy in lipid homeostasis and storage and the therapeutic potential of this strategy. The proposed research is also relevant to the fundamental goals of the NINDS to “understand how the normal brain and nervous system develop and work, and what goes wrong in disease, and to translate basic and clinical discoveries into better ways to prevent and treat neurological disorders”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cells can sense and move along shallow gradients of chemoattractants, a process that is essential for normal physiology in the embryo and adult as well as for the pathology of numerous diseases. These studies focus on the molecular mechanisms of motility and directed migration in normal and cancer cells. A thorough understanding of these processes will make it possible to interfere with them specifically in target cells and eventually lead to new therapeutic strategies for cancer and a host of other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Patients with hemophilia have significant bleeding events, but they also suffer from mental health disorders and demonstrate executive dysfunction more frequently than the general population. Our proposed studies aim to quantify volumetric brain differences, cerebral bleeds, and neuroinflammation to understand their impact on behavior outcomes. Understanding the neurophenotype in hemophilia may help in earlier screening, detection, and treatment of anxiety, depression, and neurocognitive deficits in hemophilia patients which would transform current patient care standards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We investigate the chemical and physical mechanisms by which animal tissues rapidly detect wounds, and initiate inflammation, resolution, repair, and regeneration in response. Failure in wound detection can cause acute and chronic conditions ranging from poorly healing wounds and infections to chronically inflamed skins, fibrosis and cancer. Understanding the underlying mechanisms will pave way for new therapies for these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The molecular and metabolic processes that drive cancer cells to rapidly divide, invade, and metastasize dictate patient outcomes, treatment options, and quality of life. This study will address how loss of the Fanconi Anemia (FA) DNA repair pathway promotes the rapid development of aggressive head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) by re-wiring metabolism. In doing so, this project will establish a novel link between aberrant DNA damage repair and stimulation of 1-carbon (1C) metabolism, and define the therapeutic potential of targeting 1C metabolism to prevent progression of FA-deficient HNSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco smoking is a leading cause of preventable death in the US, though most smokers who would like to quit are unable to do so with current available therapeutics. The molecular mechanisms underlying the failed successes of smokers attempting to quit remain a critical gap in our knowledge. This proposal aims to elucidate the roles of a novel signaling pathway (NRG3-ErbB4) during nicotine use and withdrawal in hopes of developing better therapeutics for nicotine dependence by specifically targeting affective disruption, thereby improving smoking cessation and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Pancreatitis is an inflammatory disorder of the pancreas that is associated with high morbidity and mortality. No effective disease modifying therapy is available. One novel approach is to harness mitochondrial mechanisms to treat both acute and chronic pancreatitis. We have identified important roles for ubiquitin mediated regulation of mitochondrial health as a protective mechanism against pancreatitis. In this project we propose to fully leverage prior discoveries and to focus on developing novel disease modifying therapy for treating pancreatitis by modulating ubiquitin pathway and improving mitochondrial health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Due to small sample sizes and the persistent aggregation of Asian American and Pacific Islander data, there is a significant dearth of research on substance use and suicidal ideation in Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander adults. The proposed project will: (1) provide essential training in conducting ethical research and collaborating with this highly minoritized community and (2) use a sequential mixed-methods methodology paired with community-based participatory research to explore the relationships between substance use, suicidal ideation, and historical trauma among Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islanders. Results will fill significant gaps in the extant literature related to health disparities within this understudied community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will provide new details about the earliest pathophysiologically-driven changes in cholinergic innervation and signaling in prefrontal cortex of males and females and the impact of such early changes in cognitive decline associated with a Parkinson’s-linked mutation in LRRK2. These studies will reveal potentially new targets of early disease pathophysiology, define sex-specific differences in anatomical and behavioral trajectories, and characterize changes with age, potentially influencing diagnostics and treatments for a variety of neurodegenerative disorders in which early mild cognitive impairment is manifest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed project seeks to address the limitations of current therapies for glaucoma, which suffer from poor bioavailability, limited specificity, and delivery barriers. Leveraging the unique properties of reconstituted high-density lipoprotein (rHDL) nanoparticles and a custom-made cholera toxin B subunit (CTB) – fatty acid conjugate, we aim to develop rHDL-ApoAI-CTB nanoparticles (rHAC NPs) with enhanced specificity for retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) by binding to GM1 gangliosides and the scavenger receptor class B1 (SR-B1) as dual targets. Compared to rHDL NPs, rHAC NPs have improved drug delivery capabilities and effectively penetrate biological barriers, leading to improved treatment outcomes for this debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Program Narrative The inability to perturb, and then study the effects of specific immune pathways in humans has been a major limitation to alleviating the morbidity and mortality associated with infectious disease. In this Cooperative Center for Human Immunology, we “capture the human experiment” through focused profiling of the human immune system following key immune perturbations where the timing and nature of the perturbation can be carefully controlled or documented. Specifically, we will investigate persistent immune defects following acute viral infection with SARS-CoV-2 that contribute to Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19, long lasting defects developed during chronic HCV infection that persist even beyond cure, and alterations in vaccine responses in the context of precision PD-1-targeted immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Furthering our understanding of the human immune system is dependent on availability of adequate research specimens from well-defined clinical cohorts of patients. Our group of researchers have built a robust infrastructure for recruiting key groups of patients who are undergoing real-world perturbations such as PASC, chronic viral infection, and immune therapies and have an expansive resource of immune cells in our biobanks. From these resources, a wide variety of experiments can be performed that will reveal the intricacies of our immune response against viruses and augment our ability to modulate our immune system or optimize vaccines.

PHR: Project Narrative Non-genetic influences, like viral infections and environmental factors, shape the human immune system. It is not, however, clear how this heterogeneity influences responses future events, like vaccination or immunotherapy. Core C will perform high dimensional immune profiling with integrated analysis on all clinical samples to identify immunotypes associated with disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC) affects ~20M Americans with long-term, often crippling, symptoms. Although PASC is now well-described clinically, the immune mechanisms are poorly-understood. Here, we will test the hypothesis that PASC is caused by viral persistence driving virus-specific immunological abnormalities in innate and adaptive immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic viral infections are associated with impaired host immunity and long-term health outcomes, even affecting immune responses against other pathogens or vaccines. However, the precise mechanisms driving immune dysregulation in these settings are poorly understood. In this Project, we will use chronic infection with hepatitis C virus as a paradigmatic persistent infection in humans to better dissect impact on host immunity and identify molecular targets for intervention to restore functional immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Here, we focus on testing how the PD-1 inhibitory receptor pathway influences vaccine-induced immunity. By capitalizing on patients treated with PD-1 inhibitors while getting standard of care vaccines, these studies will address a major gap in knowledge in human immunology about how PD-1 regulates vaccine-induced humoral and cellular immunity. This work will have implications for improving vaccines and for the fundamental regulation of immunological memory in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Neutrophils are abundant yet poorly understood immune cells that drive lung diseases with enormous public health relevance. We hypothesize that cellular and humoral signals originating from the circulation and from specific niches within the injured lung microenvironment drive heterogeneous neutrophil phenotypes and functions that determine the balance between inflammation, injury, and repair in patients with neutrophilic lung and airways diseases. The Neu-Lung Consortium brings together experts in fundamental immunology, respiratory disease, clinical medicine, and computational biology who will synergize to test mechanistic hypotheses of neutrophilic disease pathogenesis using cutting-edge technologies applied to human lung, airway, and blood samples obtained from well-phenotyped patients with pneumonia, primary lung allograft dysfunction, and asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dopamine is critical for prioritizing motivationally significant events in long-term memory so that past experiences can guide future choices. This project will investigate how dopamine impacts hippocampal- dependent reward memory in healthy older adults. If successful, this project will contribute to our understanding of basic mechanisms by which declines in dopamine function drive memory changes in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Precise axonal-dendritic targeting of neuronal growth factors is critical for neuronal function, but how they are targeted is largely unknown. We have found that an ER stress sensor protein, PERK, and a kinase associated with neural plasticity and memory, CaMKII, cooperate to control localization of two neuroprotective growth factors. This project will test the relationship between PERK and CaMKII in this novel pathway, which will not only advance our understanding of protein localization in neurons, but also may explain how PERK is genetically linked to neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Washington University Cooperative Center on Human Immunology (WashU-CCHI) will define the cellular and molecular mechanisms governing generation of broad and durable T cell, memory B cell and bone marrow plasma cell responses to rapidly evolving respiratory viral pathogens. It will also determine the functional caliber of systemic and mucosal immune responses to influenza and SARS-CoV-2 vaccination and infection in humans. The assembled multi-disciplinary team of investigators has extensive expertise in immunology, virology, pathogenesis, universal vaccine development, proteomics, metabolic labeling, and structural biology as well as a well-established track record of successful collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - PROJECT 1 Vaccination-induced adaptive immunity protects against severe disease from SARS-CoV-2 and influenza, but these viruses continue to infect humans because of the limited duration of vaccine-induced immunity, which is exacerbated by viral antigenic drift. In Project 1, we address key gaps in our understanding of the cellular, molecular, and genetic mechanisms governing the generation and maintenance of the immune cells that confer durable immunity and the diversity of viral strains against which they protect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Despite widespread availability of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 and influenza, these viruses continue to infect humans because of antigenic drift that evades pre-existing immunity. In Project 2, we address key gaps in our understanding of human antiviral immunity as it relates to durability, immunodominance, function, and breadth of vaccine-induced, infection-induced, and hybrid vaccination/infection-induced mucosal and systemic immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mesenchymal epithelial transition factor (c-MET/MET), a receptor tyrosine kinase, is an oncogenic driver in numerous tumor types, notably non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and melanomas. On-target mutations drive resistance against small-molecule MET inhibitors. I aim to comprehensively profile the selectivity of clinically approved MET inhibitors against MET mutants, and determine combinations of inhibitors that maximize on-target activity and reduce off-target effects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  Children from adverse developmental environments exhibit varied reading achievement. The proposed research examines how reading development is buffered or protected from atypical development across the population and within individuals in the context of a canalization conceptual framework. The proposed research also advances a data sharing resource that would include the distribution of data and cutting-edge methods established in this project.
