IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Communication between the cells of the peripheral nervous system and the immune system can determine the extent to which nerves recover after injury. The proposed project will identify key molecular mechanisms involved in the macrophage response to peripheral nerve injury and how these mechanisms contribute to nerve fiber repair. The results of this project will expand the knowledge base of the emerging field of neuroimmunology and provide potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of peripheral nerve injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ST. JUDE CHILDREN'S RESEARCH HOSPITAL GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES, LLC
PHR: Project Narrative Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma, and the survival rate has not increased for the past three decades. Our lab has shown that proteins called transcription factors can control the emergence and cell type of rhabdomyosarcoma through elegant mouse models. My project is specifically focused on understanding how the transcription factor SOX8 functions during normal muscle development and how rhabdomyosarcoma cells utilize SOX8 for tumor initiation and fate to potentially solidify a new therapeutic target for rhabdomyosarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal seeks to advance the state of the art in automated image guidance methods with optical coherence tomography (OCT) to improve diagnosis and treatment of diabetic retinopathy. We will develop novel robotically-aligned and handheld OCT devices to automatically measure retinal biomarkers currently not identified with standard of care OCT systems and to provide real-time 3D feedback to clinicians performing a novel, less invasive injection procedure. We believe our technologies will allow for increased access to new diagnostics and therapeutics for patients with diabetic retinopathy.

PHR: Project Narrative This project interrogates clonal repertoire in delayed-type drug hypersensitivity reactions, which are a major yet understudied public health problem. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Luciferases and luciferins are essential reagents for bioluminescence assays and imaging, which have broad applications in fundamental and preclinical biological and biomedical studies. In addition, this project will derive bioluminescence imaging tools for calcium, a ubiquitous second messenger. The new tools and reagents from this study can be used to develop new drugs, monitor bioactivities, understand new biology, and track disease progression in animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Label-free optical microscopy, combined with artificial intelligence (AI), has emerged as a promising method for the rapid imaging of fresh, unprocessed surgical specimens, bedside brain tumor diagnosis, margin delineation, and molecular genetic prediction. Existing AI methodologies are limited because they rely on weak, slide- or patient-level annotations for model training, and are therefore unable to capture the cellular complexity and spatial heterogeneity found in diffuse gliomas. The objective of this research is to develop an innovative AI-based system to learn single-cell optical image features and identify patient-level clusters, without weak supervision, in order to advance the role of AI in diffuse glioma research and enable better, and more personalized care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  More than 150 million women worldwide use oral contraceptives (OCs), and for about 10% of users, OCs trigger severe mood-related adverse consequences including depression. In this project, we will use a mouse model recently validated in our laboratory to understand how OCs contribute to depression vulnerability via modulation of the HPA axis. This research will allow for a personalized approach for prescribing OCs to limit adverse effects and enhance benefits.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Males suffering from non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA) have limited options to have biological children. In the future, AAV gene therapy could offer new promise and a therapeutic approach to cure infertility in NOA patients. I will demonstrate that AAV gene therapy can be implemented to safely and ethically treat NOA caused by Sertoli cell dysfunction without the risk of germline transmission and that this therapy has potential applications to humans. My project will help develop a bench to bedside approach to show a route forward for testicular somatic cell gene therapy to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The major clinical obstacle in EGFR-targeted therapy of lung cancer is the development of acquired resistance that limits its long-term efficacy. Thus, understanding molecular mechanisms underlying the acquired resistance and accordingly developing mechanism-driven effective strategies to overcome acquired resistance are highly desirable and urgently needed in the clinic. This proposal will primarily focus on the critical impact of PGC1β/PPARγ modulation on therapeutic efficacy of EGFR-targeted cancer therapy with particular emphasis on identifying effective strategies for overcoming acquired resistance through targeting PGC1β/PPARγ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ebola virus (EBOV), part of the Filoviridae family, causes periodic outbreaks of severe hemorrhagic fever and Ebola virus disease, with case fatality rates as high as 90%. There is increasing evidence that viruses can antagonize the immune response by interfering with host ubiquitin-dependent pathways, or by hijacking the host ubiquitination machinery to promote viral pathogenesis. In this proposal, I will show how EBOV VP35’s interaction with the host ubiquitin machinery affects its function and change host-viral dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) associated with the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is currently, and will continue to be, a major threat to public health. Given the rapid emergence of novel variants and the long-term complications associated with the recovery from COVID-19, the development of novel drug therapies for the treatment of COVID-19 is imperative. Virus replication is reliant on the expression of the p38β kinase and the research proposed here will characterize both the host- and virus-mediated mechanisms responsible in order to enhance the understanding of SARS-CoV-2 biology while identifying putative novel targets with therapeutic potential for COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Almost half of the identified genes underlying hereditary podocytopathies, which are clinically characterized by steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, encode for proteins involved in actin cytoskeletal functions. Mutations in α-actinin-4, a mechanically regulated actin crosslinker expressed in podocytes, cause focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). This proposal aims to elucidate structural mechanisms of deficient actin mechanosensing by FSGS-causing α-actinin-4 variants via cryo-EM, and completing this project will advance mechanistic insights into how impairments in actin cytoskeletal functions drive podocytopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory skin disease that affects 15-30% of children worldwide and predisposes to significant allergic comorbidities, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, and food allergy. A hallmark feature of AD is skin dysbiosis and increased prevalence of Staphylococcus aureus (SA); it is thus crucial to identify mechanisms of persistent microbial colonization in AD that may be targeted clinically for AD prevention and treatment. This proposal focuses on elucidating microbial patterns on AD skin and delineating the mechanisms of SA adhesion, invasion, and persistence over time in early life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and its comorbidities pose an ever-increasing challenge to public health despite existing therapies, highlighting the need for new therapeutic strategies. Increasing the amount of energy-burning brown adipose tissue in humans has the potential to reverse the caloric imbalance at the root of obesity, but there are major gaps in the current understanding of how brown adipose tissue develops. The studies performed as part of this fellowship will elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the development of brown adipose tissue, thus identifying new targets for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Fragile X syndrome (FXS), the most common form of heritable intellectual disability, is caused by the expansion of a CGG short tandem repeat (STR) at the FMR1 gene on chromosome X where local DNA methylation silences FMR1 expression. At the FMR1 locus and on multiple autosomes, we have recently found Megabase-scale H3K9me3 domains that form inter-chromosomal contacts in FXS. Using CRISPR/Cas9 engineering of the CGG STR, genomic assays and multimodal single nuclei-imaging, I will elucidate how expansion of the CGG STR at FMR1 spatially coordinates heterochromatinization and 3D genome miswiring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in TMEM106B have been reported to alter risk of frontotemporal dementia, and TMEM106B protein aggregates were recently discovered in postmortem brains of individuals with FTD. This proposal aims to improve our understanding of how TMEM106B SNPs alter protein function, and to define disease-specific interactions of TMEM106B fibrils. Together, these data will inform the development of new therapeutic strategies and/or protein targets to combat FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) is a metabolic disease that has recently been characterized as a disease of the whole pancreas, not just of insulin-producing β-cells. The goal of this proposal is to measure changes in energy metabolism in the exocrine pancreas within the context of T1D. The information gained from this work will provide unique insight into T1D pathophysiology and determine metabolic mechanisms underlying exocrine pancreas anomalies in T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is a deadly parasitic disease that affects nearly half the world’s population. Unfortunately, drug resistance has been identified for all antimalarials in clinical use, which highlights an urgent need to design drugs that overcome resistance. This work aims to investigate a common mechanism of resistance in the malaria parasite in order to inform the development of antimalarials that circumvent drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The creation and maintenance of a vascular access to secure hemodialysis represents a challenge even to the most experienced nephrologist. The narrowing of blood vessels (stenosis) that give access to patient circulation remains a significant complication. It is estimated that every year, over $2 billion is expended in the maintenance of vascular access and its complication in the US alone. This study aims at identifying a new therapeutic to prevent the failure of the most common vascular access, the arteriovenous fistula. Outcomes from these studies may represent a breakthrough that will provide new therapeutic targets and strategies to improve vascular access dysfunction, reduce medical complications, and, ultimately, save lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myc is a well-known oncogene that contributes to the evolution of many cancer subtypes, and its expression is associated with increased metastasis, resistance to therapy, and poor prognosis and survival outcomes. While it is known that high Myc levels markedly increase protein synthesis rates in cancer cells and activate associated cellular stress-response signaling, a comprehensive understanding of how Myc-driven high protein synthesis loads contributes to cellular stress in cancer remains underexplored. This proposal aims to provide critical insight into the effects of Myc overexpression on translational activity in cancer and subsequent stress signaling to help elucidate potential novel avenues for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The orexin system is increasingly being recognized for its key role in motivation to engage in maladaptive behaviors, including alcohol self-administration, in preclinical models. No clinical neuroscience research has advanced these preclinical findings, limiting our ability to determine whether the orexin system also contributes to alcohol use in humans. The proposed research will fill that gap by determining how administration of an orexin antagonist, suvorexant, impacts motivation for alcohol and other abuse-related effects of alcohol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  People who are born preterm have a higher risk of developing pulmonary hypertension (PH) and heart failure as adults than people who are born full term. Molecular and cellular mechanisms that trigger and promote this disease are poorly understood. Since preterm infants are often exposed to supplemental oxygen (hyperoxia), this project seeks to understand how hyperoxia at birth promotes PH in adults and test potential therapeutic interventions that could advance thinking in how to improve the health of people born preterm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AIRE is required for maintaining tolerance in the thymus and periphery to prevent autoimmune diseases but can also play a detrimental role by dampening immune responses against cancer. While deletion of thymic AIRE expression has been shown to improve response to immunotherapy in certain cancers by allowing the development of autoreactive T cells, whether extrathymic AIRE expression is involved in regulating anti-tumor immune responses remains unknown. This proposal investigates the role of peripheral AIRE expression and tumor associated Aire-expressing cells in tumor progression and immunity with the ultimate goal of improving immunotherapy approaches for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The differing rates of progression from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) to Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) in diverse populations have been previously attributed to factors related to clinical health outcomes, but never fully disentangled due to the diversity of diagnostic criteria of MCI. This research proposal aims to identify patients with MCI by applying computational and machine learning approaches to structured and unstructured clinical data sources, as well as quantify how clinical and neighborhood factors may affect the time to progression from MCI to AD/ADRD incidence. Ultimately, this project seeks to quantify how effects of place-based disadvantage on progression from MCI to AD/ADRD incidence may be mediated and/or exacerbated by cardiovascular disease risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Prostatitis and prostate cancer are highly prevalent among older men and are marked by immune infiltration of the prostate. As CD8+ T cells play key roles in controlling inflammation and tumor growth, understanding the mechanisms by which prostate-resident memory CD8+ T cells are formed and maintained in response to infection is critical to understanding prostate biology. The goal of this project is to define the mechanisms that control the establishment of tissue-resident T cells in the prostate, which will provide translational information pertaining to prostate inflammation, prostate tumorigenesis, and immunotherapy for prostate tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The transcriptional changes through which Merkel cell polyomavirus T-antigens (T-Ags) incite tumorigenesis and neuroendocrine reprogramming in Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) are poorly elucidated but critical to understanding the biology, origin, and vulnerabilities of these tumors. I propose to leverage in vivo murine models of T-Ag mediated reprogramming to elucidate the mechanisms of how T-Ags drive reprogramming to the neuroendocrine lineage and interrogate the requirement for tumor suppressor dysfunction to promote the acquisition of neuroendocrine phenotypes associated with MCC. These studies will elucidate a currently obscure area of T-Ag and MCC biology and establish a foundation for further exploration of T-Ag mediated reprogramming mechanisms and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: As obligate intracellular pathogens, viruses must hijack cellular machinery to mediate infectious processes. This proposal combines molecular biological, biochemical, biophysical, and bioinformatic approaches to determine how human adenovirus (AdV) manipulates arginine methylation, a post-translational modification deposited by cellular protein arginine methyltransferases, to regulate host RNA-binding proteins and thus promote viral infection. Findings generated from this study will have significant implications for understanding the roles of arginine methylation during viral infections as well as how AdV hijacks host splicing machinery, therefore informing the use of AdV vectors as vaccine, gene therapy, and oncogenic therapy platforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Financial toxicity is the objective financial burden or subjective financial strain resulting from treatment for illness. It is prevalent in many medical conditions, both acute and chronic, and in some conditions, like cancer, it is associated with worse outcomes, but its prevalence and risks in pneumonia are currently unknown. This project will use the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey to assess the prevalence of financial toxicity in survivors of pneumonia, and test the hypotheses that financial toxicity in these patients leads to (1) greater need for future care, and (2) increased disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  New strategies are needed to chemically modify proteins through selective bioconjugation of specific amino acids, as well as unselectively through rapidly tagging amino acids for proximity labeling, as important information about protein structure and function, the design of new pharmaceutical products and targeted therapeutics, and disease microenvironments can be obtained. The proposed research describes the photocatalytic generation of reactive probes (2H-azirines, carbenes, and a-lactones) that can either label aspartic acid (Asp) and glutamic (Glu) selectively or undergo reaction with a variety of side chains for mapping cell surface microenvironments. This tool will ultimately improve public health by allowing modification of native proteins with greater precision and efficiency using low energy, tissue-penetrating red light.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phosphoglucomutase I Deficiency, an inborn error of metabolism, was formerly classified as Glycogen Storage Disorder Type 14, although recent research demonstrated that it is also a Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation (CDG) with mixed glycosylation defects. Many aspects of the pathophysiology of the complex disease phenotypes, which include the therapy-resistant lethal dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) remains unclear, despite oral galactose supplementation improves some other clinical symptoms. The long-term goals of this project are to employ cardiac-specific conditional Pgm2- knockout mouse model to (a) define the pathogenic mechanisms of the cardiac phenotypes; and (b) develop effective, safe and evidence-based therapies to address the unmet medical needs of the patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and diabetes are a major epidemic in the United States and treated with pharmacotherapies targeting the glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor (GLP-1Rs). These drugs suppress appetite through their actions in the brain; however, a complete understanding of their mechanism of action in the brain is lacking. In this proposal, we will characterize the role of amygdala GLP-1Rs in regulating neuronal activity and as an anorexigenic target of GLP-1R agonists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed project will identify the relationship of historical and contemporary residential segregation on cognitive aging and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia in older adults. The project will provide insights on the role of education and poverty rates on the relationships between residential segregation and late-life cognitive decline and risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia. Lastly, we will explore this relationship using neuroimaging biomarkers of hippocampal and whitter matter hyperintensities volume.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative If we want to understand how cells of the immune system, like B cells and T cells, can both protect from infections and cause damage in settings like organ transplant or autoimmunity, it is important to be able to follow the protective and damaging cells over time to see where they go, what they do and how long they live. The goal of this Program is to analyze the different types of B and T cells in samples of blood and biopsies from transplanted tissues that are collected multiple times over months to years from the same transplant patients. In the future, this information could be used to develop better treatments to eliminate the immune cells that cause damage in the organ without affecting the cells that protect us from infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While prior research has documented that transgender and/or nonbinary (TNB) college students experience significant disparities in mental health outcomes, little attention has been paid to the ways in which campus policy environments have shaped these disparities, despite substantial campus-level variation in policies that may uniquely affect TNB students (e.g. counseling staff training and insurance coverage for gender affirming healthcare). Additionally, TNB students across intersections of racial/ethnic identities and socioeconomic status may be differentially impacted by these policy environments due to unique structural vulnerabilities, although no studies have explored this. The objectives of this project are thus to use unprecedented, national data from over 300 institutions to fill this gap and discern the role of campus policy environment in TNB mental health disparities across intersecting social positions, with the goal of informing campus-level interventions for an increasing and diverse population of TNB college students.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: The majority of the world's children live in low- and middle-income countries and experience substantial childhood adversity that potentially have lasting negative implications for health, health behaviors and wellbeing of young adults and their children. Yet there are few longitudinal studies from low-income contexts that capture how childhood adversity influences sexual, reproductive and mental health in early adulthood, nor how it is transmitted across generations to their children. By expanding an existing cohort study in Malawi, a low-income country, we will illuminate causal pathways from adversity to health, identify mechanisms, and highlight protective factors – the foundational evidence needed for effective programming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Peroxisomes are metabolically plastic organelles housing critical reactions, and peroxisome dysfunction can lead to severe developmental defects in multicellular eukaryotes, including mammals and plants. Peroxisomes contain abundant intralumenal vesicles that have been implicated in lipid metabolism, enzyme compartmentalization, and protein import. The goals of this project are to elucidate how a peroxisomal membrane-shaping protein, PEX11, influences peroxisome membrane architecture to impact global peroxisome function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Trips account for over 50% of falls each year, leading to an enormous physical, psychosocial, and financial burden on the population. Older adults with mild cognitive impairment experience twice as many falls as cognitively intact older adults; however, it has rarely been examined how mild cognitive impairment affects the ability to prevent falling and recover balance when unexpected perturbations are experienced. In this study, we will examine differences in reactive balance between older adults with and without mild cognitive impairment when exposed to trip perturbations while walking on a treadmill to investigate the mechanisms underlying increased fall risk in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurotransmission and proper circuit function are crucial for processing environmental stimuli. Critical to these processes are calcium fluctuations within single neurons, however intracellular contributions to these fluctuations have remained largely unexplored. This proposal aims to uncover the contribution of endoplasmic reticulum calcium handling to neurotransmission in a well-characterized Drosophila neural circuit, informing our understanding of neurotransmission and circuit function at the level of the human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research will provide insights into the molecular responses of kidney cells to saturated lipid induced injury, specifically, the mechanism by which deletion of Fas-associated factor 2 (FAF2) is protective against lipid induced cellular toxicity, known as lipotoxicity. Lipotoxicity can lead to cell injury and death and has been implicated in the pathogenesis of chronic kidney disease. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms of lipotoxicity in the kidney may contribute to the development of therapeutic strategies for diseases lacking treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Nuclear receptors evolved to respond to small molecules, translating these signals into changes in gene expression. Our data, that RORα transcriptionally regulates TH17 cell pathogenicity and ligand regulation affects chronic inflammation, suggests that RORα may be a key transcriptional regulator of this cell type. The proposed studies will address fundamental questions regarding the transcriptional role of RORα, insights which will be particularly valuable understanding TH17-mediated chronic inflammation and whether targeting this nuclear receptor may be therapeutically relevant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Jails are critical healthcare access points for people with opioid use disorder (OUD) who are incarcerated, yet access to medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) in jails remains limited. This mixed-methods study will examine the implementation of MOUD in Massachusetts jails through qualitative interviews with jail staff and people who received MOUD while incarcerated, survey analysis of jail staff to examine the impacts of organizational factors on staff perceptions of MOUD, and modeling of the effects of MOUD treatment during incarceration on post-release engagement with MOUD treatment using the Massachusetts Public Health Data (PHD) Warehouse database. This study will elucidate strategies to improve implementation of MOUD in jail settings and will seek to improve accessibility of evidence-based OUD treatment for people who are incarcerated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Investigating host-driven substitutions and potential adaption to novel transmission cycles is essential in understanding the current spread and reemergence of the tickborne flavivirus, Powassan virus (POWV). Recent isolations of POWV from novel tick species in New York State augment concerns over viral spillover and spread into new transmission cycles. Investigating the adaptive potential of emergent POWV isolates in distinct tick hosts and emergent host-specific substitutions is vital in understanding POWV ecology and predicting potential viral diversification.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative P. falciparum malaria is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Antibody responses against the highly conserved, uncharacterized P. falciparum protein PF3D7_1136200 are correlated with protection from symptomatic disease. To further explore PF3D7_1136200 as a vaccine candidate, this project will study the role of PF3D7_1136200 in parasite biology and determine which protein domains are the main target of protective immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks funding for a non-profit seminar and conference that will bring together a diverse group of scientists, trainees, clinicians, and industry leaders to present and discuss their unpublished research on the role of Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF) signaling in human health and disease. FGF signaling plays fundamental roles in tissue development and homeostasis, and its dysregulation results in a wide-range of human diseases that include congenital disorders of craniofacial complex and skeleton, metabolic diseases, and cancer. By highlighting innovative research and promoting multidisciplinary interactions in the field of FGF signaling, this conference will advance our knowledge of FGF-related disease and accelerate development of targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Paramyxoviridae family includes several pathogenic viruses that pose major threats to human health, including human parainfluenza virus 3 (HPIV3) which causes illness or death in millions of infants and young children. The goal of the proposed research and graduate training vehicle is to elucidate host proteases required for HPIV3 infectivity, the impact of protease dependence on viral tropism, and how delaying proteolytic activation may enable virions to evade host defenses. The findings will broaden our understanding of viral fusion machinery and offer an ideal training opportunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation-induced anorexia is a common complication of inflammatory bowel disease, resulting in malnutrition, increased morbidity, and decreased quality of life. The goal of this proposal is to determine how peripheral inflammatory signals communicate with central food intake circuitry to ultimately drive anorexia. Not only will this contribute to the limited mechanistic understanding of inflammation-induced anorexia, but also may facilitate the development of treatment options that address the underlying immuno-metabolic causes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative We will develop the next-generation, ultrasensitive stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) microscopy by integrating innovations from imaging instrumentation, probe chemistry and data science. This research will bring SRS microscopy to the ultimate sensitivity (comparable to that of fluorescence microscopy), and fully open the application in live cell biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mathematical models that help predict cases and hospitalizations of COVID-19 are essential for policy makers and the public to plan public health interventions and prepare for outbreaks and typically rely on data about cases. As data on cases has become less reliable and sparser, wastewater surveillance has emerged as a new source of data for tracking infections; however, it is not clear yet how wastewater surveillance can be used to improve modeling of transmission. This project will take advantage of a unique collaboration with the New York State Wastewater Surveillance Network to find out how wastewater surveillance data may be used to improve SARS-CoV-2 forecasting and protect the public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Detecting interactions between cellular perturbations requires an appropriate model for non-interaction (i.e., a null interaction model). A key challenge is the design of null interaction models for biological assays with high- dimensional phenotypes, in which individual features exhibit unknown, non-linear behavior. I propose to establish an analytical approach to construct null interaction models for high-dimensional phenotypes and perform drug target identification using high-dimensional, chemical-genetic interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative COPA syndrome, an autosomal dominant monogenic disease causing autoinflammation and interstitial lung disease (ILD), results from defects in Golgi to Endoplasmic Reticulum retrieval of stimulator of interferon genes (STING) by coatomer subunit α (COPA). This proposal characterizing which STING functions are preserved or defective in a common STING allele that is associated with non-penetrance of pathogenic COPA mutations. STING hyperactivation has been broadly implicated in ILD, thus these studies hold potential to unlock novel therapeutic approaches for this group of morbid diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) occurring in adolescents and young adults aged less than 40 years is associated with worse health outcomes. Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1 RAs) are a relatively new T2D treatment, but how well they work in adolescents and young adults outside of clinical trials is unknown. The purpose of this study is to use a large-scale database to test how GLP-1 RAs are prescribed and how well they work in adolescents and young adults in the real world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is frequently driven by increased activity of the hypoxia- inducible transcription factor HIF2. We demonstrated that the circadian clock components BMAL1, CRY1, and CRY2 regulate the activity of HIF2. This project investigates contributions of circadian clock components to HIF2 activity and cell and tumor growth in ccRCC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization Supreme Court decision, which overturned a half century of legal precedent that protected the right to induced abortion, is a landmark policy change with implications for fertility, population health, and related disparities in the US. The proposed research will use a comparative interrupted time series design to estimate the impact of the Dobbs decision on fertility and maternal and infant health outcomes over time and by subgroups in states that recently banned or restricted abortion services. This work will address major gaps in the literature regarding the causal impact of abortion restrictions on population health, in particular post-Dobbs abortion restrictions, for which we currently have limited knowledge, and produce results that can inform time-sensitive reproductive health policy decision making in states in the coming years.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (3 sentences) Although men involved in the criminal justice system have been noted as a “high-priority target population” among sexual and reproductive health experts for at least two decades, we know almost nothing about formerly incarcerated young men’s sexual and reproductive health attitudes and behaviors, as well as their experiences with, and barriers and facilitators to, accessing sexual and reproductive health education and care. Drawing from population-based survey data and data collected from in-depth interviews with recently incarcerated young men (ages 15-29) and national and regional justice, medical, and public health experts, this study will inform the development of interventions to support the sexual and reproductive health goals, education, and care of formerly incarcerated young men, and will provide critical preliminary data to develop a national agenda for further research centering this neglected and understudied group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The glymphatic system is a recently characterized pathway of cerebrospinal and interstitial fluid circulation, facilitating solute transport and thought to be important for the removal of toxic amyloid-beta and tau aggregations, two neuropathological hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The proposed work will investigate how changes in mRNA expression of key glymphatic genes and common genetic variation in genes of this pathway contribute to glymphatic dysfunction in AD, potentially rendering certain individuals more susceptible to AD neuropathology and subsequent cognitive decline. This work will characterize key genes in the glymphatic pathway that could be targeted for future mechanistic studies, providing critical information for the development of disease-modifying therapeutics to prevent the accumulation of toxic proteins.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children’s early language learning abilities are critical to their long-term outcomes with regard to acquiring language, forming social connections, and succeeding in school. This project’s goal is to investigate how very young children manage the massive variability inherent in human speech, an unsolved problem in theories of language learning. This research will have substantial implications for our understanding of typical language development and for translational work developing early language assessments and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The incidence of liver cancer continues to rise, and the poor survival rates of advanced disease highlight a dire need for new understanding and therapies. This fellowship application explores how the enzyme histone deacetylase eleven (HDAC11) drives liver cancer and tests HDAC11 inhibition as a possible treatment avenue. Completion of this research proposal and training plan fills major knowledge gaps, and it offers a platform to prepare a promising candidate for a career as a cancer investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently an unmet demand for therapies that preserve and/or rescue pancreatic β-cell function in the progression of type 2 diabetes (T2D). Our mouse model uses continuous stress-independent activation of ATF6α in β-cells to drive diabetes, and may be useful for uncovering novel molecular mechanisms regulated by ATF6α that explain one aspect of the damaging effect of chronic stress that diminishes β-cell function in T2D. We believe our proposed experiments, which use transmission electron microscopy, RNA- sequencing, and the gold-standard islet perifusion assay to analyze insulin secretion, will contribute valuable knowledge for developing therapies to preserve and/or rescue β-cell function in T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Signaling between cells is essential for the proper development and function of neural circuits and occurs often over long distances. This project will test the hypothesis that extracellular vesicles are a novel long-distance mechanism of intercellular neurotrophin signaling which promotes recipient neuron survival. Ultimately, this work will increase our understanding of the mechanisms required for the proper target-directed circuit refinement in the developing nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Applicant: Andrea Bucknam Project Narrative Medicinal chemistry programs continue to be fueled by rapid access to classes of natural products with demonstrated pharmaceutically-relevant biological activity, and molecularly flexible total synthesis programs expand access to enantiomerically enriched natural products and natural product-like compounds to broaden the investigation of their potential as therapeutics. There are greater than 100 FDA-approved drugs which are tetracyclic triterpenoid natural products, and yet some classes of tetracyclic triterpenoids–including cardenolides–have yet to be investigated deeply as drug candidates despite their structural relatedness to in-use pharmaceutical agents. The research proposed herein is an asymmetric de novo synthesis of sarmentogenin, a cardenolide natural product utilizing a novel oxidative dearomatization/Wagner-Meerwein rearrangement to establish a key quaternary center and oxidation pattern characteristic of the cardenolide carbon framework in a stereospecific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trifluoromethyl groups are common in small-molecule therapeutics, due to the dramatic improvement in pharmacokinetic properties caused by the presence of C–F bonds. A significant limitation of established methods for the incorporation of trifluoromethyl groups into organic molecules is the high cost of many commonly employed trifluoromethylation reagents, which hinders the discovery and synthesis of new trifluoromethylated pharmaceuticals. This proposal describes the trifluoromethylation of organic compounds using a silver(II) catalyst together with inexpensive, abundant trifluoroacetate as the trifluoromethylation reagent.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Experience-induced patterns of brain development in bilingual children have either not been taken into account or been explicitly excluded from foundational longitudinal neuroimaging studies characterizing developmental trajectories of brain language and reading networks. This creates critical barriers to understanding the development of reading networks in emergent typical and struggling bilingual readers. The overarching goals of this proposal are to disentangle how bilingualism and reading development shape brain structure during childhood and to reveal compensatory neural mechanisms associated with better outcomes in struggling bilingual readers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the US, 1 in 14 pregnant people smoke cigarettes during pregnancy; prenatal nicotine exposure leads to an increased risk of developing several neurobehavioral disorders (e.g., ADHD and autism spectrum disorders). Pressingly, the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which the nicotinic cholinergic system modulates circuit and synapse maturation, and how these are dysregulated by nicotine exposure during early brain development, remain poorly understood. Characterizing the role of the nicotinic cholinergic signaling in circuit and synapse maturation will expand our knowledge of brain development and elucidate therapeutic targets to mitigate the adverse outcomes of prenatal nicotine exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Tourette Syndrome (TS) is a highly prevalent neurological disorder in which the underlying neuropathology still remains poorly understood and under investigated. This grant proposal will utilize novel preclinical mouse models expressing orthologous human mutations in high-confidence TS genes to investigate the underlying circuit mechanisms of TS. These experiments will begin to reveal the uninvestigated neuronal substrates of habit formation and dopamine dysregulation hypothesized in TS, as well as aid in future research for improving therapeutics/interventions for TS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cortical resections of brain tissue in children with drug-resistant epilepsy may damage parts of the broad network of cortical regions which interact with subcortical structures to control oculomotor function. This project aims to understand the extent to which key eye movements such as smooth pursuit and saccades are affected by such resections, how intact cortical regions involved in oculomotor control may adapt after resection of other areas, and whether neural and behavioral changes in oculomotor function have consequences for higher-order cognitive processes (e.g. such as when eye movements are critical for search of a complex display). These studies will be the first to systematically assess oculomotor function of smooth pursuit and saccades after pediatric epilepsy surgery and their postsurgical functional consequences, providing insight into the neuroplastic potential and limitations of the oculomotor system and its function; they will also expand understanding of both surgical risk and recovery in this population, and will open avenues for future investigations into interventions that will improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative 97% of ALS patients and 57% of Alzheimer’s Disease patients present with dysregulation of the protein TDP-43, causing disruption of a variety of critical genes, leading to neurodegenerative disease. Neuroinflammation, an understudied facet of ALS and Alzheimer’s Disease, occurs when overactive immune cells cause catastrophic damage to otherwise healthy neuronal tissue. Using neuron/immune cell culture and a mouse model of TDP-43 pathology that exhibits a progressive neurodegenerative phenotype, this project aims to understand the genetic and molecular regulators of neuroinflammation and characterize potential therapeutic targets for ALS and Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will create and test the efficacy in vivo of a novel T cell therapy to treat pulmonary fibrosis via TGF- β inhibitor payload delivery and profibrotic fibroblast depletion. T cells will co-express a Synthetic Intramembrane Proteolysis Receptor (SNIPR) and a Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR), both of which target profibrotic fibroblasts. The activation of the SNIPR circuit will drive the local secretion of TβRII-Fc to the fibrotic niche.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Gamma delta T cells are unusual T cells that play important roles in the immune response in mucosal tissues. Some gamma delta T cell subsets develop and acquire function only in the fetal thymus. We will use a mouse model to understand how maternal infection and inflammation during pregnancy influences the fetal thymic development of gamma delta T cells, and whether maternal infection/inflammation can result in long-lasting changes in gamma delta cell function in offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is a widespread and severe clinical outcome of poorly treated diabetes mellitus, and preliminary work has defined an association between diabetic heart disease, DNA methylation, and protein O- GlcNAcylation—(molecular marks implicated in the regulation of gene expression and protein function). However, while the possible downstream effector, Nox4, is upregulated upon long-term increased cardiac protein O-GlcNAc, the regulatory mechanism of Nox4 expression is understudied. This proposal aims to determine Nox4 regulation by DNA methylation, and Nox4’s necessity in the observed cardiac dysfunction during chronic enhanced O-GlcNAc.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS) have a well-documented association with a variety of disease pathologies, ROS also serve as key signaling molecules. Moreover, cardiac preconditioning has been effective in attenuating damage induced by ischemic injury, suggesting a beneficial role of ROS in priming cardiomyocytes for injury response. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate how diminished ROS during the initial neonatal mouse period impairs cardiomyocyte regeneration, as well as how lowered ROS levels during this period can delay metabolic maturation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Globally, it is estimated that infertility affects approximately 10-15% of all couples trying to become pregnant, and while the exact cause of infertility is not always known, dysfunction in circadian timekeeping capacity likely plays a role in the inability to conceive. This research will examine whether time-of-day changes in sexual behavior influence reproductive success in mice and whether sexual behavior can be manipulated throughout the day to optimize fertility. Overall, this project may lead to a better understanding of the daily changes in sexual drive propensity and may help in the design of therapeutics for individuals with misaligned daily rhythms (shift workers, etc.) who are trying to conceive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE American Indian populations experience the highest burden of cardiovascular disease compared to any other racial/ethnic group in the US and thus may be particularly vulnerable to the adverse health effects of even low levels of air pollution; however, there is currently a lack of relevant data to comprehensively characterize the air pollution levels, components, and sources in American Indian and other rural populations. Leveraging the NIH- funded Strong Heart Study, we will characterize air pollution and its association with cardiovascular disease in American Indian populations in the Southwest and the Great Plains. This study in rural and American Indian communities will provide critical data that are currently missing to inform National Ambient Air Quality Standards, contributing key information needed to inform interventions and mitigation strategies to reduce air pollution exposures and improve overall health of vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it closes a major gap in knowledge on how similar incretins elicit starkly different signaling responses in primary beta () cells. This proposed study extends our current understanding of incretin signaling within primary  cells and integrates this with differences between incretin-mediated cAMP responses in  cells and the interplay of cAMP and Ca2+ dynamics that dictate the  cell secretory response to nutrient and incretin co-stimulation. The proposed research is relevant to NIDDK’s mission because it directly addresses the mechanisms by which incretins potentiate glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which can be leveraged to improve therapies for millions of Americans with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because there is currently no clear consensus of the mechanism by which beta and delta cells coordinate their Ca2+ and hormone secretion in response to elevated blood glucose. The proposed mechanisms complement existing observations and link delta cells with distinct patterns of Ca2+ behaviors to specific mechanisms of coordination. The proposed research is relevant to NIDDK’s mission because it directly addresses the mechanism of beta-delta cell coordination, which is a crucial aspect of islet crosstalk to regulate insulin secretion that can be leveraged to improve the quality of life for millions of Americans afflicted with diseases of impaired glucose homeostasis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will combine neuroimaging methods and advanced functional MRI techniques to study the role of the cerebellum in linguistic functions. We will examine how the cerebellum uniquely contributes to the comprehension of syntax in sentences using functional MRI. Findings from this work will improve our basic scientific understanding of the cerebellum’s core algorithmic capabilities, reveal the cerebellum’s potential range of neural computations, and provide insight into how a disruption in these processes may cause language and verbal working memory deficits in various disorders such as dyslexia, specific language impairment and autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to investigate how thermo-tactile interactions drive human behavior by studying touch and temperature perception together. We will use centrally-mediated thermal illusions to determine if illusory thermal cues and illusory thermal pain modulate vibrotactile perception, providing insight into whether these interactions also occur centrally. Additionally, we will examine if primary somatosensory neurons encode cutaneous thermal information by analyzing the neural firing rates in response to vibrations under varying skin temperatures in non- human primates.

PHR: NARRATIVE Alterations in fat metabolism contribute to the etiology of multiple metabolic diseases that ultimately accounts for over 30% of mortality worldwide. The proposed research is designed to discover key mechanisms by which intestinal epithelial cells and microbiota respond to a high fat diet, and is expected to lead to increased understanding and new treatments for human diabetes, cardiovascular, and other metabolic diseases. The proposed research is therefore relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental new knowledge that will enhance health and reduce the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will advance knowledge about the impact of power outages on cardiovascular outcomes in the context of climate change. We plan to examine the role of power outages on cardiovascular disease, to understand the effects of outages during anomalously hot and anomalously cold temperatures, and to identify communities especially vulnerable to the effect of outages on cardiovascular disease outcomes. Our project can shape approaches to minimize outage-related morbidity and inform equitable preparedness strategies, emergency response, and energy policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We need new methods to track mental health symptoms that can be obtained passively, objectively, remotely, and continuously. Here, we combine video recordings, invasive brain measurements, and frequent symptom assessment to model mood using continuous video-derived facial and speech patterns as well as map the brain activities underlying these patterns. This objective mood classifier can aid in diagnostic screening, treatment optimization, and relapse prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gliomas are aggressive brain tumors with a dismal prognosis. Recent evidence has shown that neuronal activity promotes glioma proliferation and progression, but the mechanisms that mediate these effects are poorly understood and it is unclear how different types of neuronal activity, including seizures and stimulus-evoked neuronal activity, may affect glioma cells. This proposal aims to investigate and target a novel mechanism of glioma-neuron crosstalk to advance our understanding of how neuronal activity contributes to glioma progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human gut commensals Bacteroides spp. produce spherical membranous structures known as outer membrane vesicles (OMVs), which are proposed to participate in essential physiological roles like nutrient degradation and immunomodulation. However, our understanding of bacterial vesiculation is still in its infancy, and, therefore, determining the physiological relevance of Bacteroides OMVs has been challenging. In this project, we will investigate a family of regulators and proteins involved in OMV production. By employing OMV markers as tools, we will also investigate vesicle production in vivo and assess the impact it has on bacterial fitness and colonization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Inherited retinal degenerations, caused by mutations in over 300 genes, lead to progressive vision loss in people between 15-45 years of age and most are currently untreatable. We have identified a common mechanism that drives disease pathology in diverse inherited retinal degenerations. This research will investigate the efficacy of two small molecule drugs that target this mechanism for their ability to prevent inflammation, retinal degeneration, and vision loss in mouse models of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acinetobacter baumannii (Ab) is a bacterium that is highly resistant to antibiotics and often causes outbreaks in hospitals. We propose that new Ab strains are introduced into hospitals by patients previously infected with this bacterium which can remain dormant in the patient, reemerging upon hospital treatments that weaken their immune systems. In this proposal we will employ mice models to investigate how and where Ab survives within the patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lymphatic malformations (LMs) are a common developmental malformation consisting of a mass of overgrown lymphatic channels. Mutations in the oncogene PIK3CA drive the formation of LMs, but surprisingly these mutations are typically present in less than 10% of cells in the lesion. By better understanding the precise location of the mutant cells and their corresponding gene expression programs within intact human LM tissues we will advance our understanding of how these malformations develop, improve the development of novel therapies, and improve the lives of individuals with vascular malformations and other mosaic disorders in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  GPCRs are the largest class of membrane proteins in humans and have been linked with many cardiovascular disorders. While GPCRs make up a third of all FDA-approved drugs, including for example widely prescribed anti-hypertensives, many potentially druggable GPCRs remain intractable because they lack known ligands to modulate their activity. Here, I propose a platform to systematically generate probes to modulate understudied GPCRs, which would serve as a steppingstone to study them and develop new therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac fibrosis can compromise cardiac function and eventually lead to heart failure, and chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells represent a potential strategy for ablating pathologically activated fibroblasts that can cause cardiac fibrosis. This project aims to explore the feasibility of T cell engaging therapies in cardiac fibrosis, and also identify the mechanisms and effects of CAR T cell cross talk with other cardiac cellular populations. These findings will provide insights into the effects of cellular immunotherapies in cardiac fibrosis, and help identify ways to maximize their therapeut ic potential in this novel setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) has the highest mortality rate of all major cancers in the United States. Based on preliminary results my research will assess how MTH1 modulates PDAC tumorigenesis by evaluating both tumor intrinsic and tumor extrinsic responses using novel mouse models and in vitro models. Successful completion of this study will validate MTH1 as a new pharmacologically actionable target for PDAC and validate novel MTH1 conditional KO as a tool to study KRAS-driven cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community Engagement: A Short Course to Optimize Research Endeavors (CE-SCORE) will enhance the knowledge and skills of contemporary behavioral and social science researchers (BSSR) around community- engaged research and practice to advance public health goals in the United States. Current students, scholars, practitioners, and educators at various stages of their careers will engage in critical adult education learning cohorts and join a new community of practice. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Angiogenesis is crucial for tissue homeostasis and growth, yet it remains unclear how angiogenesis is spatially and temporally regulated to drive proper neovascularization therapeutically in settings such as tissue ischemia, or to block vascularization of tumors. This study will use innovative tissue-engineered human microvessels and sophisticated molecular and imaging approaches to deepen our understanding of endothelial control systems that enable angiogenesis, and inform future efforts towards development of new therapeutic interventions for driving or blocking tissue vascularization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Gender-Affirming Hormone Therapy (GAHT) for transgender women, which involves estrogen supplementation combined with anti-androgen therapy, is associated with an increased risk for cardiovascular diseases compared to the general population. Yet, the mechanisms involved are unknown. This project will investigate the etiology of increased cardiovascular risk in transgender women on GAHT using a novel and innovative model of GAHT in the male rat that mimics the effect of elevated estradiol with androgen suppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition in which the insulin producing beta cells are selectively targeted for destruction. The specific autoantigens that are critical for disease onset have yet to be identified, however, we have identified autoantigens that may play a significant role in the development of disease. The current proposal aims to determine the origin of these autoantigens and to study if the level of these autoantigens can affect the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes. Results from these studies may allow us to establish a disease-critical role of the antigens in the pathogenesis of diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We know very little about the role of germline variants in fibroid tumorigenesis despite fibroids being highly heritable, prevalent in the population, and recently identified variants having associated with risk. Despite the significant disparities and impact of fibroids among Black women, little progress has been made relative to other complex diseases, despite federal research agencies including the NIH, ORWH, and AHRQ recognizing fibroids among their priority women’s health topics. To our knowledge our study will be the first and largest evaluation of overall and cell-specific myometrial gene expression associated with fibroid risk among Black women, that leverages existing GWAS data and RNA sequencing approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intraoperative molecular imaging (IMI) with 111In-dinutuximab-IR800 could assist in localizing and completely resecting GD2-expressing pediatric cancers such as high-risk neuroblastoma and metastatic osteosarcoma, which currently have 5-year-survival rates of only 50% and 20%, respectively. Here, we propose to optimize probe manufacturing, evaluate safety, and test the ability to detect pulmonary osteosarcoma metastases of our group’s recently designed GD2-targeted IMI probe, 111In-dinutuximab-IR800. We will use results from these aims to prepare an IND and design an early phase clinical trial for intraoperative use of 11In-dinutuximab-IR800 in the surgical resection of neuroblastoma and osteosarcoma metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural killer (NK) cells are crucial for host defense against viral infection, and patients with primary NK cell deficiencies have been shown to have significant morbidity and mortality from unresolved viral infections. However, the molecular regulators that promote optimal effector function in human NK cells, and the associated metabolic changes that are required to meet the increased energy demands of activated NK cells remain poorly understood. Our proposed studies will describe how a novel transcriptional regulator of cytokine-induced metabolic adaptation promotes NK cell antiviral function, expanding our understanding of the molecular and metabolic mechanisms that regulate NK cell antiviral activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Although selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a primary therapy for individuals with Disorders of gut-brain interaction (DGBIs) and mood disorders, they have severe limitations (e.g., low efficacy and adverse effects [GI pain, dysmotility, and (paradoxical) anxiety]) that we found are due to their systemic absorption beyond the gut epithelium. Specifically, our published and preliminary data show that: (A) beneficial SSRI effects (anxiolytic, anti-depressive, anti-nociceptive) result from SERT antagonism in the GI epithelium and may involve vagal- and 5-HT3-mediated signaling and; (B) surprisingly, detrimental SSRI effects result from ENS or CNS SERT antagonism (anxiety, dysmotility, pain), implying that selective pharmacologic blockade of GI epithelial SERT could be beneficial for treating DGBIs +/- mood disorders without producing negative and efficacy-reducing effects linked to systemic SSRI exposure. We now propose to: (Aim 1) elucidate the roles of vagal signaling in linking gut epithelial 5-HT to beneficial effects on GI motility and pain sensitivity as well as mood; (Aim 2) examine how ENS SERT ablation affects DGBI symptoms and mood, to determine if avoidance of ENS SERT antagonism is necessary to prevent the negative and efficacy-reducing effects associated with systemic SSRI use and; (Aim 3) determine whether a state-of-the-art SSRI delivery platform that we have recently created, that maximally disperses and retains SSRI locally on the intestinal epithelium and minimizes systemic absorption, provides the beneficial mood effects of SSRIs while avoiding deleterious effects on GI pain, GI motility and mood.
PI_NAMEs: ANSORGE, MARK SASCHA;LEONG, KAM W;MARGOLIS, KARA GROSS (contact)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Adoptive cellular therapies have limited efficacy in solid tumors which account for 90% of adult cancers. The CARD protein-BCL10-MALT1 signaling complex is an essential mediator of T cell activation, and the novel CARD11-PIK3R3 fusion identified by our group has demonstrated robust and dramatic anti-tumor efficacy in vivo. This proposal aims to understand the mechanisms by which CARD11-PIK3R3 improves T cell fitness and anti-tumor efficacy in order to advance our understanding of T cell biology, elucidate mechanisms to engineer more effective T cell therapies, and ultimately provide more efficacious treatment options for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because: 1) it will directly lead to an improved understanding of how Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an important lung pathogen, regulates drug metabolism and disposition in the infected host, 2) it will give us unprecedented information into structure-function relationships between the P. aeruginosa cytochrome P450 enzymes and their substrates and inhibitors, and 3) it will provide leads to design inhibitors to the P. aeruginosa CYP enzymes that may eventually serve as adjuvant therapy to treat antibiotic resistant P. aeruginosa infections. These achievements are directly related to the goals of the NIH to reduce human disease and suffering and discover novel therapeutic drug candidates to treat the infectious pathogen, P. aeruginosa. Additionally, our proposal provides an opportunity to make fundamental discoveries related to the treatment of P. aeruginosa infections and serves as a basis for improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT NARRATIVE Our LJI CCHI was first funded in April of 2019 and it has been highly impactful in human immunology research in the past < 4 years, particularly during the COVID pandemic in the areas of COVID and COVID vaccines immune responses. The adaptive immune system is important for control of most viral infections. Improvements in controlling COVID remain somewhat impaired by our limited understanding of immune memory and upper airways immunity to SARS2, and the overarching focus connecting the three Projects in this LJI CCHI renewal proposal is immune memory, with emphasis on COVID and upper airways protective immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will enable us to view the molecular components of infectious disease with unprecedented resolution through the development of a new multimodal imaging platform. The proposed technologies will improve throughput and molecular specificity, enable automated high-precision and high-accuracy image alignment, and allow for more accurate descriptions of molecular signals through the fusion of multi-modal imaging data sources. These studies will uncover new targets for therapeutic intervention and antibiotic development and the techniques developed as a result of this proposal will be broadly applicable to all physiologically relevant processes, profoundly impacting biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fungal infections represent significant causes of morbidity and mortality in vulnerable patients across the globe. This Keystone Symposia meeting will bring together scientists in the mycology field to better understand the mechanisms of host-fungal interactions. This is a timely gathering of experts from diverse scientific backgrounds related to fungal biology and fungal immunology who share an ultimate goal of decreasing the burden of fungal infections and improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic genome engineering holds the potential to revolutionize the treatment of genetic diseases, from ultra-rare diseases to common leading causes of death, such as heart disease and cancer. It will also lead to significant advances in drug discovery by allowing researchers to more accurately model diseases, identify potential drug targets and test new therapies. This Keystone Symposia conference will bring together experts in technology development, therapeutic applications, and clinical translation to foster deeper understanding of what the current tools are capable of and how best to deploy them to treat human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epicardial adipose tissue has been suggested as a new cardiometabolic risk factor due to its anatomical proximity to the heart and coronary circulation and appears to be higher in adults with type 2 diabetes. Our lab utilizes novel, state-of-the-art MRI methods to assess cardiac structure and function, including specific fat depots. The proposed research will determine the relationship between epicardial adipose tissue and cardiometabolic health in youth with type 2 diabetes and investigate the impact of bariatric surgery on epicardial adipose tissue and cardiometabolic risk factors, independent of overall weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Plant terpenoids like cyclopamine (anti-cancer) can exhibit remarkable medicinal properties, however, the production of terpenoids via plant biosynthesis or chemical synthesis remains challenging. In contrast, engineered microorganisms can be used for the scalable, renewable, and inexpensive production of individual terpenoids like artemisinin (anti-malaria) from simple sugars and salts. This proposal aims to engineer brewer’s yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) to solve the challenge of sourcing cyclopamine for cancer treatment, establish methods to rapidly produce diverse libraries of triterpenoids as potential drug candidates, and accelerate the future microbial biosynthesis of medicinal terpenoids.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research on factors that contribute to safe reproductive health outcomes remains limited, as demonstrated by the alarming increase in maternal mortality rates. This project aims to investigate the differentiation pathway of uterine natural killer (uNK) cells from peripheral blood NK (pbNK) cells to decidualized NK (dNK) cells. By understanding the transcriptional program and factors involved in the creation of uNK and dNK cells, the most abundant leukocyte in the endometrium, scientists may identify the causes of pathological reproduction, infertility, and miscarriage, ultimately leading to improved outcomes in maternal and fetal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal outlines a training and research plan to investigate the utility of trans-ancestry polygenic risk scores in a real-world, ancestrally diverse cohort to predict health outcomes in a clinical setting. The research is relevant to NHGRI’s bold predictions by 2030, number 6 “The regular use of genomic information will have transitioned from boutique to mainstream in all clinical settings, making genomic testing as routine as complete blood counts” and number 9: “Individuals from ancestrally diverse backgrounds will benefit equitably from advances in human genomics.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Within healing wounds, many different types of cells work together to repair damaged tissue. This proposal will examine how small extracellular vesicles released by one cell type, endothelial cells, affect the function and behavior of another cell type, fibroblasts, in the context of the healing wound. The results of this study will better inform our fundamental understanding of how cells communicate in wounds, and may lead us to discover new therapies to improve healing or prevent scar formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromosomes must accurately segregate in order for organisms to develop and survive. Chromosome segregation errors lead to aneuploidy that drives cancer and genetic disease. Our proposed studies address the mechanisms that ensure proper chromosome segregation to avoid cancer and genetic disease associated aneuploidy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human milk provides significant health benefits to infants as well as the lactating parent, and while breastfeeding is recommended for the first six months of life, many families struggle to initiate and maintain lactation. Few clinical interventions exist to improve lactation outcomes, in part due to lack of understanding of the cellular process of lactation by cells in the mammary gland. This study will leverage existing transcriptomic data of mammary gland cells from human milk to identify the gene pathways underlying the process of lactation and its response to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The apoE4 gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late onset Alzheimer’s disease and is implicated in early prodromal network dysfunction in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus. Our preliminary work suggests an apoE4-induced accumulation of immature hyperexcitable dentate granule cells in aged mice. The proposed studies will use a combination of electrophysiology with single cell transcriptomics (patchSeq) together with morphological reconstruction to determine the mechanisms underlying apoE4-induced dentate gyrus dysfunction and how these mechanisms may be counteracted and treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The decline of neurogenesis has been associated with many neurological disorders. Considering the critical role NR2E1, a nuclear receptor, plays in regulating neurogenesis, it is likely that certain NR2E1 missense mutations might cause neurogenesis-associated pathology by impairing NR2E1 function and/or activity. Our project will investigate the molecular, cellular, and behavioral consequences of one patient-specific NR2E1 mutation to gain insight into the importance of NR2E1 for human neurogenesis.
