IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Rotavirus vaccine was developed to prevent severe diarrhea and is especially important in low- and middle- income countries where 85% of deaths due to rotaviruses occur; unfortunately, vaccine efficacy is lower in these countries compared to high-income countries. This proposal will study infants from three countries with different socioeconomic levels and use sophisticated methods to determine how specific bacteria in the infant gut (microbiome) may change the response to the vaccine. If successful, this study will have a significant impact on this important public health disparity as a targeted intervention to improve vaccine response, even if small, could save tens of thousands of lives every year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Splicing factors (SF) control which version of a given gene is expressed. Defects in SFs lead to human diseases such as neurological disorders, cardiac myopathies, diabetes, lupus, or cancer. Here, we will elucidate at the molecular level how SFs are regulated, and will develop molecules to correct SF defects in disease models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE  COVID-19, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus type 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has caused over 6 million deaths and economic devastation worldwide; while several vaccines have been developed, there is a growing need for effective prophylactic treatments, especially for vulnerable populations. The goal of this highly collaborative proposed research is to develop potent lipopeptides that inhibit SARS-CoV-2 infection by blocking viral entry into host cells. Through structure-guided engineering and sophisticated and multi-pronged assay implementation, these efforts could generate effective pan-variant therapeutics for COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes are a heterogenous population of glial cells that play critical roles in neuronal circuit assembly and function in health and disease, but the molecular drivers of their heterogeneity remains poorly understood. This proposal seeks to characterize astrocyte molecular, structural, and functional diversity across development stages and brain regions in the rodent and primate brain using cutting-edge techniques. Detailed characterization of astrocyte subpopulations will enable their more precise manipulation for basic and translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress-induced activity of corticotropin releasing factor (CRF) has been shown to shift neuronal function in a variety of brain regions. The ventral pallidum is a basal ganglia structure that integrates environmental stimuli, and mediates motivated and reward-consumption behaviors. This proposal aims to investigate a potential mechanism underlying stress-induced potentiation of reward consumption, and posits that stress exposure, via CRF signaling, increases activity of a ventral pallidum population that expresses CRF receptor type 1.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Diabetes is highly prevalent in the United States and is currently incurable. Therapeutic strategies to amplify and protect the endogenous β cell mass in patients are a major focus of research, with the hypusination pathway identified as a relevant avenue of investigation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Chronic pain has estimated costs in the US of $635 billion annually , yet no scientifically validated therapy exists for such condition; as a consequence many patients receive long-term treatments with prescription opioids and risk becoming addicted. Recent data show that functional deactivation of the medial prefrontal cortex represents a critical step causing the pain phenotype, but the underlying cellular mechanisms remain largely unclear. We will take advantage of electrophysiological, chemo- and opto-genetic, behavioral, and molecular techniques to test the overarching hypothesis that impaired cholinergic modulation of the prefrontal cortex causes several emotional, cognitive and sensory symptoms of neuropathic pain and that pharmacological normalization of the cholinergic signaling importantly ameliorates the neuropathic pain phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although neuronal loss following brain injury is generally considered permanent, new neurons are born in select locations in the mammalian brain and then integrated into specific neural circuitry (i.e. neurons born in the subventricular zone and then guided by the rostral migratory stream to the olfactory bulb). We have created the first implantable engineered microtissue that structurally and functionally emulates the glial tube of the rostral migratory stream, to date being biofabricated from both rodent as well as human cell sources. The current proposal will evaluate the efficacy of this approach to redirect endogenous newborn neurons to sites of focal degeneration in a preclinical model of traumatic brain injury, which if successful, would provide a regenerative medicine strategy for neuronal replacement potentially capable of mitigating the often devastating — and currently untreatable — cognitive and motor deficits in afflicted patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative In radiology today, we are frustrated daily by our inability to obtain useful diagnostic images in young children, who are often unable to remain still for long scan durations, without resorting to the use of sedation or anesthesia, which unfortunately are associated with the possibility of serious adverse side effects and add significantly to the cost of imaging. Thus, there is an urgent, unmet need for accurate, safe and reliable imaging techniques to offset the effects of uncontrolled, fast motion in children, to produce images of superior diagnostic value without the use of sedation, leading to effective diagnosis, treatment and monitoring of pediatric disease. The proposed project, “Improved Motion Robust MRI of Children” promises to deliver a highly innovative imaging method capable of producing high-quality images in the presence of large and frequent motion by tracking the position of the head and updating the acquisition in real-time, which will in turn remove the need for sedation, effectively eliminating potentially life-threatening side effects from the imaging equation.

PHR: 9. Project Narrative This project will investigate several aspects of the impact of herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) infection on neurogenesis. We will investigate the effects of the virus on the neuronal progenitor cells proliferation, differentiation and migration, and whether HSV-1 can establish latency using human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC)-based technologies and an animal model. Our long- term goal is to prevent or treat long term neurological sequelae caused by the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) in children remains one of the most common causes of childhood morbidity and mortality, and a known, common complication is post-injury nosocomial infection. TBI is frequently accompanied by systemic injuries (polytraumatic TBI), and these types of combined injuries are likely even more prone to post-injury immune suppression; however, there is little preclinical data examining the timeline for immune suppression following injury or how reversing post-injury immune suppression may affect the injured, recovering brain. This project seeks to identify therapies to treat post-injury immune suppression with the central hypothesis that post-injury immune suppression is an important acute and chronic sequela of critical injury that can be attenuated without negatively impacting neurological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative/Public Health Impact Despite the fact that safe and effective endoscopic procedures for removal of colon lesions have been demon- strated in the academic literature, over 60,000 patients per year in the USA alone still undergo invasive surgery to remove sections of their colons. The culprit for this is the lack of dexterity in tools passed through conventional colonoscopes, making procedures so challenging that only a small number of the best endoscopists can attempt them. To help more patients beneﬁt from minimally invasive, endoscopic approaches, we propose a new dex- terous steerable instrument sheath that is thin enough to ﬁt through the port of a conventional colonoscope and provides dexterity, enabling endoscopists to perform complex surgical motions easily inside a patient's colon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: || PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron deficiency is the cause for over 50% of anemias and is associated with heart failure, chronic kidney disease, and chronic inflammation. Because all of these diseases are associated with abnormal endothelial function, it is critical to understand how changes in systemic iron impact endothelial function. This project investigates iron-induced changes in hemoglobin alpha, a key regulator of endothelial function, as a novel mechanism by which iron regulates endothelial function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Defects in endothelial cell specification causes embryonic lethality, vascular malformations, and contributes to many diseases; however, the mechanisms regulating endothelial cell specification are poorly understood. We propose that cell cycle control is necessary for proper endothelial cell specification and that its loss will lead to immature and malformed vasculature. Completion of these studies will reveal novel mechanisms that regulate arterial and venous vessel formation, which will aid in the creation of clinical and regenerative therapies for vascular pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nucleic acid therapeutics, including DNA and RNA-based drugs, have emerged as promising treatments for many diseases. Nucleic acids offer a high degree of specificity and selectivity for their targets, making them potentially safer and more effective than traditional small molecule drugs, but their delivery to specific cells and tissues remains a central challenge. This Keystone Symposia conference will assemble researchers who bring diverse scientific perspectives and methodologies to advance the field of nucleic acid therapeutics toward broader clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac hypoxia is a prominent contributor to the pathophysiology of a myriad of cardiac diseases, constituting the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the world. Cardiomyocytes have an innate ability to adapt to mild hypoxia through fuel switching over chronic timescales, however, the molecular mediators of this transition have not been fully elucidated. The goal of this proposal is to gain a comprehensive understanding of the pathways that facilitate adaptive and maladaptive metabolic rewiring (particularly for fuel use) in hypoxic CMs, with the long-term goal of targeting these pathways as novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By determining the role of locomotion in inter-areal communication, we seek to understand how communication in the brain can be altered or improved by behavior. Better understanding of inter-areal signaling may provide important insights into the neural substrates of disorders where signaling is altered, as in autism and schizophrenia. Understanding changes in inter-areal communication with behavior may help us elucidate mechanisms of existing therapies, such as mirror therapy, music therapy, and mindfulness, as well as develop new therapies that help to restore optimal inter-areal communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We will develop a set of cutting-edge methods to: (i) reliably identify connected neurons in superficial and deep brain structures, (ii) visualize and physiologically characterize these neurons within a larger population using advanced scanning laser imaging and high density multielectrode recordings, and (iii) analyze the population dynamics in the context of an ethologically relevant behavioral task. Our findings will reveal how brain regions communicate and integrate sensory signals and prior knowledge to support complex perceptual behavior. Ultimately, our studies will bring us closer to devising strategies to alleviate and treat brain disorders of impaired object recognition resulting from dysfunctions in the occipito-temporal pathway (e.g. agnosia) and from diminished communication between visual and prefrontal cortex (e.g. autism).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We will continue to use the touch receptor neurons of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to study basic questions about nerve cell development (how are cells ensheathed by surrounding tissue) and mechanosensation (what is the structure of the transduction channel, what genes negatively regulate touch). The importance of this research to public health derives from the similarity of the nematode genes to those of humans and the fact that, as many people have remarked, one must have something to translate to do translational research. Genetic approaches such as those that we use provide the new players and novel insights into biological functions that not only increase our general knowledge, but also provide new ways to address and understand the processes that go awry in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Michigan's Clinical Research in Digestive Diseases (CRDD) Training Program provides patient-oriented clinical research training to physician-scientists whose goal is to improve the treatment of digestive diseases. The purpose of this training is to produce outstanding clinically oriented medical researchers who investigate the causes, prevention, and treatment of digestive diseases. Since 2003, our trainees have fulfilled this goal, and 95% of our graduates are now faculty at academic medical centers, being awarded multiple research grants, and producing numerous publications of their research work over the past 19 years of funding, leading to improved care and outcomes in a broad range of digestive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This institutional training grant will provide stipends for post-doctoral trainees wishing to pursue a career in research to better understand the mechanisms or the utility of complementary and integrative health approaches to maximize nervous system health or treat dysfunction/disorders of the nervous system including those related to stress. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCCs) confer significant morbidity and mortality that associate with older age, yet preclinical models predominately focus on outcomes in young animals, possibly underlying the poor efficacy of current pharmacological treatments. We propose to test how age impacts the cellular, epigenetic, and transcriptional behavior of a syngeneic orthotopic xenograft model of HNSCC. Our study will provide a comprehensive characterization of tumors in different aged niches, providing insight to age- associated mechanisms of pro-tumorigenic phenotypes that may be targeted for the future development of treatments to improve clinical outcomes for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Excessive sneezing and ensuing rhinorrhea are the cardinal symptoms of allergic rhinitis. This proposal will characterize the role of a highly restricted population of nasal sensory fibers in detecting both histamine and non-histamine mediators released from mast cells and mediating sneezing in allergic rhinitis. These studies will advance our understanding of the neuro-immune interactions in allergic sneezing and unravel new drug targets for controlling nasal symptoms in allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The World Health Organization (WHO) recently launched a Call to Action to eliminate cervical cancer by 2030, with aggressive goals for vaccination, screening, and treatment. To scale-up screening, there must be a low-cost, effective test for the human papillomavirus (HPV) that allows women to collect their own samples and returns results the same day to treat those who screen positive. The current research will show that self- collection of AmpFire®, a new affordable test for HPV, will be superior in efficacy to the current test used in low-resource settings, allow for a single-visit approach to decrease loss to follow-up, and provide a cost- effective approach that aids in the effort to eliminate cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Due to the extreme complexity of the brain, we still have a very limited understanding of how different cells in our brains work together to give rise to our behaviors. Through development of novel technologies that enable non-invasive, precise, selective excitation and/or inhibition of brain cells while measuring high-resolution videos of the associated whole brain interactions during behavior, we aim to reverse-engineer the brain function algorithms underlying behavior. Upon success, these measurements will enable quantitative description of normal brain function and how it changes during brain disorders including Alzheimer's disease and related dementias or pain leading to opioid crisis, which in turn will enable us to systematically design therapies that can restore normal brain circuit function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  We propose to conduct a well-powered multi-omics study to discover novel methylation markers and novel genes for breast cancer risk in three racial groups. Findings from our association study, together with integrative bioinformatics and functional experiments, will greatly improve our understanding of novel mechanisms for genetic effects on breast cancer. The identified methylation markers could be used in risk-assessment and risk-stratifying for the prevention of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The Society for Investigative Dermatology (SID) Retreat is an annual conference specifically designed to increase the number of dermatology residents and PhD trained skin scientists that enter academia. The SID Retreat provides formal and informal mentoring and panel discussions focused on career development, work-life balance, career paths, obtaining research funding, and provides useful information about circumventing barriers to entry into academia and insight into grant funding opportunities and the publication process. The ability to increase the pipeline of multidisciplinary educators and scientists focused on skin biology, wellness and disease supports the mission of the SID to advance sciences relevant to skin disease through education, advocacy and scholarly exchange of scientific information and will help identify, retain, and support future generations of dermatologists and investigative skin scientists.

PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the basic mechanisms that control the excitability of central neurons will help in understanding the normal function of the nervous system as well as pathophysiology resulting in pain, epilepsy, ataxia, and other disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: In the past, the medical community identified human diseases by combining patients with similar phenotypes and looking for shared genetic changes. This approach is limited by our clinical ability to see appropriate connections between phenotypic features in patients. This application uses a gene-first approach in a large research cohort with associated exome sequences to identify the full range of medically relevant human phenotypes (common and rare) associated with variants in genes coding for elastic fiber proteins followed by deep phenotyping in individual patients to learn more about the mechanism of disease and its clinical impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal seeks to develop new combinations of treatment for patients with a subset of melanoma patients with a mutation in the NRAS gene. We will determine whether drugs that block growth of the tumor cells and reprogram the tumors immune cells can be used to make tumors that do not respond to immune checkpoint inhibitors responsive. If successful, these combined treatments will prolong the survival of melanoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This project seeks to use an animal model to interrogate novel mechanisms by which diet-derived lipid metabolites and the gut microbial flora influence the development of hypertensive crises in individuals living with spinal cord injury. The proposed research is expected to lead to an improved understanding that will inform future clinical studies. This work is particularly important as current treatment practices are limited to acute management of the symptomatic outcome rather than targeting the underlying cause of this disease process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health as the incidence of gastroparesis has been rapidly increasing, partially attributable to growing diabetes prevalence. Gastroparesis causes a significant detriment to quality of life, and treatment consumes a considerable amount of healthcare resources, including frequent hospitalization. Current therapeutic options for gastroparesis management do not adequately address this growing public health concern, and novel interventions with established efficacy will be required, particularly once the disease becomes medically refractory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative CLL is the most common leukemia of adults, yet incurable. The most significant risk factor for CLL is a family history of the disease, and we have identified mutations in the ATM gene as associated with CLL. In this work we will further characterize the clinical and biological effects of these mutations, as well as identify other genes associated with CLL risk, with the goal of providing counseling and screening to patients and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age- and disease-related changes in sleep are thought to play a direct role in cognitive impairments and Alzheimer’s disease pathophysiology. Sleep enhancement is a promising long-term, low cost, feasible intervention to mitigate excitotoxicity which may cause cognitive impairments and leave neurons vulnerable to Alzheimer’s disease pathology. The present study will examine whether habitual slow-wave sleep enhancement ameliorates neuroimaging markers of excitotoxic hyperactivation, Alzheimer’s disease pathophysiology, and cognitive performance in older adults with and without significant Aβ deposition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: We propose an innovative approach to the evaluation and treatment of post-traumatic infection by developing methodology and analytic tools optimized for application of indocyanine green (ICG)-based dynamic contrast- enhanced fluorescence imaging (DCE-FI) to objectively measure bone perfusion and use this data to guide surgical debridement of devitalized bone. The scientific premise of this project is based on our preclinical and pilot clinical study demonstrating that real-time intraoperative ICG-based DCE-FI can provide surgeons with objective clinically relevant data regarding blood flow to bone. In the proposed study we will define quantitatively the relationship between perfusion and recurrent bone infection, enhance the capability of DCE-FI to estimate bone perfusion by identifying the correlation between DCE-FI and dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI (DCE-MRI), and optimize bone-specific analytic techniques.

PHR: Narrative The proposed studies will contribute to public health by increasing our knowledge of the functional alterations that lead to the cognitive and behavioral deficits associated with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, which is among the most common neurodevelopmental diseases in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Catalytic C-H bond functionalization has emerged as a powerful approach in organic synthesis for the discovery and production of new pharmaceuticals. The next generation C-H bond functionalization methods described in this proposal will enable the rapid assembly of pharmaceutically relevant compounds, including complex architectures, from simple and readily available inputs. As they are developed, these synthetic methods will be applied to the discovery and optimization of potent and selective ligands to challenging biomolecular targets relevant to the treatment of unmet medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Hyperglycemia in patients with T2DM is initially treated with metformin coupled with intentional caloric restriction, which is difficult to sustain due to multiple barriers, including acquiring the necessary knowledge, teaching the intervention, cost of delivery and potential burden on quality of life. In contrast to intentionally restricting calories, time restricted eating (TRE), presents a simplified view of eating focused on restricting the eating window, which allows ad libitum intake per their dietary preferences during a daily fixed eating window. We propose a 24 week feasibility study to test if TRE is a viable alternative to Caloric Restriction in improving glycemic measures while accounting for weight loss in overweight/obese patients [BMI:25-35 kg/m2] with metformin-only treated Type 2 diabetes.

PHR: Cellular polarity is an essential feature of organogenesis and tissue development and homeostasis in general. The regulation and maintenance of the epithelial planar cell polarity (PCP) feature is linked to many diseases, ranging from deafness and infertility to neural tube closure defects and ciliopathies, and also cancer (several PCP determinants are tumor suppressors or proto-oncogenes). This application addresses the cell biology and molecular regulation of PCP establishment, which is of high significance for many medical disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the first R01 cycle we demonstrated successful microfluidic delivery of small-molecule cancer drug panels to glioblastoma (GBM) xenograft slices as well as to GBM patient tumor slices. In this second R01 cycle, we propose to further develop Oncoslice to integrate multiplexed combination immunotherapy testing of cancer slices with molecular and computational analysis, as well as live imaging of the tumor microenvironment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: University of Detroit Mercy’s Integrated Research Initiative for Student Enhancement (I-RISE) with U-RISE program will result in more underrepresented graduates transitioning into biomedical, research-focused advanced degree programs (e.g., Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D.). We will accomplish these goals through 1) intensive recruitment of underrepresented students to biomedical majors, 2) early introduction to research practices, 3) immersion in culturally-responsive, authentic mentored research experiences, and 4) ongoing and extensive trainee support. The integration of trainee-focused activities throughout the three-year I-RISE with U-RISE program has been carefully planned with the ultimate goal of helping trainees successfully matriculate into graduate biomedical research programs and the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Misregulation of chromatin states either via misregulation of ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling enzymes or misregulation of heterochromatin is strongly associated with cancer and developmental defects. Yet how chromatin remodeling enzymes work or how heterochromatin is assembled and regulated is poorly understood. This proposal combines biophysical approaches with cellular tests to tackle these challenging questions, with the goal of identifying key steps that are targets for regulation and that can be controlled for therapeutic intervention in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Migraine affects an estimated 12-15% of the world population, while chronic migraine – which completely disrupts the lives of sufferers – affects close to 3%, accounting for the vast majority of the disability and cost of the disorder. Current clinical criteria are useful for diagnosing episodic and chronic migraine, but they have not necessarily been predictive of progression, and thus are not helpful in identifying subjects at risk. This study will develop and validate sensory measures as predictive biomarkers of migraine progression, generating tools that can identify patients at risk of chronic migraine and allow preventive measures to be taken.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) women experience profound maternal health disparities in the US, including rising rates of maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity. This study will develop a Well- Mama intervention for pregnant and postpartum BIPOC women, centered around Community Doula Navigators conducting in-person and telehealth check-ins on 5 priority areas (mental health, cardiovascular symptoms, safety, opioid/substance abuse, and social support), supplemented with virtual support groups and labor support. We will conduct a randomized trial in Chicago IL, Newark NJ, and Baton Rouge LA to test whether the Well- Mama intervention increases BIPOC women’s receipt of prenatal and postpartum care.

PHR: Narrative Despite significant improvement in short-term survival of organ transplants, attrition of transplanted organs over time due to chronic rejection remains a significant clinical problem. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project has the potential to change prevention paradigms and alter the staging and strategies for treating patients with newly diagnosed melanoma, a serious skin cancer that leads to approximately 10,000 deaths in the USA each year. The goal is to identify at the time of diagnosis which melanomas are the dangerous, potentially lethal ones that should be treated early and, conversely, which melanomas are very unlikely to lead to recurrence and death, potentially sparing these patients toxic and expensive treatments. We will accomplish this by examining the genetic and immune alterations in tumor samples collected from 1,690 patients diagnosed with melanoma in the year 2000 with 10-year follow-up, allowing us to determine which combinations of tumor alterations identified the melanomas that led to the death of the patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: The objective of this work is to develop novel applications of deep neural networks leveraging ground truth cine DENSE data in order to provide a novel approach to extracting data from cine imaging through machine learning methods, and the application of these methods to a rich dataset with complete CMR, response, and survival data. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research has strong public health significance as it focuses on a population at disproportionate risk for obesity and for whom intervention reach and effectiveness must be markedly improved to reduce existing disparities. The proposed pilot trial will utilize a group randomized, repeated measures design to assess the feasibility, acceptability and preliminary effectiveness of the house chat model as a grassroots approach to lifestyle intervention delivery in a community setting. This project is directly relevant to NIDDK’s priorities related to obesity management among underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Approximately 7% of older adults diagnosed with cancer have pre-existing dementia. Often, these scenarios require complex decisions integrating information about two significant illnesses and the risks and benefits of potential interventions in the context of the dual diagnoses. The overarching goal of this proposal is to adapt an existing communication tool developed by our team for use in patients with Alzheimer’s Disease or Related Dementias (ADRD) and their care partners, and evaluate if this tool can enhance communication about cognitive impairment in the context of a cancer management decision in discussions between patients with ADRD, their care partners and their oncology clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: There is a critical need to identify the daily social determinants of cardiovascular disease and their biological mechanisms among urban middle-aged and older African American (AA) adults. By adopting a prospective, mixed-method, and multiple-time-scale design, we will work on a sample of 500 AAs aged 55-75 years living in Detroit to determine through ecological measurements the psychosocial stressors that characterize this sample and identify the psychological and biological intermediaries through which psychosocial stressors pose a risk for cardiovascular disease. Our results are expected to have a substantial positive impact because they will contribute to establish a model of the social determinants of cardiovascular disease risk that will inform the identification of culturally relevant targets for the development of behavioral interventions to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease among urban middle-aged and older AA adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While defects in mitochondrial function are implicated in the pathogenesis of heart failure (HF), translation of mitochondrial-targeted HF therapy to the clinic has not succeeded to date. This project will employ an innovative luminoptogenetic technology to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of preserving cardiomyocyte mitochondrial function in improving cardiac remodeling and contractile dysfunction in the failing hearts. The findings will not only advance our understanding of the mechanisms connecting mitochondrial dysfunction and pathogenesis of HF, but also lead to the development of a novel synergistic mitochondrial-targeted therapy for HF treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The negative impact of maternal depression on the livelihood of families and children cannot be understated, particularly for those living in poverty and marginalized communities who are less likely to receive treatment. We developed a paraprofessional-guided Internet-delivered depression intervention to overcome barriers to service utilization for depressed mothers of young children. Our Phase II SBIR goals serve to significantly expand access to depression intervention within the community by developing a Train-the-Trainer program that will more firmly seat training and intervention delivery in the community, by the community.

PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are important in providing energy for the contracting myocyte, but dysfunctional mitochondria can be harmful to the cell and needs to be eliminated by autophagosomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient processing of RNA and translation into proteins requires interactions with numerous RNA binding proteins, and can be regulated by chemical post-transcriptional RNA modifications (PTrMs). We have selected Adenovirus as a model system with which to study RNA modifications on non-coding and messenger RNAs and to determine how they can be harnessed to control cellular processes during infection. The overall goal of this proposal is to develop high-throughput mass spectrometry approaches to quantify PTrMs and identify how they impact association of RNA binding proteins with technologies that will have broad applicability to enable new biology in virus-host interactions and epitranscriptomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative As the burden of neurological disorders and neurodegenerative diseases in the United States and worldwide is high, there is a critical need to discover and perform an initial evaluation of molecular imaging biomarkers and/or biomarker signatures, such as positron emission tomography (PET) imaging tools, to support the clinical development and translation of novel neurotherapeutics. This work will identify, design, and evaluate subtype- selective metabotropic receptor PET ligands to deliver candidate biomarkers for definitive analytical and clinical validation studies, facilitating drug discovery and target engagement study of novel neurotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections due to Staphylococcus aureus pose a major public health threat. In this study, we will define how the “normal” bacterial communities carried on the skin and in the nose may make someone more or less likely to acquire S. aureus. We will also define how topical antimicrobials (often prescribed to prevent S. aureus infection) alter the skin and/or nasal bacterial communities, and discover how these alterations may lead to colonization with harmful or antibiotic-resistant bacteria. This knowledge will help to optimize S. aureus prevention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Elderly Spanish-English bilinguals at risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) are rapidly increasing in numbers in the USA but relatively little is known about how cognitive assessments should be modified to cater to this population. The current proposal aims to establish unique aspects of the presentation of AD in bilinguals while testing theoretical models of bilingual language processing and cognitive decline in AD. The proposed studies will provide important information about the presentation of language impairments in bilinguals with AD, and will develop theoretically motivated cognitive assessment procedures for bilinguals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Recent advances in cell therapy with autologous effector T cells engineered to target and destroy tumor cells is leading to extraordinary breakthroughs in cancer treatment. The current proposal seeks to develop new engineered T regulatory cells that modulate inflammation and improve cognitive function in Alzheimer’s Disease. Successful development of this innovative therapeutic strategy will be the foundation of new treatment approaches for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate factors that may contribute to poor outcomes in Hodgkin lymphoma in people living with HIV in South Africa where the difference in outcomes is striking. Present evidence suggests that at least part of the difference in outcomes reflects long delays in Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosis in PLWH. As such, we will develop and test a new diagnostic algorithm based on plasma tumor molecular markers that may expedite the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma in PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Defining STIM1 function at the Immunological Synapse – NARRATIVE STIM1-dependent Ca2+ signals represent the primary means of Ca2+ entry in T cells and are required for adaptive immunity. An immunological synapse is a temporary interaction between T cells and antigen-presenting cells and leads to a profound re-organization of multiple signaling proteins within the T cell. The current proposal focuses on defining the underlying mechanisms controlling localization of proteins at the immunological synapse and determining their impact on T cell activation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The thymus mediates T cell positive and negative selection to prevent autoimmunity. Migratory and resident antigen presenting cells contribute to thymocyte selection by diverse, sometimes cell specific mechanisms. Our understanding on the emergence of autoimmune pathologies driven by autoreactive T cells who escape tolerance mechanisms, such as central tolerance, is still limited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The first-in-human DNA vaccine, AV-1959D based on MultiTEP platform is designed (i) to augment anti-Aβ antibody production without activation of potentially harmful autoreactive Th cells (ii) to activate Th cells specific to foreign epitopes incorporated in MultiTEP, providing broad coverage of the targeted population with high MHC class II gene polymorphism and (iii) to activate naïve and memory Th cells overcoming the immunosenescence in the older people. Of note, due to an ethical imperative raised by the FDA during our pre-IND meeting, we propose Phase 1 safety/tolerability/immunogenicity trials of AV-1959D in early stage AD patients based on IND18953 cleared by the FDA in April 2020 prior to initiating the preventive trials in asymptomatic people at risk of MCI/AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: This study will advance and optimize a co-registered photoacoustic microscopy and ultrasound endoscopic system to fill a critical gap in the current management of rectal cancer: identifying tumor treatment response after neoadjuvant therapy. A clinical trial will evaluate the system’s ability to identify treatment responders and therefore reduce morbidity in the treatment of this common disease. Finally, serial surveillance of patients with complete responses to therapy will investigate markers of tumor recurrence among this high risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The periosteum is a highly specialized tissue microenvironment. Periosteal cells regulate the strength of bones by controlling bone width and the ability of bones to heal after fracture. This grant focuses on the importance of BMP2 signaling in regulating periosteal cell function during growth in width and during fracture healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: It is unknown why some cancer cells within a given tumor cell population die while others do not when the whole population is exposed to a death stimulus like an anti-cancer drug. In this project, we test the hypothesis that these differences are due to cell-to-cell variation in the cellular recycling process, autophagy. Understanding these mechanisms may allow new approaches to control how we kill cancer cells and to reduce heterogeneity in tumor cells responses to therapy and thus provide a new way to improve cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) affects nearly 1.5 million people in the US and we need new treatments for it and the increased risk of atherosclerosis that accompanies it. Isolevuglandins (isoLGs) are reactive products of oxidative stress that change proteins causing inflammation and worsening autoimmune disease and atherosclerosis in animal models. We will study 2-hydroxybenzylamine (2-HOBA), a compound that scavenges isoLGs and has the potential to both treat RA and decrease atherosclerosis, to determine its safety and potential efficacy in patients with RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of patients with metastatic breast cancer do not respond to immunotherapy with the tumor- infiltrating neutrophils as a major factor to mediate the immunotherapy resistance. Our preliminary results identify the metabolic enzyme aconitate decarboxylase (ACOD1) to be dramatically upregulated and functionally critical in tumor-infiltrating neutrophils. Upon completion of our project, we expect to define the mechanisms underlying neutrophil ACOD1 function in breast cancer metastasis and demonstrate the potential of ACOD1 inhibition to enhance metastatic breast cancer response to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Within the eukaryotic cell nucleus, the human genome is associated with core histones and other proteins to form a multifaceted complex known as chromatin. This complex brings about the orderly packaging of the immense length of DNA within the tiny volume of the nucleus and is directly involved in critical cell functions. This project aims to elucidate fundamental aspects of chromatin structure, and how chromatin modifiers regulate access to DNA within chromatin and contribute to control of gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many events during animal development require that proteins are made at particular cellular locations where they are needed; often cells accomplish this by moving messenger RNAs (mRNAs) that code for proteins to the locations where they are needed and applying controls to ensure that protein is produced only there and only at the right time. Impairment of such mechanisms is associated with cancer metastasis, neurodegenerative disorders, and infertility. The proposed studies use sophisticated microscopy methods, innovative biochemical strategies, and genomic approaches to investigate how gathering mRNAs together in structures called germ granules localizes them within an embryo to control the production of proteins needed for cells to follow the right developmental programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VISITING NURSE SERVICE OF NEW YORK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-living older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) make up 31% of the Medicare Home Health (HH) patient population and receive more intensive HH care, yet remain at higher risk for adverse outcomes including readmission. Efforts to improve HH care quality for those with ADRD must consider the critical contributions of family caregivers: family caregivers are a major source of support during HH and prior work indicates that engaging/supporting caregivers in care delivery improves outcomes for older adults. The proposed research will elucidate the role and support needs of ADRD caregivers during HH and determine how family caregiver availability and capacity affect HH outcomes for patients with ADRD, providing crucial foundational evidence for the development of effective interventions to improve HH care quality for those with ADRD by better supporting their family caregivers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative It is unlikely that COVID-19 vaccines will lead to the end of PASC syndrome given the emergence of increasingly infectious variants and the high numbers of individuals with continued symptoms several months from their initial infection. High rates of hesitancy and refusal to become vaccinated, both in the US and worldwide, will also contribute to the persistence of both COVID-19 and PASC. Given that there has been over 79 million people infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus in the U.S. and 434 million worldwide, it is imperative to develop and rigorously test the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a rehabilitation program that may ameliorate symptoms and restore pre-infection function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Comparing the US to 184 other nations, only 40 nations have higher rates of low birth weight (LBW) (less than 5 pounds, 8 ounces) and 53 have higher rates of preterm birth (PTB) (before 37 weeks). The surprisingly high incidence of LBW and PTB is driven primarily by birth outcomes among low-income, disproportionately Black, mothers, pointing to social and economic determinants of health. This study uses the Panel Study of Income Dynamics, a nationally representative, longitudinal dataset to: (1) compare the effects on birth outcomes of individual ESPs and ESP combinations; (2) determine the extent to which improvements to healthcare access, food insecurity, psychological distress, and prenatal health behaviors mediate the relationship between ESP generosity and birth outcomes; and (3) identify whether ESP generosity effects are moderated by poverty level, race, marital status, and/or education. By improving scientific knowledge of which ESPs or ESP packages work best in general, for specific health risk-factors, and for specific groups, this research will support the funding, design, and delivery of policies and interventions that promote economic security and reduce rates of, and inequalities in, LBW and PTB.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates the biological basis underlying the migration of neural crest cells. Neural crest cell migration represents directed cell migration and is critical to diverse diseases including craniofacial anomalies, heart defects, and cancer. Mechanistic understanding of the complex dynamic events during in vivo cell migration will shed light on the etiology of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the explosion of biological knowledge that has occurred since the turn of the century, the impact on drug discovery and precision medicine has been modest. To address the key issues limiting this success, this project will develop an AI-driven, integrated protein structure and interaction network-based approach, MEDICASCY-X, that will predict disease associated proteins, identify the most effective protein targets to treat the disease and suggest effective, de-risked therapeutic strategies. MEDICASCY-X will be applied to improve drug discovery and precision medicine and will be validated by developing novel preclinical treatments for a variety of intractable diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COPD is an HIV-associated lung disease and a leading cause of illness and death, and its clinical significance is increasing as the HIV-infected population ages worldwide. Despite this, our understanding of the mechanisms underlying this condition is limited. Our objective is to improve our mechanistic understanding of COPD and lung function abnormalities seen in persons with HIV infection that would lead to a future study that tests new treatments for this important and growing clinical problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative It has been well-documented that Black adults experience greater sleep difficulty and duration compared to White adults. Work-related stress, with its robust link to sleep deficiencies, may be a critical, but overlooked source of these racial inequalities in sleep. Through our proposed research, we will examine numerous types of work-related stress in relation to sleep and also clarify the possible biological link responsible for the impact that stress has on sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Numerous recent studies have consistently shown that likely no two cells in the human body have the same genomes, a phenomenon called somatic mosaicism. Mosaicism can be studied using various approaches, but the study of mutations directly in the cell promises a comprehensive characterization of mosaicism in any tissue. However, all existing methods have significant limitations for studying the genome in a cell. Here we propose to develop and test a hybrid approach, which allows comprehensive and accurate analysis of the cell’s genomes in various tissues of the human body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative. In the United States, ~5% of the population have an alcohol-use disorder and alcohol mis- use is the third leading preventable cause of death. The exploration of how a neuron-specific, nonnuclear NFkB mediates alcohol responses needs to be explored because it provides a novel way for neuroimmune signaling to mediate the response of the nervous system to alcohol. Furthermore, understanding how an NF- kB could directly modulate synaptic activity may also contribute to our understanding of the origins of the un- usual consequences of neuroimmune dysregulation such as impaired brain function, the exacerbation or cause of mental illnesses, and neurologic complications of Covid-19 disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE In this application, we propose a critical development of a duplex-seq-based single-cell whole- genome sequencing method that will achieve high accuracy and high coverage in detecting somatic mutations in single cells and the corresponding dual-omics chemistry that allows simultaneous transcriptome profiling and accurate detection of somatic mutations of single cells. To meet the goal of large-scale profiling of somatic mosaicism set by the SMaHT program, we will also develop a high-throughput platform for this chemistry with the innovative picoinjection system. The large-scale single-cell dual omics profiling of both genome and transcriptome will allow us to effectively construct the lineage tree of single cells, leading to the large-scale characterization of different branches/clones in normal tissues and the phenotypical difference between the different branches/clones, and the associated somatic mutations that drive these differences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reactive species from lipid peroxidation generated under disease conditions damage DNA and form etheno lesions, which are strongly cytotoxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic. This project will characterize the repair of these etheno adducts by enzymes across two distinct pathways: base excision repair and direct reversal repair. Results will identify the differential repair fingerprints of such lesions and inform future translational studies that capitalize on these repair mechanisms to protect against genomic instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project narrative: Neuromesodermal progenitors are an undifferentiated vertebrate embryonic cell type that generates spinal cord, skeletal muscle, and other mesodermal cell types. This proposal will use zebrafish embryos to identify mechanisms of canonical Wnt signaling and Sox2 interactions, and to understand how cell cycle phase impacts normal cell fate and cell behavior. Our results will further develop knowledge of NMP biology to aid in their use in regenerative medicine and reveal broadly conserved signaling and cell biological mechanisms important for understanding cancer and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: The NCATS KL2 career development programs are foundational to developing the next generation of clinical and translational researchers and ensuring that they achieve career success and research independence. The University of Cincinnati Center for Clinical and Translational Science and Training has a strong record of accomplishment in training KL2 Scholars: of the 20 graduates, 95% are still conducting clinical and translational research, 100% have served as Principal Investigator or Co-Investigator of an externally-funded grant, and the sum of direct costs generated by Scholars’ grants I $109,286,934. We propose to 1) train the next generation of clinical and translational investigators through mentored research experiences, core methods and skills development, and tailored experiential learning opportunities; 2) develop engaged, diverse junior investigators who have sustainable translational research careers; and 3) promote the translation of Scholar research into improved health outcomes across the lifespan, through innovative training strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Wildland fire disasters raged throughout the western US in recent years, continuing a trend for increasing frequency and severity of such events driven by climate change. Our recent studies with naturally-occurring wildland fire smoke (WFS) exposures from the California October 2020 wildfires demonstrate clear neuroinflammatory outcomes in otherwise healthy mice. In the present renewal proposal, we will utilize precise, laboratory-based exposure systems to address pulmonary and neuroinflammatory risks of wood smoke from metals-contaminated biomass obtained from these regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic mutations accumulate in every cell of our bodies throughout our lives, but before mutations become permanent in both strands of a DNA molecule, they begin as mutation or damage to just one of the two strands. This study will develop a new technology to detect for the first time many kinds of mutations and damage to just one of the two strands of DNA. This will help us understand the first step of the mutation process, why mutations occur differently in different parts of the body, and factors that affect how our DNA mutates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to Public Health This grant proposal will develop a robust and comprehensive analysis of the expression status of a previously undefined mitochondrial lipid kinase, AGK, in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) which we have detected recently in CLL cells however; functional implication of this aberrantly expressed lipid kinase in CLL oncogenesis remains unknown. The proposed studies are dedicated in novel and important directions: 1) to establish if aberrant expression of AGK in CLL cells represents high-risk CLL patients' cohort for aggressive disease and/or predicts time to therapy; 2) delineate the mechanism of AGK upregulation in CLL cells; 3) define the function of AGK in CLL cell survival and therapeutic outcome of the patients and finally, 4) assess the feasibility of targeting aberrantly expressed AGK to induce apoptosis in vitro in leukemic B-cells from previously untreated CLL patients, and in vivo in a CLL-specific established mouse model. In total, the information gained on the aberrantly upregulated AGK in CLL cells in relation to disease progression and our goal on developing increasing rationale for the use of AGK-inhibitor alone or in combination with the current targeted therapies for CLL has great potential to impact and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Memory impairment is a core deficit accompanying many neurological disorders. This proposal will examine how a simple nervous system encodes model-based memories constructed on inferred values (sensory preconditioning). These experiments will add to the knowledge base required for the rational design of treatment for memory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This grant is aimed at understanding how cells adjust their growth in response to mechanical forces. This is an important question because the cellular response to force is altered in numerous diseases, ranging from cancer to fibrosis to cardiovascular disease. Deciphering the pathways by which cells respond to mechanical forces may thus reveal new targets for future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loneliness affects a large proportion of older adults and has been linked with increased risk for dementia, particularly Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed project will examine the directionality of relationships between loneliness and cognitive function and investigate biological mechanisms linking loneliness with cognitive decline. The findings will clarify the role of loneliness as a risk factor for future cognitive decline or an indicator of cognitive dysfunction prior to the onset of dementia, supporting the development of early detection and dementia risk reduction strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed randomized trial is relevant to public health, because incorporating hypnosedation (HS) during breast cancer surgery provided by a clinical team member will allow patients to avoid general anesthesia. Not only do we expect HS to improve patient reported outcomes (pain, anxiety, nausea, fatigue, and satisfaction), we also expect that replacing general anesthesia with HS will lead to less use of opioids during and after surgery, fewer physiological perturbations during surgery, and faster postoperative recovery. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to addressing the opioid epidemic and understanding the bidirectional relationship between psychological and physiological responses to cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a highly efficacious, user-controlled, evidence-based HIV prevention option, which has not been rolled out for key populations in India. The present study will provide crucial information about how to engage and retain highly stigmatized populations in PrEP care in India by testing the acceptability, feasibility, and sustainability of an adapted WHO E-PrEP Implementation Tool. The findings from this implementation science study will aid in the scale-up of sustainable interventions to reduce HIV disparities among stigmatized groups across India.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although proteasome inhibitors are currently used in the clinic against Multiple myeloma, this approach alone is insufficient for sustaining long-term remission in patients. DDI2 protease plays a major role in cancer cell survival during proteasome inhibition therapy. This proposal aims to identify inhibitors of DDI2 protease that can be used to increase the efficacy of proteasome inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapies are emerging as a curative therapy for some patients with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL); however for the more than 60% of patients who do not have a complete response survival is measured in months. Recently, we identified the cell surface lymphotoxin beta receptor (LTBR) as a positive T-cell regulator that enhances CD19 CAR T-cell efficacy in vitro and in vivo; here, we will comprehensively explore LTBR as a T-cell activating strategy to maximize the intrinsic anti-tumor activity of CAR T-cells in relapsed or refractory (R/R) DLBCL. Our findings will inform the clinical development of next-generation CAR therapies with enhanced clinical efficacy for R/R DLBCL and possibly other diverse tumor types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bile duct cancers (also termed cholangiocarcinomas; CCA) are usually diagnosed at advanced stages and have poor survival. There is evidence that a portion of the risk for CCA is inherited. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a strong risk factor for development of CCA, but most patients with CCA do not have PSC. We aim to identify genetic variations that explain individual susceptibility to CCA in the presence and absence of PSC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is no effective antiviral drug to treat acute hepatitis A. Despite an effective vaccine, hepatitis A virus (HAV) still causes thousands of hospitalizations and many deaths each year in the United States alone. It is a much more serious problem in the developing countries, and it is also an agent of bioterror concern. However, there is currently no effective antivirals to treat severe HAV infections. A drug called DHQ was under development for hepatitis B and also has activity against HAV but had neurotoxicity in culture and long-term animal studies. Harlingene Life Sciences has modified this drug to be hepatoselective (HS) and is developing it for HAV. HS-DHQ would be the first and only HAV antiviral drug to mitigate liver injury in acute hepatitis A.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Spermatogonial stem cells support male gamete production for the reproductive lifetime of the individual and are required for the continuation of our species. Disruption of stem cell self-renewal can cause cancer and infertility. A better understanding of the regulation of the fate of these cells will enhance our knowledge of male infertility and may lead to the development of a male contraceptive. Fertility preservation in young cancer patients is also dependent on spermatogonial stem cells and future regenerative medicine strategies may use the unique developmental potential of these cells for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Young-adult men who have sex with men (YMSM) are likely to turn to the Internet to seek information about pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a highly effective treatment for preventing HIV infection. This investigation will use qualitative and quantitative methods to test promising health communication messaging strategies most likely to enhance Black, Hispanic, and non-Hispanic White YMSM's engagement with online content about injectable and oral PrEP. Findings from this research will inform the design of health communication campaigns to better engage YMSM's attention—a necessary first step toward promoting PrEP uptake and ultimately reducing HIV infection rates among YMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hereditary TTR amyloidosis (hATTR) is a debilitating disease that predominantly affects African American and Hispanic/Latino patients in the U.S., and often escapes diagnosis until symptoms of late-stage heart failure appear. Because new treatments have emerged to delay progression, it is increasingly important to recognize early clinical features of hATTR, in order to hasten diagnoses and improve outcomes. We will take a genetics- first approach to comprehensively study multi-systemic features and cardiac imaging findings in African American and Hispanic/Latino patients at high genetic risk for hATTR, to improve knowledge of disease presentation and penetrance, and to inform strategies for cardiac surveillance and earlier clinical diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We identified differences in tumor genomics and the status the tumor microenvironment in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) between Black and White patients. We propose to evaluate drug combinations that reprogram tumor cell metabolism and induce change in the tumor microenvironment, which when coupled with immune checkpoint blockade will help to overcome the survival disparities for Black patients. Results from the proposed research will inform future studies and provide a potential direction for investigator-initiated clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic itch severely diminishes quality of life. However, the neurons that mediate itch in the dorsal root ganglia and dorsal horn have never been observed at a population level. Our proposal will address this issue by providing a network view of how itch input is initially integrated and where KOR agonists act to inhibit this circuitry. These efforts will provide key insight into the neural coding of itch, and may elucidate new avenues for treatment.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human brain learns in real-world circumstances by parsing experiences into events, but the neural interactions supporting this function are poorly understood. We will use short films to test memory function while recording from key memory regions in surgical epilepsy patients, then test our findings by using electrical stimulation. The gained knowledge will provide an important translational advance and accelerate new approaches to the diagnosis and management of memory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Just like human cells, bacteria are susceptible to fatal viral infections. Recently there has been increasing excitement about the possibility of using bacterial viruses (called bacteriophages) for therapies to treat bacterial infections as bacteriophages are harmless to human cells. In this proposal, three researchers with complementary expertise join to uncover novel mechanisms by which bacteria fight off bacteriophage infections, with the goal of “helping” the bacteriophages to kill the bacteria more effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Perinatal mood disorders (PMDs) are the most common health complication from pregnancy, and though treatable, most mothers with PMD symptoms never receive diagnosis or treatment. In this SBIR, BetterHope LLC (dba Poisera) will develop a mobile health app to longitudinally monitor perinatal mental health to improve detection and delivery of treatment for PMDs. The Poisera app will identify and treat PMD at earliest onset for 750,000-800,000 women each year to avoid long-term adverse health outcomes for both mother and child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic skin disease marked by allergic inflammation and itch, and is increasingly common among children and adults in the United States. We and others have found that the cytokine IL-18 is dysregulated in human AD, along with IL-18-responsive basophils and group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s). In this proposal, we investigate the role of IL-18 in mediating ILC2 and basophil responses in AD and AD-like skin disease, in order to advance our mechanistic understanding of AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Incarcerated individuals have higher rates of chronic disease than the general population, including more hypertension, diabetes, high cholesterol, and obesity. The Chronic Disease Self-Management Program (CDSMP) is an evidence-based disease management program that has been utilized in state corrections systems on a limited basis; however, there has been little deliberate research investigation into efficient and effective strategies for scaling up the intervention among older adults within state corrections systems. The research objective of this K01 is to use mixed methods research approaches to engage community-agency CDSMP leaders, correctional staff, and incarcerated individuals in developing strategies to maximize the scalability of the Chronic Disease Self-Management Program among older adults within a state correctional system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Using a unique rat intrauterine e-cigarette exposure model coupled with cutting-edge genomic and epigenomic approaches including the spatial genomics and single-cell sequencing technologies, this project will determine the genomic and epigenomic mechanisms underlying prenatal e-cigarette caused abnormal brain development in the offspring. A large amount of genomic and epigenomic data will be produced, including whole genome sequencing, DNA methylomes, ATAC-seq chromatin accessibility, RNA-seq transcriptomes, and single-nucleus RNA-seq/ATAC-seq, which will provide valuable new insights into the effects of e-cigarette on early central nervous system development, and help explore promising molecular and cellular therapeutic targets for treating e-cigarette vaping-induced brain damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main aim of this project is to uncover roles of circular RNAs (circRNAs) in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). To do so, we will utilize established Drosophila models of the disease in combination with our collection of 110 strains that will allow us to determine comprehensively whether circRNAs can alter the development or progression of pathology in the AD models. Identifying roles of circRNAs in AD has obvious implications for human health, especially given the incidence of AD and other neurodegenerative disorders in the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The female sex bias in Alzheimer’s Disease incidence is well documented, yet the biological basis for this sex difference is unknown. We have identified estrogen-mediated changes in microRNA expression, a non-coding RNA, that are dependent on age and length of time post-menopause, and these E2-regulated microRNAs are critical regulators of cognition and memory. This proposal will investigate how estrogens regulate microRNAs in the female brain across the lifespan and determine if this process is dysregulated in Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative A common cause of inherited hearing loss – which directly impacts >30 million people and has no cure – is the disruption of cochlear hair cell stereocilia, which are essential for transducing sound vibrations to the brain. This proposal combines advanced genetic tools, high-resolution imaging, and hearing assays to elucidate the basic cell biological mechanisms of stereocilia length regulation and determine the critical window for restoring hair cell function in vivo. Finally, this study will investigate the potential for partial reprogramming technology to expand or reopen this critical window for restoring hearing and cochlear function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance We propose to study the novel humanized mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease we created which allows, for the first time, studies of disease progression in the face of HIV- 1 infection and antiretroviral therapy. The model now enables studies of immune cell subsets and novel therapies that enables the simultaneous suppression of viral growth while clearing plaques and tangles that affect AD progression. This research builds on groundbreaking work that served to define the mechanism(s) of viral persistence in the central nervous system, deliver medicines to sites of viral growth, and most importantly determine how specific CD4+ T cell subsets can affect the tempo of disease and secondly provide immune based disease to combat progressive viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social factors contribute to substance use disorders (SUDs), but the molecular mechanisms which support this relationship are unclear. Adolescent drug use is a risk factor for SUDs later in life, but also causes social dysfunction. In this proposal, we will examine how adolescent drug exposure impacts social development in sex- specific ways, and in turn social influence over drug-associated reward learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: High blood pressure or hypertension is a common and potent cardiovascular risk factor. Hypertensive heart disease refers to unfavorable enlargement, stiffening and weakening of the hearts of hypertensive patients that increase the risk of developing heart failure. This research examines how changes in microtubular structures within heart muscle cells contribute to these structural and functional abnormalities in order to develop new treatments to prevent and treat hypertensive heart disease and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia in the elderly. This project will perform innovative research to study AD risk factor SORL1 and discover new molecular mechanisms involved in AD pathogenesis. The knowledge gained from the proposed research will provide fundamental information needed for development of new therapeutics for treating AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Quantitation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) mutant huntingtin (HTT) is being used in HTT lowering clinical trials as a target engagement biomarker, but we lack the understanding of CSF mutant HTT required to interpret this data in a meaningful way. This study will determine the source and mechanism(s) of mutant HTT entry to CSF in order to better understand what treatment-induced changes mean and assess longitudinal changes in CSF HTT in individuals to correlate to clinical signs and aid in trial participant selection. The results of this study will enable substantive use of CSF HTT quantitation as a biomarker of HTT lowering and Huntington disease onset and/or progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disrupted organ size control mechanisms underlie a multitude of birth defects, deficient tissue repair, and cancer. The proposed research studies cellular and molecular processes that perfectly restore size and scale during an astonishing example of innate vertebrate organ regeneration. As such, the project will uncover conceptual and specific mechanisms that may be disrupted in human disease while also guiding novel regenerative medicine approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An overwhelming number of Americans require immune suppression of variable duration at some point in their lives due to various diseases from asthma to HIV to rheumatologic diseases to organ transplant - during the time at which their immune system is being suppressed these individuals are at great risk for developing an opportunistic viral infection that can be caused by many different types of viruses. Standard of care therapeutic interventions for these patients are restricted by highly focused targeting of only select viruses and the emergence of drug resistant strains. Successful completion of this application will result in a clinically ready, orally taken, antiviral drug that 1) provides protection against highly diverse viruses and 2) limits the acquisition of drug resistance.
