IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Somatic mutations, those that exists in a subset of cells in the body, impact numerous neurologic disorders. However, because of the difficulty in identifying rare mutations accurately, we do not know the extent to which somatic mutations affect the brain. This proposal applies innovative technology to find somatic mutations that cause epilepsy and brain malformations and makes estimates of the degree to which normal brain development is impacted by somatic mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: PACIFIC INSTITUTE FOR RES AND EVALUATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 and necessitated state Medicaid telehealth policies impacting alcohol and substance use disorder treatment delivery provide an opportunity to use varying policy interventions across all states as a natural experiment to investigate the impact of telehealth service expansion on AUD and SUD service utilization. The proposed study aims to evaluate state Medicaid telehealth policies on AUD and SUD treatment use of medically underserved Federally Qualified Health Centers patient populations. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIAAA and NIDA's goals to improve existing behavioral treatments for alcohol and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ultimate goal of this work is to discover candidate medications and develop new molecular tools to study the dopamine D4 receptor (D4R) and its variants, the more common D4.4R variant, and the ADHD- and substance use disorder-associated D4.7R minor variant. Developing new molecular tools to elucidate the role of D4R variant signaling through the discovery of D4.4R- and D4.7R-selective compounds can untangle the important signaling effects of this receptor and identify potential targets for medications development for ADHD and substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Errors in the process of distributing chromosomes to the gametes, are the major cause of spontaneous abortions and birth defects and are an important contributor to infertility. This project uses a novel technology based on lacO/lacR (Operator/Repressor) and combines genetic and cellular approaches to unravel the mechanisms of double-strand break repair and by which the homologous chromosomes find each other and establish permanent connections, all of which is of paramount importance in preventing the chromosome segregation errors that lead to birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to Public Health Statement Heart failure is projected to affect more than 8-million American adults by 2030 and is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. Physical activity improves outcomes for patients with heart failure, although most heart failure patients rarely participate in enough physical activity. This research will use mobile technology to characterize real-time factors such as symptoms, mood, and motivation that impact physical activity for heart failure patients, and then use that information to adapt and pilot a mobile health intervention to support heart failure patients in being more physically active.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, around 60% of patients present with cardiac defects, largely due to a deletion that includes TBX1; this provides a unique population in which to investigate possible genetic modifiers of heart development. Our lab performed whole genome sequence analysis on human subjects and discovered a subset of chromatin regulatory genes associated with heart defects in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. This study aims to determine the mechanism by which Tbx1 interacts with these chromatin regulatory genes, particularly Kmt2c and Kmt2d, in mouse heart development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Most patients with diabetic eye disease – one of the most common causes of severe vision loss in working-age Americans – respond inadequately to current therapies. Moreover, aside from tight control of serum glucose, little else can be offered to patients to help prevent the development of early stages – or progression to late stages – of diabetic rertinopahy, highlighting the need to examine new molecular targets for its treatment. To expose novel therapeutic targets for the early treatment and/or prevention of this vision-threatening disease, we propose to interrogate the molecular basis whereby hypoxia inducible factor (HIF) accumulation in response to glucose dysregulation promotes progression of early diabetic eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Anthracycline-based chemotherapeutics such as doxorubicin are among the most effective and widely prescribed anticancer agents, but their clinical use is associated with dose-limiting damage to the heart muscle (cardiotoxicity). Using unique genetic mouse models, we found that acute and chronic forms of cardiotoxicity caused by doxorubicin are dependent on an uptake process in the heart that is mediated by the transporter OCT3. The proposed studies are a logical continuation of our prior NCI-funded studies and will directly test the hypothesis that targeted interference of OCT3 with pharmacological inhibitors can mitigate the incidence and severity of this debilitating side effect without affecting the agent’s anticancer properties.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Marital conflict is linked to a wide range of severe adjustment problems in both children and adults, so a critical need exists to identify mechanisms of constructive prevention and intervention through multi-method, process- oriented analyses. The goal of this research is to test the hypothesis that empathic communication and perceived understanding are key mechanisms that help explain how an RCT intervention improved short-term conflict resolution and long-term emotional security and relational satisfaction within families. This project has the potential to advance understanding of how constructive family conflict behavior is causally linked to relational family outcomes, and it may therefore inform the design of more effective family interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative Implants based on neuroelectronic interfaces, which are central to the treatment of many neurological diseases or injuries and can be used to record and/or stimulate neural activity, are quickly becoming the fastest growing sector of biomedical devices. Despite significant initial successes, various challenges exist with the development and translation of neuroelectronic interfaces for some clinical indications. The proposed conference will support the ability of the international community to come together in partnership to develop multidisciplinary solutions that benefit society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The relationship between alcohol use and aggression is widely recognized, however treatments for alcohol use disorders rarely focus on treating aggression. As people with both alcohol use and aggression problems may have unique treatment needs including more focus on aggression problems and their relationship to alcohol use, we propose to develop and test a treatment that integrates existing effective treatment for these two problems. Our goal is to learn (1) how acceptable and realistic this integrated treatment would be to administer to patients, and (2) how impactful the treatment would potentially be in reducing drinking and aggression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruptions in branched-chain amino acid metabolism have been recently implicated in the pathogenesis of multiple neurodegenerative disorders. This project aims to reveal if loss of branched-chain amino acid transaminase-1 (BCAT1) is sufficient to induce neurodegeneration and elucidate how alterations in metabolic homeostasis drive disease progression. Insights from this work will aid the discovery of novel neurodegenerative pathways and further the development of more targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The microbiome and the gut-brain axis has been demonstrated to mediate the symptoms and progression of a wide variety of neurological disease1-6. While the role of the gut-microbiota-T-cell-brain axis in the context of specific neurological diseases has been studied, its role at steady-state and scope of neuroimmune interactions between microbiota-educated-T cells and microglia is not known. It is essential to understand the steady-state gut-brain T cell axis in order to fully understand the molecular mechanisms behind neurological disease to develop better targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptor (AMPAR), a subtype of the ionotropic glutamate receptor (iGluR), is a ligand-gated ion channel that mediates fast neurotransmission in the central nervous system. It plays a critical role in learning and memory, and its dysregulation is implicated in neurological conditions like epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed research will elucidate high-resolution three-dimensional structures of AMPARs, reveal molecular basis of their functional assembly and regulation as well as guide in the rational design of therapeutics targeting iGluRs in disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research contributes to public health by investigating the ways in which culture impacts memory and brain activity. Cross-cultural comparisons are needed to have accurate understanding of how memory works and whether strategies are equally effective across groups. Understanding cultural differences in the use of memory strategies can inform the development of effective interventions to maintain memory function with aging and Alzheimer's disease, to improve cognition in diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most aggressive type of malignant primary brain tumor and accounts for the majority of deaths among brain tumor patients due to its highly invasive nature and lack of therapeutics that efficiently target invasion. This proposed study will use recently developed spatial single cell RNA-sequencing and spatial Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin (ATAC)-sequencing on GBM tumor samples to provide a comprehensive understanding of the genetic and epigenetic regulators of driving GBM invasion, that will serve as novel targets to evaluate the potential of invasion-targeting therapy. Findings from this study will elucidate a comprehensive analysis of genetic and epigenetic regulators of GBM invasion, mechanistic insight through chromatin accessibility and interactions with the tumor microenvironment, and evaluate the therapeutic potential and mechanistic impact of invasion therapy which ultimately may inform future therapeutic modalities and improve clinical outcome for patients with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative We will elucidate the most fundamental event in hearing: the conversion of a sound-induced mechanical stimulus into an electrical signal by the receptor cells of the inner ear. We will use a combination of biochemical, physiological and computational methods to understand how the mechanical stimulus is transferred from linking proteins, PCDH15 or LHFPL5, to an ion channel protein, TMC1, and to understand how the stimulus opens the ion channel in order to generate the electrical signal. This work will produce a fundamental understanding of one form of mechanosensation which can be applied to others such as touch, and will reveal mechanisms of pathophysiology caused by deafness-causing mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the associated improvements in cardiometabolic and physiological health, intentional weight loss for obese older adults can exacerbate age-related declines in musculoskeletal health and increase fracture risk, leading many to consider alternative therapeutic approaches. This F31 Independent Predoctoral Fellowship Award will develop an automated computational pipeline to assess muscle health in older adults undergoing weight loss via caloric restriction and randomized to perform no additional lifestyle intervention, participate in supervised resistance training, or wear an incrementally-weighted vest. The results of this study will improve our understanding of muscle-bone interactions and elucidate the mechanism by which weight loss increases age- related declines, providing evidence to support and guide clinical therapeutics for weight loss that can preserve musculoskeletal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Splicing factor gene mutations are prevalent in blood disorders and induce widespread, recurrent alternative splicing events. We propose a novel approach of targeting these mutations via antigen-based immunotherapies, based on the hypothesis that mis-spliced mRNAs give rise to meaningful tumor antigens. The proposed research will (1) contribute to the understanding of mis-spliced mRNAs as immunotherapeutic targets and (2) inspire T-cell receptor therapies for myelodysplastic syndromes and immunoprevention strategies for clonal hematopoiesis with spliceosomal mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is driven by an autoimmune attack against myelin in the Central Nervous System, though the etiology of this disease remains unclear. Enteric Glial Cells (EGCs) are potential autoimmune targets in MS as they express several myelin proteins which are known targets in MS patients. In this proposal, I aim to characterize T cell responses targeting EGCs in an animal model of MS and investigate how depleting EGCs impacts disease severity, providing insights into how the Enteric Nervous System may be implicated in MS etiology and pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Comedones are an exceedingly common dermatologic problem across the lifespan. Rare comedonal diseases such as nevus comedonicus and common comedonal diseases such as epidermal inclusion cysts have been connected via mutations in the same gene, NEK9, a gene associated with ciliary dysfunction. This project serves to relate the NEK9 gene, ciliary function, and comedogenesis together to better understand the formation of comedones during development and adulthood and use our findings to inform better treatment of both rare and common comedonal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is an age-related neurodegenerative disease affecting millions of people worldwide for which limited therapeutics are currently available to slow or halt disease onset or progression. The studies outlined in this proposal will elucidate the role of microglial protein quality control in the context of AD pathogenesis. This will both advance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the progression of diverse neurodegenerative proteinopathies, and identify potential targets for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic events can lead to major muscle loss that exceeds the body’s natural ability to heal. While materials derived from biological tissues can engage the immune system to promote regeneration of muscle in these traumatic wounds, aging causes dysregulation of these responses. Our strategy utilizes pre-existing T-cell immunity generated by past infections as the basis of a strategy to enhance the material-induced immune response and promote greater muscle recovery in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is a deadly disease with the majority of these deaths attributable to Plasmodium falciparum infection, complicated by a lack of natural sterilizing immunity in humans and current vaccines with modest and strain- specific efficacy. Using samples from a cohort in a low transmission setting in Senegal, we will seek to understand the kinetics and dynamics of functional immune responses to merozoite antigens that provide broad protection against multiple strains. The proposed project will aid current vaccine efforts by identifying broadly functionally protective immune responses with consideration to antibody characteristics and natural parasite diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Spasticity is a condition that manifests after spinal cord injury and causes severe difficulties in the daily lives of patients. While there are pharmacological treatments available to treat spasticity, they have significant side effects, including a decrease in spinal excitability, which further diminish motor recovery. This project will investigate if epidural stimulation can be used as a treatment to alleviate spasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease is the most prevalent form of late-onset dementia, but patients with presenilin-1 mutations can develop early-onset dementia in their 40s. A patient with a mutation in APOE3 (APOE3cc) didn’t develop dementia until her 70s, despite having a presenilin-1 mutation. This project will dissect the cell type-specific molecular mechanisms governing the neuroprotective effect regulated by the APOE3cc mutation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Gender disparities in mental health are stark—relative to men, women consistently report higher rates of anxiety and depression, as well as lower levels of self-esteem—and emerge by adolescence. To date, research on these gender differences has focused largely on the role of biological factors linked to sex (e.g., hormonal differences). The current research will pursue a more complete understanding of how gender disparities in mental health emerge by examining adolescents who vary both in assigned sex and gender identity (i.e., cisgender and transgender youth): in doing so, this project will clarify the role of gender identity in predicting gender disparities in mental health and reveal the psychological variables related to gender (e.g., attributes, behaviors, and experiences common in men vs. women) that account for such disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During developmental refinement of synaptic connections in the visual thalamus, astrocytes wrap around clusters of synapses. In this pilot proposal, we will examine the role of this astrocytic wrapping in the process of synapse elimination and strengthening. Additionally, we will test whether the astrocytic wrapping acts to increase the concentration of neurotransmitters around the synaptic clusters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Through hypothalamic and extrahypothalamic nodes, stress imparts flexibility to an organism's ability to maintain long-term weight homeostasis (WH). This application will explore the role of the neurons expressing Corticotrophin Releasing Factor Receptor 1 (CRFR1) neurons in the Bed Nucleus of Stria Terminalis (BNSTCRFR1) in modifying WH. These studies will mechanistically explore the neural basis through which stress alters WH, and in the long-term, spur development of novel therapeutics that prevent or mollify stress-related disturbances in WH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Natural product-based drugs are the cornerstone of drugs available on the market today. Genome mining and microbial engineering have consistently been efficacious tools for natural product dug discovery and development. Current advances in molecular genetics, such as fast, accurate, and affordable sequencing technologies, enable us to further tap into the potential of microbial natural products for drug discovery. These technological advances leave room for significant advancement in microbial production and engineering. Currently, there is a bottleneck in natural product drug discovery brought on by a shortage of well-studied bacterial hosts available for heterologous expression of unexplored gene clusters. The lack of diverse and well- studied host strains results in minimal yield production platforms, which limit the ability to utilize microbes for natural product drug discovery and development. The research outlined in this proposal aims to test and develop a Burkholderia bacterial host from strain FERM BP-3421, a strain proven capable of producing medicinally relevant compounds in gram per liter scale. Development of this Burkholderia strain increases the diversity of well-studied host strains available to the scientific community. Furthermore, the proposed testing of the Burkholderia host will result in the immediate production of natural products that have potential as drug leads.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project adds four additional waves of survey and two waves of time diary data to the NICHD-supported National Couples’ Health and Time Study (NCHAT), which is the only population-representative, multi-method study of American couples that includes fully-powered samples of racially and ethnically diverse and sexual and gender diverse individuals collected during the COVID-19 pandemic and the co-occurring period of intense racial trauma. These longitudinal data, which will be made publicly available, and the current and future analyses are essential to identify the risk and resilience factors associated with the long-term impacts of discrimination and COVID stress on mental health and family functioning among the most marginalized Americans. This project will identify mental health adaptations to the pandemic and racial injustice and produce policy-relevant recommendations to promote improved well-being during periods of uncertainty and stress.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health as it develops and establishes alternative splicing as a powerful and viable method to control regulation of gene therapies. Current gene therapies do not take advantage of this ubiquitous regulatory mechanism, and we propose to use it to achieve tissue-specific and self-regulatory control over AAV-delivered cargoes. Findings from this study will constitute new compositions and guiding principles for the development of gene therapy cargoes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteroides species are prevalent and abundant in the human intestinal microbiota providing the host with numerous properties essential for health. In this proposal, we will examine new pathways and factors that these bacteria use to generate energy and their contribution to human health and disease prevention. These studies will ultimately support the design of better probiotic formulations and inform about factors important in the restoration of a healthy gut community to various patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Current therapeutics for atherosclerosis fail to consider the role of inflammation and lymphatic system function, both of which have the potential to promote plaque stability. Through preliminary in vitro and in vivo models, we found that IL-19, an endogenous anti-inflammatory cytokine, induces the formation of functional lymphatic vessels by modifying their permeability, which has the potential to increase both white blood cell egression and reverse cholesterol transport. This grant will explore the mechanism of action behind IL-19’s effect on lymphatic system function in the setting of hypercholesterolemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A robust immune response to intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is well documented but the B cell response in the post-ICH brain remains poorly understood. This grant proposes a thorough characterization of the B cell response to ICH over time, with particular emphasis on understanding the phenotype and function of brain- infiltrating IgA+ B cells. This work will therefore have important implications for our understanding of the adaptive immune response to brain injury and may guide therapeutics targeting post-ICH inflammation-induced damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Sensing of the mechanical stiffness of embryos and similarly small tissues is extremely important in fields such as developmental biology and cancer biology. However, many important questions are unanswered due to the fact that the available instrumentation for measuring at such small scales is table-mounted and is very limited in its range and direction of motion, such that it can only perform sensing on tissue of a certain regular shape or on flat, horizontal surfaces. This project will develop a new type of stiffness-sensing instrument that combines the large range of motion of the human hand with the accuracy of microrobotics in order to produce an instrument that shares the strengths of both, and therefore is capable of sensing in ways that other instruments cannot.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study builds and deploys a tablet-based system for collecting information about infant and toddler attention patterns associated with autism. We use this system in two groups of 2-year-old toddlers with and without autism who we follow up with at 3-years (one group in lab, the other remote), and also collect data from a large community sample of 3- to 36-months old infants to help establish developmental baselines. The goals of this study are to: (1) accelerate research methods for large scale collection of mobile device eye-tracking data; (2) use these methods to better understand unique qualities of autistic attention; and (3) to use that understanding to better characterize individual attention profiles with the goal of advancing personalized medicine in toddlers with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circuit dysfunction is a phenotype in early-stage Alzheimer’s disease (AD), yet the interaction between circuit dysfunction and the emergence of classic AD pathology remains unclear. This proposal will investigate how the emergence of pathological tau is related to cell-type-specific mechanisms of circuit dysfunction in a model of early AD. Ultimately, this proposal aims to address neuron- and circuit-level excitability changes in early AD, and establish a cell-type-specific mechanism causally linked to pathological tau progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is characterized by progressive deterioration of the aortic wall and catastrophic aortic failure resulting in sudden death in >80% of acute ruptures leading to the death of ~30,000 Americans and ~500,000 people worldwide. Unfortunately, there are no pharmacological treatments available for the prevention of AAA progression and rupture and the only option for these patients is surgical intervention. Our proposal seeks to investigate the mechanisms by which trimethylamine N-oxide (TMAO) activation of its putative binding target protein kinase R (PKR)-like endoplasmic reticulum kinase (PERK) contributes to vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) dysfunction and subsequent initiation and progression of AAA to elucidate novel therapeutic targets for this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is an often-lethal inflammatory myeloid neoplasia that arises due to mutations (most commonly in the protein BRAF) that persistently activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway in myeloid lineage cells, which alters their physiology leading to accumulation of LCH cells in tissues and reshaping of the tissue microenvironment. Current treatment strategies, which include chemotherapy or inhibitors of MAPK signaling have significant toxic side-effects and do not eliminate LCH cell precursors leading to recurrent disease and deleterious life-long complications. Recent studies from our lab have identified that the epigenetic protein HDAC3 modulates many facets of myeloid cell biology, including development, making it a promising therapeutic target that may provide persistent disease remission for patients with LCH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide fundamental insight into how decision-making emerges from various cell types and different subregions of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, a brain area that is frequently impaired in psychiatric and neurological disorders. Our results will be invaluable for better understanding how neural activity in this clinically relevant brain region leads to cognition. These insights, when combined with precise techniques to perturb neurons and networks are essential for the development of circuit level therapeutics for psychiatric and movement disorders, and the next generation of brain machine interfaces used for recovery of function following brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive T cell transfer therapy is a promising approach to treat aggressive solid tumors; however, many patients still do not respond. We discovered that a CD4+ T helper subset, termed Th17 cells, regresses large melanoma tumors when infused into mice and this immunity is partially dependent upon host B cells. Our mechanistic studies, aimed to understand the relationship between infused Th17 cells and host B cells, will allow us to harness these pathways to elicit robust anti-tumor immune responses in patients in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) induced diarrhea and colitis represents a significant clinical problem, affects up to 40% of immunotherapy patients. Our proposal aims to characterize immune subsets driving ICI-induced colon inflammation and target these populations using drugs that may be advanced to human trials after evaluation in a novel model of concurrent colitis and malignancy. We expect our research to identify and advance rational targeted therapies modulating immune cells in ICI-colitis, ultimately leading to improved treatment regimens to mitigate ICI-colitis while preserving ICI-mediated anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE We previously discovered that a large insertion in intron 32 of TAF1 is functionally associated with intron retention and alternative splicing in the disease X-linked dystonia parkinsonism (XDP) and that there are protein aggregates in XDP postmortem brain. In this renewal, we will determine whether these signatures can be ameliorated by treating with antisense oligonucleotides, including if the treatment has an impact on the clearance of protein aggregates from cultures of neurons and glia. This endeavor will clarify the disease mechanism and inform future genetic therapy for XDP and many other neurodegenerative diseases with which XDP has commonalities, such as Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson’s Disease, and Huntington’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor is a negative regulator of cellular proliferation that is inactivated through phosphorylation by the cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 (Cdk4/6). Very little is known about additional mechanisms that inactivate Rb and therefore dictate its functional properties. This project will investigate how the ubiquitin-mediated degradation of Rb controls normal cell cycle progression and therapeutic response to Cdk4/6 inhibitors in the context of breast cancer, and my findings will broaden our overall understanding of how Rb’s tumor suppressive functions are regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel drugs for the treatment of tuberculosis that are capable of shortening treatment duration, treating drug- resistant infection, and preventing the rise of further resistance are urgently needed. Our proposed research will harness Mycobacterium tuberculosis amidases to activate amide prodrugs, thereby identifying prodrugs that are activated by several amidases and yielding novel, pyrazinoic acid-releasing amides that can restore pyrazinamide-like activity in pyrazinamide-resistant strains. In doing so, this work will demonstrate a novel approach to drug discovery that enables the design of prodrugs that can treat drug-resistant disease and have extremely high barriers to resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Although Clostridioides difficile is an important human pathogen, relatively little is known about how basic transcription processes regulate virulence and pathogenesis. This research will determine how Rho and Nus factors dependent termination regulates C. difficile virulence, sporulation, and pathogenesis. The results will expand our understanding of the diverse functions of these well-conserved bacterial transcription elongation and termination factors and potentially reveal new avenues for the development of C. difficile treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Early pregnancy loss can be a devastating outcome for people with the ability to become pregnant, and nearly two-thirds of all losses occur prior to and around the time of implantation. Extrapolation of data from animal models of implantation is challenging at this stage owing to the lack of knowledge regarding conservation or divergence of these mechanisms across key mammalian species. Through understanding how morphogen and mechanical cues via WNT/β-catenin signaling orchestrate correct embryo development at this period across species, we will be able to confidently extrapolate data from animal models towards human health applications to better understand the root causes of pregnancy loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of early-onset CRC has been increasing at an alarming rate. Concurrently, younger populations experience circadian clock disruption through exposure to light-at-night and erratic sleep/wake and feeding/fasting patterns. The goal of this proposal is to define the complex connection between circadian clock disruption, immunity and CRC pathogenesis which will provide critical evidence for CRC prevention and treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOBEC3 enzymes play a crucial role in several biological events in relation to innate and adaptive immune responses. The studies outlined in this proposal will identify the source of APOBEC3 induced mutagenesis in urothelial carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence and disease severity of human coronaviruses range greatly, from the highly infectious SARS-CoV-2 to the endemic common cold coronaviruses 229E and NL63. A deeper understanding of the functions and mechanisms of the major pathogenicity factor Nsp1 could help explain these differences in disease severity among coronavirus genera. Additionally, the results will provide insight into the evolution of Nsp1 among coronaviruses, inform targets for specific Nsp1-based therapeutics, and lay groundwork for treating future coronavirus strains that present a real and repeatable threat to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related cognitive decline impacts a majority of the world’s population. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides an innovative approach for mechanistically linking systems-level neural activity to age-related cognitive decline. By understanding the basic principles of neurobiological organization that affect cognition across the aging brain, it will be possible to promote the development of interventions that broadly improve cognition in normal aging and Alzheimer’s disease and meet a mission of the NIA to advance our understanding of age-related cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cortical hyperexcitability is an early phenotype of the devastating neurodegenerative disease Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) which presents across patients of heterogenous genetic backgrounds. The proposed research will determine the effects of cortical hyperexcitability on cell types in the spinal cord key to this disease’s pathology: motor neurons, interneurons, and astrocytes. These experiments are expected to reveal the consequences of early cellular dysfunction in ALS in human cells, ultimately leading the way towards identifying therapeutic targets and thereby furthering the missions of the NIH and NINDS to use fundamental knowledge about the nervous system to reduce the burden of neurological disease for all people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Norepinephrine (NE) neurons in the locus coeruleus (LC) project widely throughout the central nervous system, playing critical roles in arousal and mood as well as various components of cognition including attention, learning and memory. LC-NE neurons are highly susceptible to degeneration in age-related neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Here, we define the molecular impacts of neuromelanin and AD-related pathology on local gene expression in the human LC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to learn to recognize the category, or behavioral significance, of visual stimuli is essential for planning and carrying out successful behaviors in response to our surroundings. This project develops novel behavioral tasks and neuronal population recording approaches for studying the brain basis of rapid reward- based visual category learning during naturalistic foraging paradigm. The work will provide a detailed and mechanistic understanding about how encoding in and interactions between multiple interconnected brain areas mediate rapid learning and decision making, which is critical for understanding and ultimately addressing the profound deficits of learning, memory and decision making that frequently accompany brain diseases and conditions such as stroke, schizophrenia and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that poses a serious health threat to individuals that are immunocompromised or those with cystic fibrosis. In addition, a rise in antibiotic resistance among P. aeruginosa infections makes them particularly difficult to treat. This study is focused on understanding how the P. aeruginosa outer membrane, which serves as a barrier for toxic molecules like antibiotics, is both built and maintained.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The peripheral immune system has recently emerged as a potential driver of age-related cognitive impairments and neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease, with a prominent role posited for CD8+ T cells. Correspondingly, the research described in this proposal aims to investigate the role of circulating aged CD8+ T cells and their secreted factors in driving hippocampal-dependent cognitive decline during aging. Completion of this work will further the understanding of how age-associated changes in the peripheral immune system impact the brain and ultimately identify potential therapeutic candidates to alleviate age-associated impairments in cognition and susceptibility to neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Public Health relevance. Advancement in the understanding of molecular mechanisms of the inner ear is a prerequisite to developing therapeutic strategies for hearing impairment. The studies outlined in this proposal seek to understand the general function of a calcium binding protein known as CIB2 and its associated pathophysiology due to mutations of CIB2 encoding this protein. Thus the proposed research is developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burden of human hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper salivary gland functioning is critical for oral health. Sjögren’s Disease, an autoimmune condition that mainly occurs in women, causes salivary gland hypofunction and leads to severe dryness of the oral cavity. This project proposes to apply a novel therapeutic approach involving the specialized pro-resolving mediator aspirin- triggered resolvin D1 together with dexamethasone to promote resolution of inflammation and restore secretory function in salivary glands.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nucleolar stress response (NSR) functions to maintain cellular homeostasis when the cell is faced with stress or suboptimal growth conditions. This research proposal will investigate how this stress response is regulated by and how it might impact viral replication of Merkel Cell Polyomavirus, a human tumor virus that causes a highly fatal skin cancer called Merkel Cell Carcinoma (MCC). Such work will advance our understanding of the role of the NSR during viral infections, an area which has not been well described, and identify potential therapeutic targets to prevent the onset of MCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this application we address the overall hypothesis that a novel population of T cells expressing a protein on their surface termed “CD26” are ideal template to modify and use as a cell therapy for pancreatic cancer. Using a series of experimental models, we will study how the unique properties of these cells allow them to work when administered on their own, and together with other more conventional T cells that are engineered to recognize, mesothelin, a marker present on pancreatic cancer cells. Our team will next conduct a first in human clinical trial in patients with pancreatic cancer to ensure these cells are safe and obtain tumor biopsies and blood samples to understand their fate in pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii chronically infects one quarter of the world’s population, and its reactivation can cause debilitating and life-threatening disease. Key to T. gondii’s pathogenesis is its ability to enter a reversible, semi- quiescent chronic stage that is resistant to clearance by the host immune response and all existing pharmacotherapies. This proposal will investigate how the T. gondii chronic-stage developmental program is initiated and, later, overturned during reactivation, providing new molecular insights to inform the design of novel therapies for toxoplasmosis directed at a radical cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Internal tandem duplications (ITD) of Fms-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) is a common driver mutation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and confers a poor prognosis for patients with AML, yet inhibitors of FLT3-ITD signaling are rarely curative. The proposed research will utilize single cell chromatin accessibility sequencing, high- resolution epigenetic profiling, functional genetic technologies, and drug sensitivity assays to investigate the epigenetic regulators of the MYC proto-oncogene, a key downstream target of FLT3-ITD signaling that enables uncontrolled leukemic proliferation, at the MYC blood-specific super-enhancer complex. Determination and validation of the regulatory factors of the MYC super-enhancer complex in FLT3-ITD AML will contribute to our understanding of leukemogenesis with the potential to uncover therapeutic targets aimed at the molecular mediators of FLT-ITD signaling.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Defects in the Hedgehog signaling pathway underlie a vast spectrum of human birth defects, including ciliopathies, holoprosencephaly, cleft palate, and a variety of limb defects such as polydactyly. This proposal seeks to fill a fundamental gap in our understanding of Hedgehog signaling regulates gene expression through the GLI proteins. It will determine how the activity of GLI proteins is regulated to repress the expression of HH target genes and which other proteins are required for this activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer's disease (AD) affects millions of people worldwide, currently has no cure, and is projected to drastically grow in numbers in the coming years. The Octodon degus provides a potential paradigm shift in the predominantly transgenic mouse-dominated AD animal model field, as it is a long-lived rodent that naturally manifests many of the AD-like features seen in human AD. The proposed behavioral, neuropathological, cytoarchitectural, and single-cell spatial transcriptomic characterization of the Octodon degu's relevance to AD can lead to invaluable insights into AD pathogenesis and the discovery of novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how phenotypic diversity arises in both adaptive and pathological states is a fundamental goal of biological research. For decades, the blind cavefish, Astyanax mexicanus, and its conspecific surface-dwelling relatives, have been important systems for addressing how naturally occurring genetic variation influences phenotypic differences. This application will support and ensure diversity at the 8th biennial Astyanax International Meeting, which has been the premiere conference where groups utilizing this model and other non-traditional aquatic systems can gather, discuss the latest research and discuss how to advance the model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stereochemistry is the crux of modern organic chemistry; therefore, direct synthetic method to access desired stereoisomer is highly sought after from fundamental organic synthesis to medicinal chemistry perspective. This proposed research describes a novel application of enantioselective photoredox catalysis to achieve stereochemical editing of quaternary stereocenters that is not established with current methods. Ultimately, the results of this proposed research will provide valuable tools to efficiently prepare small molecule drugs and their derivatives, and enhance the productivity of pharmaceutical research to advance human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Transgender male patients (i.e., assigned female at birth and identifying as male) who undergo gender affirming surgery while on masculinizing testosterone replacement therapy have been reported to have worse scarring and wound healing outcomes compared to those not on testosterone at the time of surgery. Using a variety of cutting-edge techniques, this research will investigate the biological mechanisms responsible for this phenomenon, leading to improved understanding of wound biology and the potential to rewrite perioperative guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Targeted focal resection of prostate cancer has the potential to eliminate the many complications associated with whole-gland removal, but usually cannot even be attempted, because cancerous tissue looks the same as healthy tissue in endoscope images. Fortunately, cancerous tissue is accurately identiﬁable in high-ﬁeld MR images, which opens the door to precise and accurate focal resections using a new kind of surgical robot capable of delivering two needle-sized instruments through a standard transurethral endoscope. By combining this new robot with a single-sided low-ﬁeld MRI scanner that can accurately guide the instruments to lesions identiﬁed in registered high-ﬁeld MR images, we will create a system with the potential to enable targeted, personalized, focal resections for patients who today have no alternative to radical prostatectomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed project is to investigate the regulation of the muscleblind gene, a splicing regulator responsible for Myotonic Dystrophy. In particular we will focus on the role of recently discovered new types of molecules: circular RNAs (circRNA), which we showed in the previous period of the grant has multiple functions in the muscle and brain. The present proposal will uncover the mechanism of action of these molecules; therefore, this project will unravel key regulatory mechanisms of a disease-linked gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Response to and recovery from mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is complex, reflecting the interaction of multiple biological, psychological, social, and environmental factors. Ultimately, accurate prognosis and the development of new effective treatments will require the identification of these factors and an elucidation of their mechanistic effects. Based on extensive preliminary data, this application proposes to test the hypothesis that a common herpesvirus, cytomegalovirus (CMV), is an overlooked but treatable source of adverse mTBI outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone morphogenic proteins (BMPs) represent a major developmental signaling pathway, with mutations in different pathway component genes resulting in developmental abnormalities. Understanding how each component of this pathway contributes to signaling is vital as minor changes in signal levels are sufficient to prevent healthy biological outcomes. This proposal will expand our current understanding of how BMP signaling is regulated at the receptor level, identifying key functional differences between the receptors that we can leverage to study disease causing variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gut microbiome, which begins to develop in early life, is associated with many important physiological functions. Harmful exposures during the first year of life (e.g., heavy metals and enteropathogen exposures that are prevalent in drinking water in low-income contexts) can cause gut dysbiosis, which is associated with many adverse health outcomes. This project will investigate if and how improvements to drinking water quality and access influence infant gut microbiome composition among children in Beira, Mozambique, which is critical to improve our understanding of the association between drinking water quality and access on both acute and chronic sequelae related to gut dysbiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intrinsic (or mitochondrially mediated) apoptosis pathway is a fundamental cell death pathway that helps maintain tissue homeostasis and prevent neoplastic transformation. High grade serous ovarian carcinoma (HGSOC), the deadliest and most common subtype of ovarian cancer, is found to have dysregulated expression of the BCL-2 family proteins that control the intrinsic apoptosis pathway, which supports HGSOC tumor cell survival. Thus, we propose to investigate the origins of this apoptotic dysregulation and therapeutically target these proteins to increase tumor cell death and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulatory T cells (Tregs) are a specialized subset of T cells, regulated by the transcription factor FOXP3, that control peripheral tolerance. A failure in their ability to control self-reactive T cells in the periphery leads to autoimmunity, causing immunopathology and tissue dysfunction. We have discovered a novel mechanism for Treg-mediated suppression, and the studies in this proposal will provide mechanistic insights into this process and provide important data for the potential identification of new therapeutic pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: PIEZO2 channels are necessary for sensing inflammation induced mechanical pain affecting millions of Americans each year causing substantial economic and emotional burdens. Identifying robust and selective inhibitory mechanisms of PIEZO2 contributes to an emerging field of mechanosensation which has recently been recognized by the Nobel Prize. We propose an intensive inquiry into the robust, selective inhibition of PIEZO2 channels by a possible lipid modifying enzyme (TMEM120A) contributing to a growing body of evidence implicating lipids as key modulators of mechanosensation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolism is a highly regulated process that has a strong influence on many diseases including, cancer, diabetes, and age-related neurodegenerative disorders. Our lab recently discovered a mitochondrial remodeling mechanism called the mitochondrial-derived compartment (MDC) pathway that is responsive to metabolic disruptions in both amino and carbon-sources. New insights into this evolutionary conserved pathway gleaned from the proposed studies will provide further understanding of how mitochondria remodel during metabolic transitions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Robust daily rhythms of physiology and behavior are hallmarks of healthspan and contribute to longevity. This project aims to understand the molecular mechanisms by which metabolic signals from daily feeding-fasting cycles interact with environmental time cues to regulate temporal changes in physiology over the 24-hour day-night cycle. Our findings will shed light on the impact of disrupting metabolic regulation of daily biology rhythms, e.g. in situation of mistimed feeding, and pave the way to identification and characterization of new therapeutic targets for circadian and metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The increasing prevalence of multifocal cerebral microhemorrhages (also known as “cerebral microbleeds) is a significant problem in the aging population, which progressively impair neuronal function and contribute to cognitive decline and gait disorders.Our hypothesis is that aging-induced accumulation of senescent endothelial cells in the cerebral microcirculation is responsible for a pro- fragility microvascular phenotype: senescent cells release activated matrix proteinases and other paracrine factors ("senescence-associated secretory phenotype" or SASP), which promote structural maladaptation to high pressure, degradation of collagen and remodeling of extracellular matrix, thus creating loci of least resistance that can easily burst upon induction of hypertension. Using an approach that combines neuroanatomical analysis, innovative imaging techniques, and integrative cerebrovascular physiology, we will be able to test novel, translationally relevant interventional strategies, senolytics, for prevention of CMHs and protecting cerebral function in the elderly as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The first wave of thymocyte differentiation in the fetal thymus proceeds rapidly and gives rise to specific lineages of innate lymphocytes and innate-like T cells that are not generated by any subsequent wave of development. Based on my preliminary data, I hypothesize that these populations arise from a dedicated precursor cell in the fetal thymus that is using a unique differentiation program. In this proposal, I aim to test test this hypothesis through fate mapping and perturbation studies to construct a full lineage hierarchy of fetal thymocyte differentiation and the gene regulatory networks that govern it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study has considerable relevance for public health as it will elucidate the neurophysiological mechanisms that cause individuals with substance use disorder and trauma-related disorder comorbidity to have poor adherence to treatment and high relapse rates and accordingly, it may ultimately aid in the development of effective therapies. This project aims to elucidate the effects of fear conditioning and cocaine exposure on prelimbic cortex modulation of nucleus accumbens core neurons, concerning drug-seeking behavior in a rat model. Understanding how trauma-related disorders and SUD comorbidity alters the communication within this circuitry may provide the basis for developing new pharmacological interventions that could reduce cocaine relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Obesity is an epidemic in the United States that has led to a great increase in obesity-driven metabolic disorders, including Type 2 diabetes, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Despite the high incidence of these diseases, therapeutic strategies to treat obesity-driven conditions remain limited. This project will define the potential of pharmacological activation of protective unfolded protein response signaling pathways to promote adaptive remodeling of metabolic tissues, including liver, and alleviate tissue- specific metabolic alterations present in these disorders, and thus informing on translational strategies to intervene in these metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Presbyopia corrections so far have not addressed the causative nature of loss of accommodation, and major barriers to innovation result from the need to measure biomechanics in vivo. The goal of this project is to characterize the spatially-varying biomechanical signature of the lens by developing an in vivo measurement of mechanics. Results from this study will provide a method to monitor and plan novel presbyopia treatments that target biomechanics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory feedback is critical for effective interaction with the world, requiring neural circuit mechanisms for dynamically adjusting how sensory signals are transmitted as conditions and contexts change. This proposal aims to define how connections between the central amygdala, a structure involved in processing internal states of stress and fear, and the cuneate nucleus, which transmits tactile information, are involved in adjusting the strength of sensory signaling on short time scales as well as following stressful experiences such as chronic isolation. Identifying the neural mechanisms by which social isolation modulates the processing of sensory feedback will help to clarify how chronically altered internal states affect the nervous system and lay the foundation for improved diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertonic exposure causes cell shrinkage and is thought to induce in vivo protein misfolding and aggregation, which are hallmarks for aging, cancer, and neurodegeneration. However, no studies have determined which endogenous proteins are compromised by hypertonicity, and little is known about the mechanisms that maintain proteome integrity during osmotic stress. The experiments proposed here will characterize the protein quality consequences and responses to hypertonic exposure, identifying determining factors for protein aggregation, refolding, and degradation that may inspire therapeutic strategies for protein-misfolding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exploring and adopting innovative health delivery approaches such as telehealth to prevent and manage cardiometabolic risks (CMR) is essential to reducing the burden of CMR diseases and associated risks (e.g., cognitive decline and dementia) among the U.S. aging population. Through this proposed research and training plan, the applicant will use a rigorous econometrics approach to evaluate the effects of state-level payment parity requiring equal reimbursement for in-person and telehealth visits on health service utilization in the U.S. health system, and to assess how telehealth affects health behavior (medication adherence) and disease-specific quality of care for middle-aged and older adults aged 45 or above. Therefore, this project contributes to NIA’s mission to prioritize life-course prevention and intervention efforts for chronic, multi-factorial, and age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) is found in most human genes, but its role in gene expression is not well understood. Our research using the model organism C. elegans aims to reveal how dsRNA interacts with diverse proteins to shed light on diseases associated with dsRNA, such as autoimmune disorders, cancers, and neurological conditions like epilepsy and Alzheimer's. This knowledge could ultimately contribute to the development of novel therapeutic strategies to combat these illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The nervous system of the heart plays a key role in the development and progression of heart failure and occurrence of dangerous heart rhythms, such as ventricular arrhythmias, that lead to sudden death. Differences exist in both occurrence and outcomes of ventricular arrhythmias in men vs. women, yet the mechanism behind these differences remain unknown. The current proposal is aimed at identifying sex-specific remodeling in the heart and its nervous system after cardiac injury and associated hormonal factors that may play a role in this remodeling, in order to provide important mechanistic insights as to the observed differences in occurrence of sudden death and progression of heart failure in males vs. females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke is the leading cause of disability in adults in the U.S., and there is no treatment that promotes recovery. The proposed predoctoral NRSA aims to examine innate cellular responses to a potential stroke therapeutic, a biocompatible hydrogel scaffold that establishes a unique neurovascular niche after stroke. This study will assess in vivo revascularization of the stroke infarct in mice, vascular-guided cellular migration, and axonal sprouting in the gel, infarct and peri-infarct with and without physical rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pathogenic bacterium Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, a devastating diarrheal disease that affects millions of people worldwide each year. Several life-saving oral cholera vaccines (OCV) have been developed, but they show varying efficacy in different geographical regions and from individual to individual. The proposed studies will identify how differences in the composition of the native microbial community of the gut, the gut microbiome, contributes to differences in response to oral cholera vaccines, and identify candidate next- generation probiotic and prebiotic approaches targeting the gut microbiome to improve strategies for cholera prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a serious lung condition with high morbidity and mortality rates, making it a significant public health concern. The human lung maintains airspace fluid by balancing leak with fluid removal, however, claudin organization due to chronic alcohol abuse disrupts this balance by increasing leak and when paired with ARDS leads to catastrophic lung flooding. This project aims to target lung cell junctions as an approach to ameliorate lung leakage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The largest remaining mystery in the genomic era is assigning precise function and biophysical parameters to the vast number of regulatory sequences that govern gene expression. Connecting these features to complex cellular behavior would accelerate our ability to predict phenotypic outcomes from DNA sequence alone, potentially enabling treatment options for patients with disease causing mutations found within enhancers. By combining a high-throughput temporally-resolved screen and cutting-edge DNA loci tracking combined with transcriptional imaging all within a developmentally relevant in vitro differentiation system, we will radically redefine our understanding of how enhancers activate their target genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social hierarchies, which are comprised of lower-ranking subordinate individuals and higher-ranking dominant individuals, are essential for maintaining stability in humans and other species; however, the neural and molecular mechanisms that regulate a subordinate social rank and its associated behaviors are unclear. The proposed research will use state-of-the-art tools in gene sequencing and genome editing to identify the genes and cell types in the brain that govern subordinate social status and assess the roles of androgens and serotonin in regulating subordinate behavior in an African cichlid fish Astatotilapia burtoni. Given that all vertebrates have androgens, serotonin, and similar genes that regulate behavior, this work will elucidate basic biobehavioral and genetic mechanisms underlying subordination that can be further explored in other animals, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Violence towards others and suicide are typically studied as phenomena present in discrete groups; however, self/other-directed harm co-occurs to yield a higher risk of premature death34 and represents an understudied health crisis occurring in a uniquely vulnerable and often violence-exposed group.27,28,35-37 Despite decades of research we are still unable to reliably (1) identify this group on a large scale and (2) conceptualize the function of these symptoms to guide effective and scalable treatment planning. This study directly addresses these gaps by using a multidisciplinary, mixed-methods approach to help describe possible functions of self/other-directed harm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment of pain remains a major unmet need. Opiates continue to be useful pharmacotherapy for treatment of moderate to chronic pain but suffer from severe side effects, leads to initiation of opioid use disorders (OUD) and has led to an epidemic in America. The development of safe, effective and well tolerated pain medications without side-effects based on allosteric targets and/or distinct G-protein signaling within the mu opioid receptor will be a major advancement in the treatment of pain as well as OUD that would greatly enhance both quality and length of life of patients both in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Neurotransmitter:sodium symporters (NSS), the target of therapeutic and illicit drugs, share a common structural core, e.g., the LeuT fold, with secondary transporters that mediate concentrative substrate symport and/or antiport. By targeting archetypes of LeuT-fold proteins the goal of this grant proposal is to identify the binding sites and permeation pathways of substrates, ions, and drugs within the transporters and the elucidation of the conformational dynamics associated with the different modes of transport, with special emphasis on how psychoactive drugs modulate the activity of the human serotonin transporter (hSERT) at the molecular level. Building on powerful approaches established in the associated labs will allow implementing a new paradigm for illuminating drug action and providing guidelines for improved therapy design.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION

PHR: ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT APPLICATION AND JUSTIFICATION FOR  MFRPS MAINTENANCE FUNDS PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cooperative Agreement is to provide funding for the ADPH state manufactured foods program to maintain conformance with the most current version of FDA’s Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS) national standards. It will provide adequate staffing, with funding for travel and other requirements as needed, to review and inspect each food manufacturing firm in Alabama jointly with the county Public Health Environmental staff, coordinating enforcement. By having adequate specialized staff, ADPH will be able to work toward maintaining conformance with the MFRPS National Standards and participate in the national integrated food safety system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The hippocampus is traditionally considered a brain region for memory, but emerging findings suggest that it may play a role in key aspects of vision. This proposal investigates the original hypothesis that the unique ability of the hippocampus to differentiate related visual stimuli may bias the allocation of object-based and feature- based attention. If confirmed, this would impact our understanding of the brain systems that control attention, reveal candidate neural sources of attention deficits in visual and other disorders, and suggest learning protocols that may have potential for rehabilitating central visual processing through hippocampal plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The experiments outlined here will identify the mechanisms by which two similar rhodopsin mutations, G90D and G90V, cause visual impairment using G90D and G90V knockin mice that we have generated. This proposal will seek to provide full structural and functional photoreceptor analysis of these animals, determine the molecular mechanism by which these rhodopsin mutations cause night blindness and retinal degeneration, and develop therapeutic approaches for reversing their effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traditional postmortem imaging of the brain continues to be very qualitative and is limited by the slow “one-at- a-time” approach. Using imaging mass cytometry (IMC), a recently developed quantitative multiplexed approach to image > 45 markers of interest, we will define the spatial signatures of the aged and Alzheimer’s (AD) brain, with particular emphasis on deriving information on microglia function and activity, in space and over time. By also developing the bioinformatics pipelines needed to evaluate brain microenvironments, our study could translate clinically towards better diagnostic and predictive capabilities for patients with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common inherited cardiac disorder. Cardiac fibrosis is a key determinant of adverse outcomes in HCM, yet there are no therapeutics that prevent fibrosis or attenuate established fibrosis. Serotonin-2B (5-HT2B) receptor expression is significantly increased in HCM patients and has demonstrated anti-fibrotic effects in several cardiopulmonary diseases; eliminating 5-HT2B activity is a novel therapeutic approach to reduce fibrosis in HCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Mycobacterial pathogens are agents of deadly infectious disease, including tuberculosis (TB). A strategy for new anti-TB drugs may include targeting K+ channel proteins, which can control key metabolic pathways in mycobacteria. In this work we solve the structure of a mycobacterial K+ channel and identify its role in controlling energy metabolism, contributing to the ultimate goal of developing improved treatments to fight TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ectopic centromere formation on chromosomes is associated with developmental disorders and genome instability in cancer. The goal of these proposed studies is to determine how DNA structure plays a role in centromere formation at specific loci that lack conserved DNA sequence motifs to facilitate chromosome segregation. Characterizing the mechanisms of centromere localization will contribute to our understanding of how ectopic centromeres form and how they impact human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis-induced acute lung injury (ALI) and acute respiratory distress syndrome remains an intractable disease with a mortality rate as high as 40%. ALI/ARDS bears the hallmark of inflammatory infiltration and protein-rich edema fluid due to severe disruption of lung vascular endothelial barrier. The central objective of the proposed studies is to delineate the cellular mechanisms of endothelial regeneration and vascular repair, and thereby provide novel therapeutic strategy targeting the intrinsic regenerative and reparative mechanisms for resolution of inflammatory lung injury to prevent and treat ALI/ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic/Latino populations carry a disproportionate burden of poor cardiometabolic health outcomes, with higher rates of obesity, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia than non-Hispanic White populations, but limited research has investigated how immigration status as a social and economic stressor contributes to disparities in cardiometabolic health and epigenetic aging across the life course among this population. This proposed research project will evaluate differences in cardiovascular disease risk factor profiles by immigration status and will estimate the associations between immigration status, accelerated epigenetic aging, and cardiometabolic health over the life course among Hispanic/Latino adults and adolescents in the United States. We anticipate the impact of this work to significantly advance our understanding of racial/ethnic disparities in cardiometabolic health and aging among Hispanic/Latino populations and to ultimately inform future cardiovascular public health interventions tailored to this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While vascular leak is a deadly complication of malaria, the mechanism underlying its development is poorly understood. The goal of this proposed study is to identify how platelet degranulation promotes vascular leak by driving endothelial glycocalyx breakdown and CD8 T cell activation/recruitment to the lung during severe malaria. This work is relevant to the NIH mission to develop fundamental knowledge that reduces human disease burden by defining a mechanistic pathway that could be targeted by novel adjunct therapies to disrupt the development of vascular leak in malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy dysfunction is broadly implicated in promoting diseases ranging from neurodegeneration to aging to cancer. The fundamental autophagy protein ATG3 plays an understudied role in regulating mitochondria and endosomes, and dysregulation of these organelles are also linked to neurologic diseases. Here, I explore the cell biological consequences of a mutation to ATG3 that drives neurological disease, as well as the greater cellular consequences of these non-canonical ATG3 activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The importance of developing novel antimalarials for use in the prevention and treatment of malaria is highlighted by the emerging resistance to frontline therapeutics. Further development of historically active 4-aminoquinoline analogs has immense therapeutic potential and clinical relevance. Successful completion of this proposal will result in the advancement of a novel 4-aminoquinoline scaffold with multi-drug resistant antiplasmodial activity and an increased understanding of its molecular antiplasmodial mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Capillary malformation, one of the common vascular malformations, is comprised of enlarged and destabilized capillaries. CM is caused by a somatic mutation in the gene GNAQ; the mutation changes the arginine (R) at amino acid position 183 to glutamine (Q), which is enriched in endothelial cells found in CM specimens. The proposed study seeks to understand the R183Q point mutation in the endothelial cells and how it affects interaction with surrounding mural cells in the CM using both in vitro and in vivo experiments.

PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is a common, life-altering condition, as one in ten people will experience at least one seizure in their lifetime. Completion of the proposed research will advance our understanding of the neural circuit mechanisms underlying seizure susceptibility in a mouse model of Angelman syndrome, a severe neurodevelopmental disorder in which refractory epilepsy is common. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States and about 875,000 Americans die from heart disease each year, of which 50-60% deaths are caused by coronary artery disease which can further develop into heart failure and scarring. We discovered a lung stem cell-derived exosome product and its cargo microRNAs that play an essential role in cardiac repair. In this grant proposal we will study the safety, efficacy, and mechanism of exosome inhalation therapy to treat ischemic heart diseases in both small and large animal models.
