IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The significant impact of olfactory disorders on safety, health and quality of life makes rapid and efficient diagnosis of anosmia and related disorders paramount. However, to effectively differentiate pathophysiological changes in olfactory function from fluctuations within a normal range, it is imperative to understand how a given individual's ability to smell can vary from day to day or across months or years. The intensive longitudinal assessments proposed here will provide an essential resource for physicians, researchers and the public to better understand how olfactory function varies across time and under different physiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While histone proteins are critical for packaging DNA and regulating gene expression within the cell nucleus, small changes that occur due to missense mutations in genes encoding these histones can convert them into disease-causing variants. The proposed investigations use two complementary approaches, combining rapid discovery in budding yeast with extension of these findings into human cells. These studies allow us to use disease-causing histone variants to unravel cellular pathways and functional connections fundamental to maintaining proper gene expression and protecting genome integrity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The overarching goal for this project is to understand the events governing the earliest stages of mammalian embryo development; how the specialized cells that will comprise the embryo and its extra-embryonic support tissues arise. We will use the mouse as an experimentally tractable animal model system to generate foundational knowledge for extending our understanding of early embryo development to other mammalian species, provide knowledge on the origin of birth defects, and the in vitro stem cell populations than can be derived from early mammalian embryos which are increasingly used to generate embryo-like models (also referred to as synthetic embryos), and to generate cells with distinct identities having therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate tertiary sulci — the smallest and latest-developing cortical indentations — in aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). While large-scale atrophy patterns in aging and AD are established, fundamental mechanisms underlying individual differences in regional vulnerability and associations between AD pathology and degeneration have not been fully ascertained, and sulcal anatomy has been proposed as an avenue to explore these individual structural differences. This study will probe whether tertiary sulci can serve as structural markers of early degenerative and pathological changes, providing insight into relationships between atrophy, pathology, and cognitive changes in the aging brain from a novel anatomical resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Millions of people globally contract the diarrheal pathogen V. cholerae annually. Susceptibility to V. cholerae is mediated in part by resident gut microbes. The function and diversity of these microbial communities are in turn determined by viruses (bacteriophages). These studies will evaluate the contribution of a bacteriophage to alter microbial metabolisms that can alter V. cholerae infection, facilitating the development of new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults have increased rates of infections and cancers due to declining immune function, which is likely due to alterations in T cell progenitors and inflammatory signaling pathways in the aged microenvironment. We will investigate the causes of T cell decline with age using a newly described mutant mouse model and a novel, in vitro Artificial Thymic Organoid system, which reproducibly produces all stages of T cell development from a single stem cell. Our proposed studies will provide insights into the aging immune system and inform future therapies for regenerative medicine and age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug tolerance, a non-heritable, reversible state of slow growth which enhances survival to antibiotic treatment, is a major barrier to successfully treating Tuberculosis (TB), which remains the public health challenge of our time. This study will identify unique drug targets in a clinically significant, drug tolerant Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) strain lacking a key glycerol kinase (glpK), by assessing the role of lipid metabolism and host macrophage phenotypes on drug tolerance under biologically relevant conditions. This innovative project has the potential to greatly shorten the length of antibiotic regimens, reducing relapse as well as TB mortality by producing highly translatable data that will unlock impactful new treatments against a clinically significant strain of Mtb.

PHR: Project narrative: Currently there are no disease modifying therapies available for Parkinson's disease, in part because we still do not understand the exact biological mechanisms governing dopamine neuron susceptibility to death. Cell stress responses are implicated as one potential driver or contributor in Parkinson's disease. This proposal aims to elucidate the exact role of a specific stress response pathway throughout the course of disease to determine its role in Parkinson's pathophysiology, as well as, its potential as a therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Re-activation and integration of transposable elements (TEs) into a new genomic site can introduce mutations to regulatory or protein coding regions, which has been implicated in a variety of gastrointestinal (GI) diseases such as Crohn’s, colitis, Lynch syndrome, and cancer. However, the reasons for the increased activity of these elements in the GI epithelium still unclear. Our study has the potential to elucidate a previously underappreciated link between normal tissue architecture and transposon regulation, which may be critical for our understanding of the loss of epithelial integrity in GI diseases and could lead to the future development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal uses genetics and molecular biology tools to define the mechanisms directing local translation to plasma membranes. Impaired local translation in neurons and other cell types causes disease but studying mRNA localization in those contexts can be challenging. This project will achieve our long-term goal of understanding how local translation at membranes occurs by leveraging a tractable model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The environmental contribution to neurodegenerative diseases has been suggested from epidemiological studies, however, a comprehensive understanding of environmental agents that increase disease susceptibility remains a major unresolved question in the field. A toxicant screen coupled to high-content imaging has identified a set of environmental agents as putative triggers that drive TDP-43 dysfunction, a hallmark of neurodegeneration. This study will shed light on the identity, mode of action, perturbed signaling pathways, and the pathophysiological impact of these factors, with major implications towards disease prevention and mitigation strategies that alleviate cognitive and/or motor decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diclofenac is a widely used pain relief medicine, but its use has been associated with severe adverse events, including gastrointestinal ulcers, bleeding, and cardiotoxicity. This translational research project will investigate how genetic polymorphisms in an intestinal drug metabolizing enzyme, UGT2B17, and how the concomitant use of the popular natural product, curcumin, influence the large interindividual variation in the oral bioavailability of diclofenac. Results will provide critical information to both researchers and clinicians about the safe use of diclofenac with and without curcumin across populations to advance precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This work seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms of rhodopsin transport into and along the photoreceptor cilium and its loading into new outer segment disc membranes. Retinal degeneration and blindness may be caused by improper breakdown of rhodopsin delivery to new discs in the outer segments of photoreceptor, the light detecting cells in our eyes. Understanding the mechanisms by which rhodopsin is properly delivered and packed into new disc membranes will help find new therapies to extend or restore vision in patients with genetic mutations that derail this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance Narrative Deltaretroviruses are complex retroviruses, are associated with the development of lymphoid leukemias, and are notorious for being difficult to propagate in cell culture, which has prohibited rigorous analyses of virus replication, including the steps involved in retrovirus assembly. Deltaretroviruses have distinct immature and mature particle morphologies and utilize a distinct pathway for particle biogenesis. The studies proposed in this application will advance knowledge regarding the novel aspects of deltaretrovirus assembly, which will expand fundamental knowledge of retrovirus assembly and help reveal novel therapeutic targets for antiviral intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The most successful targeted therapies for RAS-driven cancers inhibit properties specific to the mutated RAS isoform or amino acid. However, little is known about the biochemical and functional differences among NRAS mutants, found commonly in melanoma, leukemia, thyroid, and colorectal cancers. This project will define the structural mechanisms that drive distinct functions among cancer-associated NRAS mutants, understand the impact of these differences on RAF inhibitor efficacy, and uncover new targets for cancer-specific drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is the most prevalent neoplastic disease of the pancreas, 15-20% of PDACs carry G12R mutations, but most preclinical animal models focus on the KrasG12D mutation, which reflects less than half of the KRAS mutations seen in human PDAC. My proposal represents a significant contribution to understanding the molecular underpinnings of disease initiation and progression of KrasG12R by testing the hypothesis that cell lineage and/or cooperating genetic events in the PI3K pathway impact the oncogenic potential of KrasG12R mutations in pancreas cancer. We anticipate that a better understanding of KrasG12R and related cellular and molecular processes will further elaborate on the KRAS heterogeneity found in PDAC, as well as provide avenues for the development of targeted therapeutics in patient populations with varying KRAS mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Intracellular bacterial pathogens remodel mammalian cell processes to replicate and cause disease. We propose to investigate how the intracellular pathogen Coxiella burnetii modulates the immune response to infection. This study will uncover fundamental details of the requirements for intracellular replication by bacterial pathogens and provide a possible therapeutic target for the treatment of these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Accessing a broad chemical space of small molecules, peptide structures, and carbohydrate analogues is crucial for drug discovery. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health as it aims to develop new synthetic methods for conducting late-stage functionalization and modification of pharmaceutically relevant molecules. By expanding the scope of available compounds and their functional groups, this research can pave the way for developing novel therapeutic agents with improved efficacy and fewer adverse effects, ultimately benefiting patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is associated with an accumulation of mitochondrial DNA mutations in human stem cells, neurons, cardiomyocytes and muscle fibers. It is thought that these mutations contribute to various age-related diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, cancer and diabetes. In this application, we propose to clear these mutations from mammalian cells in an effort to prevent age-related pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients receiving dialysis experience multiple ongoing symptoms and diminished functional status along with frequent emergency department visits and hospital admissions, which contribute to lower quality of life and significant strain and costs on the healthcare system. This study will examine how symptom severity and functional status influence healthcare use over time in patients receiving dialysis and whether social vulnerability directly and/or indirectly influences those relationships. Information gained from this study will help to identify individuals whose healthcare use is most affected by symptoms and functional status, which can be used to develop screening tools and interventions to support these individuals while improving health outcomes and reducing burden to the healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 40% of American adults are obese and due to a lack of effective and affordable treatments for weight loss, the obesity epidemic remains a public health crisis. One hypothesis about the etiology of the obesity epidemic is that obesity is associated with increased reward sensitivity, coupled with increased impulsivity which drives excessive food intake. Here, we investigate how a ventral hippocampus to nucleus accumbens shell pathway regulates impulsive responding for palatable foods in order to provide basic science insight into the etiology of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of malaria parasites in the vector is intimately linked to mosquito nutrient assimilation and reproductive physiology. The proposed research will identify microbial regulators of egg formation and Plasmodium berghei development in Anopheles stephensi and define interactions between the gut microbiota and reproductive signaling that impact parasite maturation. This work will elucidate key host-microbiota- parasite interactions that may be exploited for reducing malaria transmission in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stem cell therapy has the potential to restore degenerating tissues, but there are challenges in tracking the location and status of transplanted cells. This project aims to develop a non-invasive ultrasound-guided photoacoustic (US/PA) imaging approach for monitoring the location and differentiation of transplanted mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) into tumorigenic cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs). The technology utilizes a versatile US/PA nanosensor to label and track MSCs in order to acquire information about their functional status and improve stem cell therapy outcomes for clinically relevant scenarios.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac Ca2+ channels have a key role in excitation-contraction coupling and hormonal modulation of cardiac function. Dysregulation of basal activity and of hormonal modulation of Ca2+ channels is associated with major cardiovascular diseases, such as heart failure, hypertrophy and arrhythmias. By elucidating the mechanisms by which β-adrenergic signaling modulates heart function we seek to ultimately develop targeted and specific therapies for arrhythmias, heart failure, and other cardiovascular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Though M. tuberculosis (Mtb) is under ongoing selection to adapt to the human host environment, the contribution of Mtb genetic variation to host disease is largely unexplored beyond antibiotic resistance. Using a library of Mtb clinical isolates, we designed a high-throughput RNA-sequencing pipeline to quantify gene expression variation in bacteria and link it to genetic change. Using this method, this study will characterize how evolution tunes the Mtb transcriptional regulatory network to create adaptive change and determine if and how evolution of the key virulence pathway, ESX-1, changes host response to infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Only ~50% of patients benefit from the commonly used chemotherapy drug paclitaxel, but it has not been possible to predict which patients will respond. This project builds on preliminary evidence that pre-existing chromosomal instability (CIN) is a key determinant of paclitaxel response. Through clinical evaluation of this hypothesis, state-of-the-art measures of CIN, and consideration of an important modifier we recently identified called pole focusing, this project will provide the basic knowledge required to develop a predictive biomarker for paclitaxel and identify novel drug targets for sensitizing paclitaxel-resistant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opportunistic pathogens, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Candida spp., are growing concerns in healthcare settings due to their increasing rates of antimicrobial resistance, and are commonly co-isolated from infections. The present study aims to develop two novel treatment strategies against such coinfections, ones using antimicrobial peptides and bacteriophages, viruses that selectively infect bacteria. Not only would such treatments provide alternative approaches to combating bacterial and fungal coinfections, but their development would provide a new pipeline for treatment of additional polymicrobial infections and site-specific delivery of drug compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Since the early onset of tobacco use among Latinx adolescents in the United States is a growing public health concern, a culturally-sensitive and ecological approach to understanding Latinx adolescent tobacco use and its influences is needed. This proposed project examines the longitudinal associations between (1) cultural values and adolescent tobacco use; (2) parental monitoring, family conflict, and adolescent tobacco use; and (3) caregiver-adolescent cultural value discrepancies, family conflict, and adolescent tobacco use over time using a mixed methods approach. The findings from this study will inform the present understanding of ecological factors that promote or prevent tobacco use among Latinx adolescents and thus, have critical implications for early intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) metastasis is difficult to treat with any modern chemo- or immunotherapies, impacting CRC survival. IL27 cytokine regulates immune responses in CRC, including CRC metastasis in the liver. Here we will study microenvironmental and cell type specific mechanisms of IL27 signaling in CRC and test immunotherapies which are simultaneously aimed at neutralization of IL27 and activation of adaptive (CD8 T cells) or innate (macrophages) arms of anti-cancer immunity. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current standard of care targeted therapy options result in improved response rates and longer progression-free survival compared to traditional chemotherapy. However, the majority of responses to these treatment options are short-lived and limited by drug resistance. The main goal of this project is to establish a novel therapeutic strategy to exploit targeted therapy resistance for sensitization to the next therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to wildfire smoke is estimated to affect 25 million people in the US alone, with 33,000 deaths per year associated with wildfire smoke worldwide, largely due to pulmonary health effects. The proposed work seeks to understand the role of extracellular vesicles and the HIF-1α pathway in mediating wildfire health effects and susceptibility in the respiratory system using linked human in vitro and in vivo experimental approaches, with a focus on understanding increased susceptibility in asthmatic populations. The results of this work will help uncover mechanisms of wildfire smoke effects, ultimately contributing to efforts aimed at reducing wildfire- associated morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer patients who develop brain metastasis are faced with particularly poor clinical outcomes, including severe neuropsychiatric symptomology and low survival rates. This project will investigate how amyloid beta, a protein classically associated with Alzheimer’s disease, can be targeted to amplify anti-tumor immunity in brain metastasis. This work will serve as a foundation for the development of novel immunotherapies specific to brain metastasis, improving outcomes for a patient population with largely unmet clinical needs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Human milk fat, which provides over 50% of an infant’s energy requirement during early lactation, has an optimized composition with respect to fatty acid chain length and regiospecific distribution. The fat ingredient of infant formula, which is typically derived from vegetable oil blends, does not match the structural diversity of human milk lipids with respect to chemical composition, and hence lacks some significant nutritional benefits of human milk fat. This project aims to provide a healthy and sustainable lipid source for infant formula by engineering an oleaginous green alga for human milk fat production through a synthetic biology approach that exploits the vast knowledge base of plant and algal lipid metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  APOBEC3B (A3B) is an innate immune enzyme that functions by catalyzing cytosine-to-uracil conversions in the genomes of DNA-based viruses. A3B is the only member of a larger 7-membered family of deaminases to localize constitutively to the nucleus. This project will contribute to our understanding of DNA virus restriction by identifying the molecular mechanism of A3B nuclear import, determining the impact of this process on multiple DNA viruses, and thereby delineating new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Approximately 10% of people with cystic fibrosis (CF) are ineligible for new, life changing CFTR modulator therapy due to their specific CFTR variants, mainly due to mutations that cause premature termination codons (PTCs). CC-90009 is a thalidomide derivative drug that: 1) promotes ribosomal readthrough to rescue PTC- CFTR variants and 2) reduces epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) activity, and these two actions are both predicted to improve defective mucociliary transport in CF and other muco-obstructive lung diseases. Because reducing ENaC activity is a mutation-agnostic approach to treat CF, and because many other genetic diseases are caused by PTCs, this proposal will investigate the potentially broadly applicable mechanisms of action of CC-90009 and will test its efficacy in preclinical models of CF.

PHR: Project Narrative Cells of complex tissues have specialized functions and identities to aid in the overall homeostasis of the tissue. However, the role chromatin modifications contribute to cell-type identity and function needs to be better understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases of ineffective erythropoiesis are characterized by dysfunctional progenitor cells that lead to decreased output of functional RBCs and, consequently, anemia. The emergence of effective metabolite therapies, such as L-glutamine for sickle cell disease, highlight the potential of metabolic inputs of erythropoiesis to develop targeted therapies. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanism by which redox balance through the malate-aspartate shuttle affects red blood cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) remains one of the most infectious and deadly pathogens worldwide. Key to Mtb virulence are membrane bound and secreted effector proteins that interact with host proteins to influence the host response to infection and promote Mtb survival. We predict that the uncharacterized effector protein Rv1075c is a nucleomodulin that interacts with the Set1 methyltransferase complex to modulate the type I interferon response and promote Mtb pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is critical in preserving healthy vision, and degeneration of the RPE can lead to irreversible blindness. This project will investigate the basic biology of the RPE, its role in maintaining the health of the retina, and how essential processes are affected during aging. Understanding the molecular underpinnings of age- and disease-related changes in the RPE will inform the development of therapeutics to combat blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The microbiome is essential for immune health, but how microbes train the immune system through microbially-regulated molecules, such as serotonin, is unclear. This proposal explores how serotonin regulates intestinal immune tolerance; a pathway important for promoting commensalism and limiting inflammatory responses. Specifically, we will investigate how serotonin-inducing microbes and serotonin receptor 7 plays a role in regulating immunological tolerance in the colon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite psychoeducational efforts about the potential consequences of drug use, relapse remains the modal outcome among treatment-engaged individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD).This clinical observation indicates a need for better understanding how undesirable information about drug use is evaluated and incorporated into patient’s beliefs about personal risk. Combining neuroimaging and real-world experience sampling, I will test whether individuals with OUD hold domain-specific optimistic beliefs about drug use in a way that can uniquely inform future efforts to develop more robust psychoeducational interventions for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Phosphoethanolamine (PEA) transferases are integral membrane bacterial enzymes that modify lipid A by PEA attachment, consequently interfering with the ability of polymyxin drugs to electrostatically interact with lipid A and disrupt the outer membrane. The recent discovery of a plasmid-encoded PEA transferase, known as the first variant of mobilized colistin resistance (MCR-1), entails the potentially rapid spread of polymyxin resistance worldwide and between bacterial strains through horizontal gene transfer. This project aims to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which MCR-1 binds its donor substrate, phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), and transfers the positively charged phosphoethanolamine (PEA) intermediate to its negatively charged acceptor substrate, lipid A, on the inner membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, thereby conferring resistance to last-resort antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work proposed here, will test for the first time whether poor sleep characteristics are associated with impaired MRI markers of hypothalamic signaling, a key brain region involved in glucose homeostasis, as well as increases in glucose and metabolic risk markers in children longitudinally. This work could lead to clinical trials to test for sleep modification as an important target for prevention of obesity and diabetes during childhood. This project is strongly aligned with the mission of NIDDK to understand: (1) Energy balance and physiological mechanisms modulating weight gain, loss and maintenance, and (2) Pathways that are involved in intermediary metabolism as they impact endocrine and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Glioblastoma is a form of brain cancer with poor treatment options, an average survival time of 12-18 months post-diagnosis, and a five-year survival rate of less than 10%. Immunotherapy has shown promise for other cancer types, and we propose to design and test an innovative new immune activating RNA therapy for glioblastoma. We hypothesize that our therapy will generate a robust anti-tumor response without damaging the surrounding brain tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There an urgent need for new effective treatments to decrease the toll that alcohol use disorder takes on individuals and society. The experimental medication psilocybin has produced positive results in early-stage clinical trials using it to treat alcohol use disorder, and depression, but very little is known about how it might work to help people stop or decrease their drinking. In this study we will determine the effects of psilocybin on brain activity related to alcohol craving and negative emotion, and test whether these effects contribute to the therapeutic benefits of psilocybin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Many aspects of age-related cognitive decline, Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and its related dementia (ADRD) start several years before the full symptoms are diagnosed, however, markers to early predict them are limited. Here, we aim to establish stool and blood-based miRNA biomarkers diagnosing age-related cognitive decline and ADRD- debilitating, costly, and non-curable public health problems in older adults. The outcomes of this study will establish proof-of-concept that can be validated in large clinical studies, fulfilling the R21 application objective and perfectly aligning with the goals and mandate of NIA supported research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) remains a devastating disease with poor prognosis. This project will establish the RNA helicase DDX6 as a novel potential therapeutic target in AML by establishing it as a specific AML dependency and providing mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying this dependency. We expect that the results from our studies will guide the development of targeted, precision therapies against AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Drug associated cues are powerful drivers of craving and relapse in people with substance use disorder. Contexts that contain reward-predictive cues often contain many other cues unrelated to reward. This proposal aims to determine how neuronal activity in the nucleus accumbens contributes to the learning of and response to selective cue-reward associations in order to better understand the neural basis of healthy and disordered reward seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal expansions driven by somatic mutations arise almost ubiquitously throughout both healthy and diseased human tissues as we age. Some of these clones have been linked to chronic disease and other aging associated maladies, however, what drives clonal expansions and how they affect tissue integrity and function are not well defined. This project aims to develop and apply novel methods for the discovery of somatic mutations driving expansion in human tissue and multi -omic single-cell mapping of these driver mutation genotypes to molecular phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address inequitable allocation, the kidney allocation system was changed in early 2021, and given the complex interplay of disparities in allocation, this change may have unintended consequences for vulnerable populations. Our goal is to develop robust equity metrics to study the impact of the new allocation system, both in ensuring equitable distribution of organs to transplant centers across the US based on patient priority on the waitlist, which was the aim of the policy change, and the new policy’s impact on kidney transplant rate for vulnerable populations who have historically been disenfranchised by allocation policy. Our results will guide the development of a more equitable allocation system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While many cancer survivors will quit using tobacco after receiving a cancer diagnosis, many (13-60%) will go on to relapse due to reasons that are still not well understood. Intrapersonal factors (e.g., cancer worry, negative affect) and interpersonal factors (e.g., social support, social constraint) may play a role, but research has yet to examine their momentary or longitudinal influence on tobacco use relapse or risk of tobacco relapse among cancer survivors. This F31 NRSA award will provide the support to complete the proposed project, which aims to examine these predictors’ relation to tobacco use relapse using multiple methodologies (i.e., ecological momentary assessment, longitudinal survey), as well as provide the applicant with support to receive advanced training needed to pursue an independent research career in cancer prevention and tobacco control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Learning when rewards are not available allows for adaptive decision making, as time and energy can be redirected towards available rewards. Such learning and subsequent decision making are impaired in disease states, including substance use disorder, though the precise mechanism of this is unknown. This project will evaluate the neural systems involved in the formation of inhibitory associations and how these associations guide choice behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis, successfully evades host defenses to make it one of most infectious pathogens in the world. The goal of this project is to determine how a key innate immune regulator (TRIM14) regulates host immune responses and mitochondria homeostasis in Mtb-infected macrophages. Determining the role TRIM14 has in regulation of a macrophage’s activity during Mtb infection may lead to the identification of novel therapeutic targets to control infection in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because obesity is a major health problem in the United States and is a leading contributor to cardiovascular disease, diabetes mellitus and stroke. The expected contribution of these studies will be a better understanding of the circuitry of the Nucleus of the Solitary Tract (NTS) in the brainstem, which is essential for the control of food intake, and in particular the NPY-expressing neurons in this region. The expectation is that increasing our understanding of circuits critical for the control of food intake will help direct more targeted strategies for the prevention and alleviation of the detrimental effects of obesity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Axon pruning is a process that refines the connections between brain regions throughout development, and increasing evidence supports a failure of this process in several neurodevelopmental disorders. By inhibiting long-range developmental axonal pruning, this project will address a significant gap in understanding how aberrant connectivity emerges and contributes to the altered cortical organization and function seen in these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative CDKL5 deficiency disorder (CDD) is a rare neurodevelopmental condition associated with cortical visual impairment, neuronal hyperexcitability, and dysregulation of arousal states. Using a mouse model of CDD, I will determine the impact of CDKL5 deficiency on state-dependent thalamocortical network dynamics and identify circuit-level mechanisms underlying how loss of CDL5 contributes to altered visual sensitivity. We expect our results to provide insight into the functional consequences of CDKL5 deletion in mice, with a focus on behavioral state modulation of thalamocortical dynamics and the balance between feedforward and intracortical functional connectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic Resonance Elastography (MRE) is an in vivo technique for assessing mechanical properties of tissues such as the brain and has many potential clinical applications for the diagnosis and characterization of various aging-related dementias as it is sensitive to microstructural changes that may occur before any macroscopic structural changes occur. However, it is often difficult to implement the MRE technique in clinical and research settings to assess aging and aging-related conditions because of long acquisition times and the need for specialized equipment to cause external vibrations to pass through the brain. This project aims to improve the utility of MRE technology through the implementation of a new MRE acquisition and processing method which uses intrinsic motion of the brain from the cardiac cycle and a novel sampling technique to accelerate data acquisition and improve data quality without the need for specialized equipment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Influenza viruses infect a broad range of species including humans, pigs, domestic birds (chickens, ducks) and water fowls; these viruses infect host cells by binding to cell surface glycans, which vary among host species. Zoonotic influenza viruses capable of efficiently utilizing human glycans can cause pandemics in humans. The goal of this proposal is to identify the types of glycans necessary for influenza virus infection of different hosts and develop a technology platform that can reliably assess and identify zoonotic influenza virus strains cable of causing human infections.

PHR: Candida auris is an emerging identified fungal pathogen that is very concerning because of its resistance to multiple antifungal drugs, rendering some strains untreatable. In doing so, we will create a community resource that can be used for myriad purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The inhalation of air pollutants such as polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), black carbon (BC), and particulate matter (PM)—all compounds that can be found in restaurant kitchens—often results in adverse health effects. To investigate an occupational environment with limited toxicological exposure data in the United States, this proposed research study will chemically characterize air pollution in numerous western-style industrial kitchens and analyze factors contributing to their trends. In order to determine the extent to which this exposure results in adverse health outcomes, a risk assessment and biomarker analysis will be performed to compare the cardiopulmonary health of culinary workers to that of non- exposed workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pollen-related illnesses affect 60 million Americans and emerging evidence suggests pollen may contribute to respiratory health disparities. This research aims to understand individual and area-level factors driving pollen- related health disparities across the US, investigate the synergistic effects of pollen and air pollution, and discover potential differences in pollen exposures across Atlanta communities through the use of automated pollen sensors. Results from this work will guide clinical recommendations and targeted interventions aimed at reducing health disparities and improving health outcomes for millions of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of mitochondrial homeostasis is a major contributor to human disease. This project aims to explore the role of mitochondrial dynamics in the innate immune system by investigating the interplay between mitochondrial fission, oxidative stress, and cardiolipin externalization in regulating inflammation and cell death in macrophages. The findings will enhance our understanding of the regulatory role of mitochondrial dynamics in the innate immune system and potentially inform the development of novel therapeutic interventions targeting mitochondrial function and homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to enhance our understanding of the factors that influence the variable penetrance and expressivity of monogenic variants. Here, we define “penetrance” as the percentage of carriers that show disease and “expressivity” as the severity of the phenotype within carriers. Identifying factors that affect penetrance and expressivity has a direct impact on public health by identifying monogenic carriers who will need more aggressive treatment to manage their symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Insulin resistance, a common and serious health problem, can be associated both with obesity and old age. Recent discoveries point to dysfunction in fat tissue as a culprit; proposed studies will build on those findings and explore the altered biochemistry of fats that leads to that dysfunction. Insights from these studies will inform therapies for age- and obesity-acquired insulin resistance, for which treatment options are currently limited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer-mediated muscle cachexia is a severe wasting syndrome that occurs in virtually every patient and strongly predicts poor outcome. How pancreatic cancer drives muscle cachexia is still unfolding. Upon completion, this study will shed new insights into mechanistic paradigms of muscle cachexia and hopefully thereby pave the way for therapeutic breakthroughs to curb this life-threatening condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity has become a major public health concern as it increases the risk for type 2 diabetes, heart attack, certain forms of cancer, hypertension and stroke. This research proposal aims to develop technologies for modulation of gene expression specifically in neurons involved in the control of body weight in mice and to use these approaches to determine how gene mutations affect food intake and body weight in certain patients. This research could lead to a better understanding on how people become obese and could lead to new treatments for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acanthamoeba castellanii is a pathogenic free-living amoeba responsible for central nervous system human infections that are almost always fatal. The proposed research will aim to identify potent amoebicidal compounds produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an environmental bacteria that co-exists with A. castellanii, and determine how these are inducing cell death. This work will therefore identify novel natural products that will bring us closer to treating devastating human infections caused by A. castellanii and other free-living amoebae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Air pollution is a serious and growing health concern that effects millions of people globally. Ozone (O3) is a highly reactive gas defined as one of six criteria air pollutants by the environmental protection agency that increases morbidity and mortality of pulmonary diseases. This proposal will identify the mechanisms of resolution from O3-induced inflammation driven by docosahexaenoic acid and its metabolites to reveal potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite their success in eradicating many pathogens, there are still many diseases for which vaccines do not currently exist. One exciting way to improve vaccines is delivering antigens with multiple adjuvants directly to dermal layers, activating distinct pathways specifically against that antigen. This research proposal will probe how combinatorial vaccines induce effective immune responses by using microneedle arrays—small, polymer patches of needles hundreds of microns long— to painlessly deliver antigen with precise ratios of adjuvants directly to dermal layers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative The gut microbiome is significantly altered in premature infants, who are at higher risk for adverse outcomes to respiratory infections such as respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). Our studies will investigate whether altered state of the premature microbiome affects the ability of the immune system to effectively deal with infection, and to define the contributions of the altered gut microbiome to the outcome of RSV infection in preterm infants. Identifying bacteria and metabolites that might be used to “normalize” the respiratory immune response to RSV infection will have the potential to improve the outcome of RSV infection in vulnerable premature infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death in the industrialized world. Recent studies suggest that atherosclerotic plaques that are prone to causing clinical cardiac events are characterized by several features of defective resolution, including inefficient clearance of apoptotic cells. The goal of this project is to advance our understanding on the triggers that lead to failed resolution during chronic inflammation and uncover fundamental mechanisms of disease to treat atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative. Although genome-wide association studies have identified numerous genes and variants associated with diabetes, the exact biological functions of these genes/variants in human pancreatic β cells are largely unknown. Here, we will use human embryonic stem cells, human islets, and humanized mice to systematically study the role of these genetic variants in human pancreatic β cell development, function, and survival in vitro and in vivo. Understanding the biological functions of these genes/variants will significantly enhance our knowledge of β cell biology, which will pave the way for the development of drugs for precision therapy for diabetes patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Effective, long-lasting therapies are urgently needed to combat psychiatric disorders involving dysregulated reward circuitry, such as depression and disordered eating. Psychedelic drugs have recently gained traction for their efficacy in treating depression, and potential as a therapeutic for disordered eating. The experiments in this proposal will examine the effectiveness of psychedelic drugs at reversing changes to reward-seeking behavior induced by early-life adversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 5-hydroxymethylcytosine(5hmC) is an epigenetic modification that serves as a stable marker of DNA demethylation and transcriptional activation. To date, the role of 5hmC regulation in a number of diseases has only been explored using plasma cell-free DNA samples. By comprehensively characterizing 5hmC profiles derived from both healthy urine cfDNA and bladder cancer urine cfDNA, this proposal aims to nominate urine cfDNA as a viable and noninvasive liquid biopsy alternative for genitourinary cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Atrial and ventricular cardiac arrhythmias, are serious public health problems in the United States, affecting over 5% of Americans and are major causes of stroke and heart failure leading to increased morbidity and mortality. This proposed preclinical study and clinical trial will determine how electromechanical wave imaging, a non- invasive ultrasound precision imaging modality can effectively diagnose and determine the mechanism of the arrhythmia and impact personalized treatment of cardiac arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Although Spanish-speaking Latinx children are at a particularly high risk for experiencing pain management disparities in the Emergency Department (ED) due to linguistic barriers, very little is known about sociocultural factors that contribute to misaligned pain understanding during interpreted medical encounters. This mixed methods design research study aims to identify sociocultural factors that influence interpreted pain communication and evaluate the concordance of pain understanding among multiple stakeholders (caregivers, children, interpreters, and clinicians) in a linguistically and ethnically diverse sample of children who present to the ED with pain-related complaints. The information gained from this research will contribute to the budding knowledgebase on culturally relevant pain assessment and management for language-diverse patients and families who use interpretation services in pediatric medical settings, thereby promoting development of future interventions and equitable health services for historically underserved youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Recently it has been identified that in IPF, one of the main characteristics is the loss of alveolar epithelial type II stem cells (AT2), with the concurrence appearance of transitional AT2 cells, an undetermined aberrant alveolar epithelial. We have identified a decrease in the expression and activity of CPT1a, a limiting regulator of fatty acid oxidation (FAO), which results in increased transitional AT2 stem cells without reaching a terminal AT1 differentiation, consequently decreasing the resilience against lung fibrosis. In this grant, we will address for the first time the functional role of FAO, one of the critical mitochondrial metabolic pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE --------------------------------------------- -------- ---- The signs of manganese (Mn) toxicity are neurological and range from mood, cognitive to motor disorders; thus, it is critical to understand how excess metal deposition from welding fumes affects different brain regions, and how these depositions are related to each other. Therefore, the goal of this research is to establish novel computational in vivo imaging methods to a) separately visualize and quantify excess Mn and Fe deposition in the individual welder brain, and b) characterize the propagation of Mn and Fe in the human brain and the role of different brain regions in the development of neurotoxicity effects with the aid of brain network science tools and advanced statistical methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neural mechanisms underlying affective pain in the brain are relatively unexplored compared to pain mechanisms in the periphery. Preliminary work has identified a C57 subline, C57BL/10SnJ, that shows a novel affective pain phenotype of increased pain-linked escape behavior, that is correlated ith increased neural activity in the ventral lateral periaqueductal grey (vlPAG) and anterior cingulate cortex. This proposal will make use of C57BL/10SnJ mice and the genetic tools available in C57BL/6J mice to elucidate the neural mechanisms in the vlPAG that modulate pain-linked escape behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will determine the various steric and electronic factors in designing stereoselective phosphorous catalysts for enantioselective acylations and tandem functionalizations. This proposal hypothesizes new, electron rich chiral P-catalysts which can function as a stereocontrolling element during several P-catalyzed steps. This proposal will use these catalysts for chemoselective P-catalysed dehydrative nitrile formation, an important transformation to the pharmaceutical community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Our preliminary and previous data show that exercise can increases striatal dopamine (DA) release in striatal slices from 12-month-old male and female mice, and that this is associated with an improvement in motor speed and coordination in mice of both sexes. This project will address several open questions in wild type and Parkinson's disease (PD) model mice, including the role of a growth factor, BDNF, in these benefits of exercise. Answering these questions could point to new cellular pathways that could be harnessed for PD therapeutics, and more generally, provide new mechanistic insight into the beneficial effects of exercise for brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In Alzheimer’s disease (AD), predictable spreading of tau pathology between functionally connected brain regions correlates well with progressive cognitive impairment, thus constituting a likely effective treatment target. The proposed study will evaluate the molecular mechanisms of pathological tau spreading within the framework of trans-synaptic tau spreading. Specifically, the results of this investigation will contribute to the fundamental knowledge about the molecular mediators of tau oligomer binding in human synapses, thus providing novel and translationally relevant avenues for future AD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Amblyopia, the most common form of monocular vision loss, is increasingly resistant to reversal with age. We propose a series of experiments to test the hypothesis that dark exposure followed by light reintroduction induces asymmetric changes in synaptic structure and neuronal excitability in primary visual cortex that promote the rejuvenation of plasticity in the adult visual cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Males and females exhibit sexually dimorphic vulnerability to obesity-induced pathology in multiple tissues, including the brain. Our recent findings suggest that subcutaneous adipose tissue, which is more abundant in females, protects against brain inflammation and synaptic dysfunction in mice with dietary obesity. The proposed experiments manipulate subcutaneous fat and anti-inflammatory signaling between cerebrospinal fluid immune cells and parenchymal glia to elucidate the underlying mechanisms for neuroprotection. In doing so, we hope to understand why the 'apple-shaped,' but not the 'pear-shaped' body fat distribution predicts dementia risk in humans, with the long-term goal of identifying novel risk factors for cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As of 2012, over 20.6 million adult Americans and 285 million people worldwide suffered from low or no vision, and it is expected to more than double by 2050, making it a significant public health problem. This conference seeks to bring basic ocular researchers from the widest possible range of disciplines together with clinicians to promote understanding of visual system development and disease, and to develop new approaches for treating vision disorders. This meeting also promotes the six major objectives of the NEI Framework for Vision Research, most notably to “gather knowledge of the molecular basis of ocular health and disease” and “strengthen the pool of vision researchers”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During metastasis, evidence suggests that tumor derived extracellular vesicles facilitate metastasis by initiating changes in the cellular constituents and extracellular matrix of the future metastatic site, resulting in the development of the premetastatic niche. Our goal is to utilize our engineered model of the premetastatic niche to determine the role that matrix dynamics, cellular compositions, and cellular plasticity have on metastatic colonization and drug resistance. These data will be critical for the development of novel therapies designed to treat the most lethal aspect of breast cancer.

PHR: Narrative Lp(a) levels are a risk factor for Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease. The levels are mostly genetically determined. The current proposal aims to understand how the genetic determinants of Lp(a) levels affect Lp(a) composition and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrhythmia can be an early indicator of disrupted heart cell-cell junctional integrity, which can progress to advanced stages of pathologic heart remodeling and sudden cardiac death, with early-stage disease diagnosis remaining a challenge, complicating the development of targeted therapies. It is essential to understand the regulatory mechanisms in place that control protein expression and turnover at the cardiac cell-cell junction in order to identify critical mediators of this process which could be targeted for therapeutic intervention. In the proposed research project, I will leverage molecular and computational techniques to characterize junctional protein expression regulation dynamics and assess the efficacy of a candidate gene therapy reintroduction approach in the rescue of arrhythmia and subsequent heart failure in physiologically relevant disease models with the goal of discovering generalizable regulatory pathways which could be exploited for patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene therapies can definitively treat genetic blood diseases like Sickle Cell Disease, Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (“Bubble Boy Disease”), and Bone Marrow Failure disorders without requiring bone marrow transplant from another individual. However, current gene therapy treatment approaches rely on collection of blood stem cells by a medical procedure from the bone marrow or peripheral blood, then complex manufacture of gene modified blood stem cells outside of the body, and finally transplant of the gene modified blood stem cells back to the patient after first treating the patient with high-dose chemotherapy to allow for blood stem cell replacement. In this proposal, building from our expertise in virus engineering, gene editing, and disease biology, we aim to develop a novel gene therapy approach that could be administered directly to a patient’s blood stem cells by vein, thereby avoiding stem cell collection, complex cell manufacture, and toxic chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Diabetic retinopathy is a major cause of blindness worldwide, and there is a great need to identify new molecular targets. Current anti-VEGF drugs address only advanced stages of disease and are only partially effective. This research will investigate soluble guanylate cyclase as a novel regulator of DR and shed light into its various potential effects, providing a new molecular target for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High prevalence of severe cocaine use disorder among patients and the lack of FDA-approved treatment for cocaine use disorder demonstrates the critical need to identify new potential therapeutic targets for cocaine use disorder. The goal of the proposed research is to further our understanding of neural circuits that drive cocaine reinforcement. To this end, the proposed research will define how cocaine recruits an endogenous opioid peptide released from neurons in the striatum to alter striatal circuit functioning and drive cocaine taking and seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alveolar macrophages (AMs) are a critical cell population that have an important role in healthy lung function and lipid metabolism while also being the main cellular niche for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB), a global health problem. We will use a novel model for human AMs to investigate an understudied class of transcription factors linked to AM function and TB. We seek to determine the role of the NR4A family of nuclear receptors in macrophage function and host defense against Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in order to deepen our understanding of AM biology and aid in identification of novel targets for host- directed therapies against TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium, or acute confusional state, affects up to 7 million hospitalized older adults annually and is associated with long-term declines in cognition and function. Medications are thought to be the cause of up to 36% of delir- ium and be contributory to an even higher percentage but are surprisingly understudied, with studies to date focusing on only a few medications and being only modest quality. In this secondary data analysis, we will apply machine learning data mining methods to a large electronic health record database with a decade of delirium as- sessments to comprehensively examine the risk of delirium due to medications, which in turn will lead to improved management for this serious but often overlooked disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The pathophysiology of pulmonary fibrosis relies on repeated local micro-injuries to the alveolar epithelium triggering DNA damage, cell death, and aberrant tissue remodeling. Elevated levels of cell-free DNA, derived from cell stress or cell death, activate the cGAS-STING pathway inducing interferon and pro-inflammatory cytokine expression. This proposal seeks to define a causal relationship between cGAS-STING, inflammation, and aberrant lung tissue remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide among chronic liver diseases; unfortunately, no FDA-approved treatments are available, due to an incomplete understanding of its molecular mediators. The objectives of this project are to discover the new function of the serine-arginine protein kinase 2 (SRPK2) on alcohol-induced pre-mRNA splicing in hepatocytes, to elucidate how SRPK2-mediated regulation of pre-mRNA splicing modulates alcohol-induced abnormalities in lipid metabolism in ALD, and to investigate whether targeting SRPK2 by fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21), a hepatocyte-derived hormone, delays and reverses the progression of ALD. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of NIAAA and public health because the knowledge gained may provide a rationale for designing innovative therapeutic strategies, such as a long-acting form of FGF21, as pharmacological interventions for human ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CRISPR systems are diverse, RNA-guided, adaptive immune systems that provide sequence-specific defense against invading nucleic acids. In this fellowship application, I present specific experimental aims which are linked to training objectives that will provide critical mechanistic insight towards the biological function of a unique class of type III-B CRISPR systems physically linked to elements of toxin-antitoxin systems. Completion of the specific aims and training objectives in this proposal will advance my training in biochemistry and structural biology, while also providing new mechanistic insights that clarify how CRISPR systems limit viral spread through a population by triggering cell death through a multipronged attack on translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Study Title: Sleep and emotion processing in adolescent Post-traumatic stress Disorder Principal Investigators: Stephanie Jones, PhD and Ryan Herringa, MD, PhD Project Narrative Despite clear links between sleep and the progression and maintenance of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), research using objective assessments of sleep during adolescence, when PTSD incidence rises markedly, are nearly absent. In this work, we will use sophisticated technologies to objectively record the brain during sleep, in the laboratory and in the home environment, and will explore sleep’s relationship to emotional learning (in the laboratory) and daily affective function and symptom severity (longitudinally in the home). Finally, we will test whether we can reliably increase the deepest stage of sleep using a novel sleep-wearable headband that employs auditory stimulation algorithms to enhance deep sleep and represents the first validated, non-pharmacological method available for sleep enhancement. The results of this work promise to have a significant impact on our understanding of sleep’s role in the pathophysiology of adolescent PTSD, and to lay the groundwork for larger clinical trials of sleep neuromodulatory interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative The surface of the intestine is the largest area of the body exposed to microbes, which in turn constantly affect host physiology. The gut contains as many neurons as the spinal cord and more immune cells than all other compartments combined. The goal of this project is to pinpoint the host and microbial components that play a role in the maintenance and recovery of enteric neurons post infection or antibiotic treatment, generating knowledge relevant to several chronic inflammatory disorders of the intestine and other tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease and Related Dementias, are increasingly prevalent in our aging society, it is imperative that we understand the basic biological mechanisms that underlie these diseases in order to generate effective treatments. This project investigates the regulation of neuronal autophagy, a mechanism that neurons utilize to maintain their overall health and function but decreases with age. The successful completion of this project will extend our knowledge of neuronal autophagy and its connection to neurodegeneration, allowing for the formulation of more effective therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Establishing specific synaptic connections is critical for proper neural circuit function, and alterations in connectivity have been linked to neurological diseases such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. This proposal will investigate how two subfamilies of cell surface proteins, the Dprs and DIPs, instruct specific connectivity in Drosophila central motor circuits. This study will also examine the signaling mechanisms underlying Dpr and DIP interactions, and potentially provide new signaling insights into their vertebrate orthologs, the IgLONs, which are associated with various neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of death globally and chronic stress is a well-known risk factor for cardiovascular pathologies. Additionally, women have increased risk of stress-related cardiovascular disease; however, the neurobiological mechanisms underlying this increased risk are not well understood. Therefore, this proposal seeks to determine neural circuit-specific adaptations induced by stress that lead to differential cardiovascular susceptibility in males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. Oxidative imbalance and functional impairment of mitochondria mediates pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and its related disorders (ADRDs). Although mitochondria are among the prominent intracellular site for ROS generation, standard clinical 18F-FDG PET/CT lacks sensitivity and diagnostic robustness. Furthermore, the mechanism of its retention and trapping poorly correlates with oxidative imbalance. To address this critical unmet need, this project is focused on biochemical validation of a novel redox-sensitive molecular PET imaging probe (identified as 18F-SLN-128) in Huntington’s disease and AD transgenic mice models, GMP production to obtain regulatory approval (eIND from FDA) including institutional RDRC, IRB approvals, and human dosimetry studies as well as assessment in AD participants for objective of its translation from the bench into clinical nuclear medicine for healthcare management. Successful accomplishment of proposed aims could deliver a redox-sensitive PET molecular imaging agent for stratification of therapeutic choices or alterations in lifestyles for managing ROS-mediated mitochondrial dysfunction in neurodegenerative diseases in general, and AD and ADRDs in particular.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Precise patterns of connectivity within and across brain regions drive the perception of visual stimuli — disrup- tion of these patterns underlie a number of complex psychiatric and neurological diseases. Important advances have elucidated neural architectures within single brain regions, but neural connectivity across brain regions is still deeply understudied, particularly in an intact animal. This proposal leverages a breakthrough two-photon holographic mesoscope — that can uniquely record and manipulate individual neurons across brain regions — to causally interrogate how interareal neural connections govern the cortical computations supporting perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 1 in 3 people are overweight and nearly 2 in 5 people have obesity; so, obesity is a national epidemic. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because new effective therapies for obesity and obesity-related complications (e.g., NAFLD/NASH and type 2 diabetes) are needed. The tools and knowledge gained, and the mechanistic details to be discovered in this proposal, all fit the purview of NIDDK's mission to reduce the burden of obesity and obesity-related metabolic complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This project aims to develop a new methodology for the site- and stereoselective formation of C–C bond from C–H bonds through the use of a photocatalytically active uranyl-containing artificial metalloenzyme. Through directed evolution using techniques such as site-saturation mutagenesis, artificial metalloenzymes containing non-native, uranyl cofactors will be developed to catalyze asymmetric chemical reactions with high activity and high selectivity. This will create new approaches by which molecules relevant to human health can be synthesized by new classes of selective C–H bond functionalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The discovery of human riboswitches represents a new layer of gene regulation that will aid researchers in better understanding how cells respond to metabolites in their environments. This may include previously unknown regulatory events and signaling molecules dictating nuanced cell behaviors, non-coding genetic variations contributing to diseased and healthy phenotypes, and insights into our molecular evolutionary heritage. In essence, eukaryotic riboswitches could teach us to speak the language of a cell more fluently, enabling the discovery of therapeutic targets for dysfunctional cellular systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mitochondria are energy-producing components within our cells, and perturbations in their function are implicated in a wide range of human diseases, including neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's, cardiovascular disorders, metabolic disorders, and cancer. I will investigate how one of the important proteins critical for mitochondrial health, YME1, makes molecular decisions about how it processes substrates in response to cellular stress and toxicity, using integrated structural, biochemical, and computational approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Human genetic studies have revealed robust links between epigenetic regulators and complex disorders, such as autism, schizophrenia and obsessive compulsive disorder, but knowledge of the mechanistic basis of these links continues to elude us. Here, we seek to understand the impact of mutations in the risk candidate gene Chd8 on cerebellum-specific neuropathology. This work will offer insights into novel causal contributions of Chd8 and cerebellar circuits to high-order non-motor functions and complex mental health disorders, inform future biomarker development, and can ultimately reveal new molecular and circuit targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite its importance to the formation of the body plan, little is known about the mechanisms driving primate gastrulation. We aim to create a high-throughput, three-dimensional model of the peri-implantation primate embryo using chimpanzee induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) encapsulated in hydrogel droplets. By using a microfluidic droplet sorter to control the number of cells and cell types in each droplet, we will investigate the impact of cell number, cell type, and local tissue mechanics on model embryo structure and explore the role of morphogen signaling dynamics on cell fate decisions via downstream optogenetic stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and its metabolic consequences are associated with increased mortality and morbidity because of their links to Type 2 diabetes (T2D), cardiovascular, lung, gastrointestinal, osteoarticular and reproductive diseases. This Keystone Symposia conference will explore the latest in the causes of obesity, as well as how the heterogeneity of obesity impacts precision management. The conference will bring together an interdisciplinary group of investigators who research obesity and cardiometabolic disease in order to network and develop new collaborations to improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After acute COVID-19 infection, millions of patients, both old and young, suffer from a syndrome called Long COVID, which can include months and years of brain dysfunction even after mild infections, placing patients at risk for both “Alzheimer’s disease and/or related dementias” (ADRD) and profound physical disability. Growing evidence indicates that Long COVID’s debilitating brain and body disease is often due to persistent inflammation and new problems of our immune system, but anti-inflammatory or immunomodulator medications have not been adequately studied in patients with Long COVID. The Randomized trial EValuating Baricitinib on pERSistent nEurologic and Cardiopulmonary Symptoms of Long COVID (REVERSE-LC) clinical investigation will enroll 500 patients with Long COVID to determine if baricitinib—an anti-inflammatory and immunomodulator drug that is FDA-approved to save lives in acute COVID-19—improves brain function and physical impairment in patients suffering from Long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Liver disease is a multifaceted condition in which multiple etiologies converge towards a common inflammatory phenotype, with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) emerging as one of the leading etiologies as it affects nearly 25% of the global population. Nearly half of these patients will advance towards the inflammatory subtype(NASH) and even on to carcinogenesis, making it crucial to characterize the way in which hepatic steatosis induces inflammation in this transition from NAFLD to NASH to better improve patient outcomes. In this proposal, we aim to focus on AKT regulation of hepatic bioactive lipid metabolism and its role on macrophage chemotaxis and polarization to promote chronic inflammation in liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections are a critical public health threat and a desired target for bacteriophage therapy. Nucleus-forming bacteriophages are a recently discovered class of bacteriophage with high therapeutic potential due to their lytic nature and intrinsic resistance to multiple bacteriophage defense systems. The research in this proposal will determine the genetic, biochemical, and structural basis for protein import into the phage nucleus, as well as how these bacteriophages affect pathogenicity and antibiotic sensitivity in P. aeruginosa.
