IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenetic mechanisms govern how behavior and environment affect the way genes work and thus, have direct influences in regulating cellular and organismal health. When epigenetic processes go awry serious health problems, including cancer, can result and lead to mortallity. This conference will bring together biological researchers, who understand the fundamental principles of epigenetic deregulation in cancer, with scientists from industry who are skilled at advancing drug discovery and development, to discuss frontiers in the field and translating these discoveries for improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial resistance is an urgent and growing threat, with a projected toll of 10 million deaths annually by 2050. A firmer understanding of existing antibiotics’ mechanisms of action and avoidance of resistance would make critical steps towards combating this public health crisis. By developing insight into the mechanism of oxazolidinone activity and the ability of certain compounds in the class to avoid emerging mechanisms of resistance, this proposal will greatly expand understanding of context-specific antibiotics and inform development of therapeutics with enhanced efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Artificial intelligence and deep learning methods have been highly successful in detecting Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and discovering patterns in brain MRI and PET scans associated with dementia. We launch a global alliance of AD experts and Artificial Intelligence (AI) teams worldwide to create a Secure Federated Learning framework, learning from diverse international data. Our novel AI approach computes, without sharing data, on multiple geographically distributed AD biobanks - in India, Japan, the U.S. and Europe - to diagnose and subtype dementia, to infer brain amyloid and tau burden from less invasive biomarkers, and predict who will decline clinically from health or mild cognitive impairment to AD, facilitating clinical trial selection and personalized prognosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Dysfunction of the primary cilium causes obesity, skeletal abnormalities, kidney cysts and retinal degeneration. The proposal aims to uncover the basic principles that underlie the packaging of ciliary signaling receptors into extracellular vesicles. If successful, this research program will further our understanding of retinal degeneration and obesity and provide novel means for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug discovery is undergoing a revolution that is now using molecules to induce “closeness” of cellular molecules as a new approach to developing therapeutics. “Proximity-based therapeutics” have the potential to regulate biological targets in a new way that will allow the development of drugs for diseases thought to have previously been “undruggable”. This conference program will bring together interdisciplinary groups of scientists, including biologists and chemists, from both academic and industry to explore the latest findings in this field and accelerate its growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative B and T lymphocytes utilize special receptors to recognize pathogens called antibodies and T cell receptors; genes encoding these receptors do not exist in our genome as functional genes, but are assembled from small gene segments during lymphocyte development by a process called VDJ recombination. However, since this process requires breaking and repairing DNA, mistakes can occur that sometimes result in deleterious genome alterations, which have been shown to promote the development of lymphoid cancers. This application aims to elucidate how VDJ recombination is regulated so that these potentially cancer causing mistakes do not occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this grant is to study the role of BDNF in the hippocampus in regulating homeostatic synaptic plasticity critical for mediating antidepressant responses in mice. Based on our preliminary data presented in this application, we will examine the impact of BDNF specifically in the hippocampus on homeostatic synaptic scaling in vivo in rapid antidepressant responses. These studies will use molecular, cellular, behavioral, and electrophysiological approaches to investigate whether BDNF is sufficient to drive synaptic scaling in vivo and mediate fast-acting antidepressant responses, in the hopes of developing novel antidepressants with rapid onset of clinical efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Fibrosis in the heart is bad and contributes to poor survival for patients with heart failure, which afflicts millions of Americans, yet no effective treatments for fibrosis in the heart are available. Using special (genetically modified) mice, the proposed study will determine if targeting a specific protein, BRD4, in fibroblasts might work as a treatment for fibrosis in the heart and will determine if other proteins in the same family are important for turning on and off specific genes in the heart. Together, this work will help us understand how cells in the heart become disease activated and help us progress toward finding better treatments for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed basic research is focused on better understanding how RNAs are localized and translated in neurons. Perturbations to these processes occur in many neurological diseases, but we do not have a good understanding of how RNA localization occurs. This research has implications for many neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to Public Health A number of human diseases result from mutations in genes that play broad roles in all cell types in our bodies, but the clinical consequences are restricted to only some cell types, tissues or organs. This type of scenario occurs very regularly where the brain and the cells, termed neurons, that are key for proper brain function are affected. The proposed studies use a combination of model systems to explore the molecular basis for a specific form of neurodevelopmental human disease, a heritable form of intellectual disability, by exploring the intersection of specific factors and modifications of RNA that may help to explain why neurons are impacted and define a paradigm for such diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Given the prevalence of nuclear size alterations and whole genome doubling (WGD) in malignant tumors, the aim of this proposal is to determine how variations in nuclear size after WGD affect tumorigenic potential and identify the cellular mechanisms that regulate nuclear size in tetraploid (4N) cells. These findings will yield new insights into the epigenetic and transcriptional consequences of WGD and unveil whether nuclear size is important for 4N cell tumorigenicity. Leveraging the mechanisms that link nuclear size, increased ploidy, and tumorigenicity may refine current cancer diagnostic practices and lead to the development of new strategies that target nuclear size in cancer cells for therapeutic benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Certain adjuvants lead to allergic sensitization, but their mechanisms of action are poorly understood. We discovered that a subset of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are sufficient as allergic adjuvants. We propose to mechanistically dissect how NSAIDs act as adjuvants to cause allergic sensitization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Colistin is an antibiotic that is reserved for the treatment of serious infections caused by bacteria that are resistant to other antibiotics but increasing use of colistin has led to the emergence of colistin-resistant strains of bacteria. There is also significant concern that colistin may not be working as well in patients with infection as it may be in test tubes. This project will expand our ongoing investigation on how bacteria can become resistant to colistin and develop rapid and accurate methods to detect resistance.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patterning during early development is a product of integration of signaling cues that result in specific gene expression. Gene expression results from transcription factors engaging with the chromatin environment. In this proposal we will investigate the mechanism by which, histone demethylases of the KDM3 family affect gene expression during the early stages of development especially in the specification of primordial germ cells that are precursors to gametes. The results obtained from this proposal will be highly impactful to the fields of early developmental disorders and infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Innate immune responses of insect vectors of human diseases are likely to affect the their ability to transmit pathogens to hosts. The long term goals of this research is to gain understanding of proteins in insect hemolymph that mediate innate immune responses, using a model system, Manduca sexta, well suited for biochemical studies. The knowledge gained from this project will enhance understanding of the evolution of innate immune mechanisms and can be applied to future investigations of arthropod disease vectors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Increasing age is associated with changes in the host immune system and the indigenous microbiota. These changes affect the interaction of the host with bacterial pathogens leading to increased susceptibility to infection and worse clinical outcomes, including infection with the pathogen Clostridiodes difficile. Three teams with complementary expertise in geriatrics, infectious diseases, immunology, bioinformatics, and microbiology will work in animal models systems to understanding how aging leads to the increased burden of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative To navigate our surroundings, the nervous system must identify which of the many stimuli we encounter are threatening enough to require a behavioral response and which can be ignored. Sensory hypersensitivity to innocuous stimuli is a hallmark of many behavioral disorders including autism, anxiety, and schizophrenia. Our research aims to determine the molecular pathways that guide the formation and function of the neural circuits that underlie this sensory filtering, with the long-term goal of establishing approaches for therapeutic intervention in disorders of sensory processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 diabetes (T1D) occurs when a loss of immune tolerance to insulin-producing beta cells of the pancreas leads to their destruction and blood glucose dysregulation. T1D can be cured with beta cell replacement through pancreatic islet transplantation, but the need for chronic systemic immunosuppression limits the applicability of this procedure. Islet transplantation without the need for chronic systemic immunosuppression can be achieved by encapsulation, where transplanted islets are coated in biocompatible gels that act as a barrier to recipient immune responses. Unfortunately, an indirect immune response still occurs. This proposed project seeks to combine islet encapsulation with two tolerance-inducing therapies that block this indirect immune response, thereby improving the efficacy of encapsulated islet transplantation and its potential for translation to the clinic.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  Our main goals are to understand the molecular mechanisms by which neurons activate pathways that induce axon degeneration during development apoptosis and pruning. Apoptosis and pruning are physiologically important as they allow for the removal of excessive or defective neurons or specific axon branches during the establishment of the nervous system. The results from this study will help identify key mechanisms by which axon degeneration occurs during brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will develop and assess a framework for developing culturally-sensitive and highly predictive parental-report screening measures to improve the equity and accuracy of future ASD screeners. Current ASD screeners do not sufficiently account for i) heterogeneity between cultural groups in culture-based parental perceptions of early Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) expressions and ii) heterogeneity within cultural groups in the development of social communication behaviors over time, which together impede equitable and accurate ASD screening and timely access to ASD-specialized services. This proposal will apply mixed- methods data collection and analytic techniques in a novel manner to precisely characterize this dual heterogeneity and to develop prototype algorithms that predict ASD in diverse families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress are hallmarks of pathologic aging and are intricately linked in the onset and pathogenesis of etiologically-diverse neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRDs). PERK—an ER stress-responsive kinase that acts as an effector of both unfolded protein response (UPR) and integrated stress response (ISR) signaling—regulates mitochondrial adaptation in response to ER stress and is deficient in neurodegenerative tauopathies such as AD and progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). Here I will define a critical role for PERK in regulating adaptive mitochondrial remodeling during neurodegeneration, and I will establish pharmacologic ISR activation as a potential therapeutic strategy to mitigate mitochondrial dysfunction and improve neuronal survival in neurodegenerative disease.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal care is one of the most important environmental factors influencing brain development and later vulnerability to maladaptive behaviors. We recently found that the mother’s presence or absence regulates the activity of the prefrontal cortex (PFC) in 11-day-old rat pups through the serotonergic system. In the current proposal, we propose to uncover the mechanisms regulating PFC activity during development and how this affects adaptive behavior in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of new synthetic methods in organic chemistry is critical to enabling the continued discovery and production of pharmaceuticals and other chemicals that directly benefit society and public health. This proposal aims to develop a series of novel methods for C–C, C–N, and C–S bond formation that will allow for the rapid preparation of medicinally-relevant scaffolds across a variety of disease states. The newly developed reagents, and their associated reactions and applications, will be of immediate utility to synthetic chemists and chemical biologists in both academic and industrial laboratories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The co-occurrence of opioid use and suicide is an urgent public health concern that has received growing national attention. The proposed project is the first to disentangle the proximal role of trauma context in subsequent co-occurring opioid use and acute suicide risk in the daily lives of community individuals. Findings will specify time-sensitive and context-dependent risk for co-occurring opioid use and acute suicide risk to inform targeted and trauma-informed prevention and intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Mitochondria produce energy but they also release free radicals that can impair neural cells and contribute to disorders of the brain. Using experimental models, we will test the therapeutic efficacy of uniquely selective blockers of mitochondrial free radicals in dementia-linked pathology, and investigate new candidate mechanisms underlying the effects of free radicals on glial cells. These studies are expected to uncover novel roles of mitochondria in dementia-related processes and new treatment approaches for aging-related disorders of the brain.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Research Narrative The adult mammalian hippocampus contains neural stem cells that provide a self-renewable source for continuous replenishment of new neurons throughout life, highlighting the striking structural plasticity and regenerative capacity within the mature nervous system. Neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD), lead to impaired adult hippocampal neurogenesis in both AD mouse models and human patients likely due to lack of permissive niche environment for neuroregeneration. Therefore, identifying critical neurogenic niche components that promotes sustainable neurogenesis may enable development of novel strategies to enhance functional repair from endogenous NSCs upon neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Injury control is directly related to two overarching goals of Healthy People 2020: (1) Attain high-quality, longer lives free of preventable disease, disability, injury, and premature death; and (2) Achieve health equity, eliminate disparities, and improve the health of all groups. Continued attention to controlling injuries in children and reducing health disparities related to injury remains a foremost challenge for public health, a priority reflected in the 43 injury prevention goals set forth in Healthy People 2020, many of which have not been achieved. This Pediatric Injury Research Training program remains the only comprehensive pediatric injury research training program in the nation that addresses injury and violence of all types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over the past 50 years, there has been an eight-fold increase in the frequency of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), a deadly tumor that develops in patients who have gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) complicated by a change in the lining of the esophagus called Barrett’s esophagus (BE). The current policy of using endoscopy to identify individuals with GERD symptoms who have BE, and then enrolling BE patients in a program of regular endoscopy to detect pre-cancerous changes has failed to stem the rising frequency of EAC, largely because of the lack of a reliable test to identify which BE patients are at high risk for cancer development. Preliminary studies suggest that a new precision medicine test called TissueCypher can identify BE patients at high risk for cancer development, and the proposed study is designed to validate TissueCypher’s utility as a BE risk-stratification tool, a finding of high relevance to public health that could stem the rising frequency of EAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Misshapen teeth are highly common in humans and most cases are due to a genetic mutation like for the Runx2 gene which, when mutated, causes cleidocranial dysplasia (CCD). Retinoic acid is a signaling molecule that plays a crucial role during tooth induction and that we suspect play a major role during tooth morphogenesis. This proposal will develop new fish models to study the role of retinoid acid and the Runx2 gene during tooth formation, clarifying the mechanisms which cause misshapen teeth in CCD and will identify novel genes implicated in the development and evolution of tooth morphogenesis.

PHR: A protein’s function depends on its shape. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal psychological risk, characterized as depression and attachment insecurity, negatively impacts caregiving behavior and infant well-being. Increasing research suggests that neurocognitive mechanisms underscoring maternal sensitivity may represent one pathway through which maternal psychological risk affects caregiving and infant adjustment – although this research is generally limited by focusing largely on European ancestry women. Therefore, the proposed study seeks to examine whether maternal risk factors undermine maternal sensitivity and infant adjustment (including attachment security and behavioral problems) as a function of infant temperament through measurements of maternal brain functioning across the transition to motherhood in 200 European American and 200 African American nulliparous expectant mothers and their children.

Increasing number of HIV-infected persons are living longer due to combined antiretroviral therapies, and a significant population of such patients suffer from neurocognitive impairments known as HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Retroviruses 2021-2024 Narrative HIV/AIDS is now a major pandemic in human beings throughout the world. According to the World Health Organization, almost 80 million people have been infected with the HIV virus since the beginning of the epidemic, and almost 40 million people have died of HIV. Sub-Saharan Africa remains most severely affected, with nearly 1 in every 20 adults living with HIV and accounting for nearly 71% of the people living with HIV worldwide. Many conferences around the world address a plethora of issues related to the treatment of HIV/AIDS, but few do so by addressing the underlying biology of the virus, and even fewer do this by putting the molecular biology of the virus and its interaction with its human host in the broader context of how all retroviruses, irrespective of host, function and evolve. A key to the success of the Cold Spring Harbor annual retroviruses conference is that the majority of oral presentations are given by graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and junior faculty chosen on the basis of scientific merit, ensuring that the conference showcases the latest developments which are often yet to be published. Participants come from academic centers, research institutes and industrial centers around the world to present and discuss their findings. Many of the currently important treatments for HIV/AIDS were first presented or proposed at this conference in past years. Importantly, this application requests support for junior scientists who might not otherwise be able to attend to actively participate in the meeting. We are proposing to host four annual iterations of this important conference in spring 2021, 2022, 2023 and 2024.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The prevalence of end-stage renal failure (ESRD) has increased ~40% over 20 years, but the kidney-related biomedical workforce has been unable to keep pace. New pathways to a career in nephrology and kidney-related medicine and research are vitally needed that combine early and frequent experiential opportunities to engage in patient-oriented kidney care and contribute to innovative technologies that will one-day change how renal dysfunction is diagnosed and treated. ADVANCE Kidney Health responds to this need by assembling diverse mentors, interdisciplinary infrastructure and novel engineering technologies to impact career trajectories and develop the new technological cures of tomorrow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project aims at elucidating the mechanisms by which cardiac TTR amyloidosis and progressive fibrosis separately contribute to age-related adverse cardiac remodeling in multi-ethnic older adults. We will use state-of-the-art MRI techniques to assess the myocardial extra-cellular volume, as well as left and right ventricular and atrial dysfunction and will use state-of art Tc-99m-PYP techniques to detect the presence and quantify the magnitude of the amyloid burden in the myocardium. The data acquisition methods will be combined with novel statistical methods (machine learning) to achieve the scientific aims of the proposed ancillary study to MESA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Aberrant activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome contributes to the pathogenesis of several inflammatory disorders, including Cryopyrin-associated autoinflammatory syndrome, gout, diabetes, and Alzheimer's disease. The goal of this application is to better understand how the NLRP3 inflammasome is activated. Understanding the mechanism of NLRP3 inflammasome activation might guide the development of novel therapeutic strategies for treating inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: P01 Narrative Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is an autoimmune disorder that not only imparts a considerable adverse impact on daily lifestyle but also, over a lifetime, often results in patients that succumb to a series of debilitating disease- associated complications and early mortality. The studies proposed in this P01 are designed to better understand the contributions of genetics to the coordinated immune response that mediates T1D development, through studies of the human pancreas, trafficking through inflamed vasculature, and phenotype/function relationships within the pancreatic draining lymph nodes and peripheral blood samples. We expect knowledge gains from these studies will lead to the identification of improved biomarkers of disease activity, and uncover precision- medicine based targets for therapeutic interventions capable of preventing or reversing T1D autoimmune pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative We will use our newly developed MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) techniques to study brain microvascular and lymphatic system abnormalities in LRRK2 (Leucine Rich Repeat Kinase 2) mouse models of Parkinson’s disease. We will assess whether those abnormalities can serve as potential indicators for PD pathogenic processes and treatment evaluation. These studies will provide a novel understanding of the neuropathological changes underlying PD pathogenesis, which may facilitate the development of biomarkers for diagnostics and PD intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Our lab recently identified an antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) that targets glucose metabolism through alternative splicing of pyruvate kinase (PKM) pre-mRNA, which could be used as a therapy to treat advanced- stage hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). To advance this work, I plan to define the underlying mechanism for how ASO-based PKM splice-switching (APSS) ultimately leads to reduced HCC growth, and will determine the synergy of APSS therapy with current HCC therapies. The knowledge gained from this proposal will improve our understanding of PKM alternative splicing in tumorigenesis, help to identify synergistic therapies that reinforce the effects of our APSS therapy, and provide further justification for the eventual testing of our APSS therapy in clinical trials for advanced HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our current understanding of how glycans regulate biological events is limited, marred by the technical challenge of analyzing protein glycoconjugate structure and interactions. Our research seeks to bridge the gap between proteins and glycans by using chemical biology approaches. This program can illuminate the nature and behavior of protein glycoconjugates in living cells in the short term, and it can pave the way towards biomedical interventions to promote health in the long term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sub-Saharan Africa bears the greatest burden of HIV disease globally, and the Central African region is particularly challenged. Research to define the most effective service delivery strategies in these settings is key to decreasing HIV and comorbidities of aging as causes of illness and death. Our research is critical to guide policy makers and program implementers on service delivery mechanisms to provide most efficient use of programmatic resources and the optimal gain to the public's health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in telomere maintenance cause a wide spectrum of diseases, including bone marrow failure, cardiovascular disease, pulmonary fibrosis, and cirrhosis, for which effective medical therapies are urgently needed. From genetic studies, we recently discovered that PAPD5, a factor that regulates non-coding RNA pathways, plays a novel and critical role in human telomere biology. This proposal aims to study the mechanisms of action of PAPD5 and new PAPD5 inhibitors, in order to develop new therapies for genetic blood, cardiovascular, lung and liver disorders, and possibly a broad range of aging-related degenerative diseases.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative  The pool of individuals that are susceptible to lethal systemic infections caused by the human fungal pathogen Candida albicans is increasing due to new medical treatments and an aging population. Improved therapeutic approaches are needed to due to the limitations of current antifungal drugs and the emergence of drug resistance. The proposed studies are expected to identify the mechanisms by which the C. albicans plasma membrane protects against stressful conditions in the host, which can then be targeted in new antifungal strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NYU LONG ISLAND SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is one of the risk factors for insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes (T2D), an emerging metabolic disease in the US population. The proposed research will lead to many discoveries that will significantly improve the health of US citizens and others suffering from obesity caused T2D by revealing new concepts and ideas that can be used to develop therapies for the prevention and treatment of T2D. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission that pertains to developing new approaches and fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Mechanism of Divalent Metal Transport by Nramp-Family Transporters Transition metal ions like iron and manganese are essential for many chemical activities in all living cells—e.g., oxygen transport and storage and energy conversion in mitochondria—but are also toxic at too high levels. Our long-term goal is to determine how a family of proteins (called the Nramp family) gets these metal ions across cellular membranes, using biochemistry, crystallography, computer simulations and bioinformatics analyses. This knowledge is critical to understanding how all cells and organisms regulate levels of these transition metals and could help design therapies for disorders caused by imbalances in essential and/or toxic metals, like anemia, hemochromatosis and several neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activity-dependent gene expression links neuronal activity to decoding genomic information and thus provides a powerful support for plasticity of neurons and synapses. L-type voltage-gated calcium channels sense variations in membrane potential and use signaling known as voltage-dependent conformational coupling to pass this information on to an enzyme, CaMKII. This project studies how L-type conformational coupling joins forces with glutamate-gated calcium influx through NMDA receptors to promote local accumulation of CaMKII in dendritic spines, thus driving nuclear transcription and synaptic plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acinetobacter baumannii is a major cause of multidrug-resistant hospital-associated infections and a top priority for the research and development of new antibiotics, according to the World Health Organization. We found that A. baumannii utilizes a previously unrecognized stress-signaling pathway, and strains with mutations in this pathway are more sensitive to antibiotic treatment and oxidative stress. In this application, we propose to investigate the stress response of A. baumannii and its relevance for pathogenesis, which will be foundational to future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Precision medicines that specifically target proteins that drive cancer growth are leading to improved responses in many advanced-stage cancer patients. This molecular treatment approach requires a firm understanding of the biological mechanism of cancer development and progression. The studies in this grant proposal focus on the characterization of a new mechanism of oncogenic signaling, focusing on the role of biomolecular condensates in ALK-driven lung cancer, with the overall goal of laying a foundation for developing a new suite of molecular treatments in the future that better control this cancer through improved precision medicine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative To expedite therapeutic innovations in neonates with hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), there is an urgent but unmet need to establish an accurate and reliable neonatal biomarker to predict outcomes and assess the impact of novel therapies in a more timely manner. Our Boston Children’s Hospital team - offering Neuroradiology and Artificial Intelligence (AI) expertise - is partnering with the Neonatal Research Network (NRN) - offering data, clinical vision, as well as clinical trial and biomarker experience. We aim to leverage clinical and MRI data collected in previous NRN therapeutic trials for HIE to develop an HIE-specific neonatal AI biomarker for 18-22 month outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Valvular heart disease affects over 2.5% of the US population. While catheter-based valve interventions substantially decrease patient risk in comparison to open surgery, existing catheters and imaging technologies cannot replicate the dexterity and visualization afforded by open surgery. To enable more effective and more complex beating-heart procedures, we propose to develop cardioscopic imaging and robotic catheter technology that can be delivered through the vasculature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Southeast Asia has over 600 million people, most of whom reside in low and middle-income countries that have a high burden of oral diseases which adversely impacts non-communicable diseases (e.g. diabetes and cardiovascular diseases), child development, and quality of life. There is a clear need for local research to identify risk factors and effective oral health management strategies in Southeast Asian countries, but the lack of personnel and access to training in research methods has been a major impediment to research in the region. We will build a sustainable, effective, and efficient clinical research methods training program by establishing a training hub in Thailand and by forming a regional network of oral health researchers who will conduct quality, locally-relevant research that will contribute to better management of this important public health problem for the benefits of the Southeast Asia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance: Streptococcus pneumoniae, the leading cause of pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis worldwide, is a model for the study of antibiotic-induced autolysis and the emerging threat of multidrug tolerance. The main pneumococcal autolysin LytA drives both autolysis and the newly discovered capsule shedding response. New data suggests regulators of LytA, discovered through analysis of capsule shedding, affect both the capsule shedding response and activation of autolysis by antibiotics. These regulators may form membraneless organelles as a novel mechanism of thwarting the bacterial lytic response to antibiotics leading to treatment failure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal outcome disparities by maternal race, ethnicity and place of birth are persistent and have complex roots that include differential maternal experiences of stress. This project seeks to explore the longitudinal trajectory of resilience (or the ability to respond to stress) during pregnancy as well as any resilience differences that might exist by women’s race, ethnicity, nativity and level of acculturation. By preparing the applicant for a career in longitudinal cohort research and examining the impact of resilience on the relationship between stress and neonatal outcome disparities, this proposal will provide critical foundational knowledge for the development of interventions to build resilience and diminish the risk of poor neonatal outcomes among pregnant minority women and their infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are essential for cellular function and maintain their health through dynamic properties including fusion, division and transport on microtubules. Mitochondrial dysfunction is associated with neurodegeneration and mitochondrial fusion is protective against declining function. This proposal seeks to understand the molecular machinery that mediates mitochondrial fusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with food insecurity may have other non-medical, health-related social needs (e.g., transportation barriers, housing instability, and job insecurity) that decrease their ability to attain glucose control and impact other health outcomes. Leveraging existing programs and relationships, we propose to test the combined effects of a food referral program, a diabetes education intervention, and referrals to address other social needs, on hemoglobin A1c levels in a population of racially/ethnically diverse participants with food insecurity and uncontrolled T2D. Innovative solutions are warranted to combat the long-term sequelae of uncontrolled T2D combined with food insecurity that contribute to the two-fold higher all-cause mortality in T2D that disproportionality impacts lower socioeconomic status and racial/ethnic minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Disrupted protein quality control (PQC) mechanisms, the ability of the cell to remove old/misfolded proteins, is intimately involved in heart failure. The sarcomere, the force generating structure in cardiomyocytes, is under constant mechanical stress that sensitizes its proteins to misfolding; however, the PQC mechanisms involved in maintaining the sarcomere are mostly unknown. Leveraging our recent discovery that this process is, in fact, disrupted in human heart failure, and a protein called BAG3 is critical – this proposal will finally begin to resolve the persistent mysteries of sarcomere PQC; in the future, these discoveries may be used to identify new therapeutic targets for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid misuse is a critical health issue for young adults; comprehensive prevention intervention efforts are needed to address the complex issue of opioid misuse. Engaging young adults in designing prevention programming and policy targeting opioid misuse may strengthen such efforts by making young adults full partners in creating meaningful and responsive prevention policies in their communities as well as by bolstering individual level protective factors such as self-efficacy and social connectedness. The proposed research to design an organization-level youth engagement strategy is expected to advance our understanding of how prevention organizations can incorporate the voices of young adults into prevention efforts as part of critical multi-component efforts to prevent opioid misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: T1DES Project Narrative Diabetes distress has been identified as one of the largest contributors to the racial disparity in glycemic control that disproportionately burdens Black patients ages 18-26 years with type 1 diabetes (T1D). Our study will address diabetes distress among Black young adults by tailoring an intervention relevant to their experiences managing T1D. An evidence-based intervention with demonstrated success among Black young adults would be a significant contribution to existing glycemic control interventions for patients with T1D seeking care in endocrinology practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project seeks to determine how obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) increases Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk by examining how intermittent pauses in breathing, sleep fragmentation, and local deficits in memory- relevant brain waves during sleep relate to AD pathology, structural integrity of medial temporal lobe memory circuits, and the acquisition and retention of episodic and procedural memories. The findings that emerge from this research will characterize which clinical features of OSA are mechanisms underlying the observed increase in AD risk, as well as elucidate whether this increased risk is due to facilitation of AD pathological accumulation, increased vulnerability to AD pathologies due to erosion of medial temporal lobe memory circuits, or both. This work will ultimately offer early, circuit-specific, mechanistic targets supporting the development of novel interventions to delay AD onset, slow AD progression, and minimize cognitive decline in older adults with OSA.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a vector-borne parasitic disease, and currently, drugs for curing the disease are few and often toxic to humans. The proposed studies in this application will explore the function and regulation of several of the key cell cycle regulatory proteins that are essential for Trypanosoma brucei to survive in its human and insect hosts. These studies may provide novel targets for drug development and chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Protecting the cellular proteome is crucial for all aspects of life. Changes in the activity of the players and mechanisms involved in maintaining protein homeostasis are linked to the development of many diseases, particularly amyloid-related neurodegenerative disorders. Our work focuses on two recent additions to the protein homeostasis network; inorganic polyphosphate, a player that serves as protein scaffolding factor in stress resistance and amyloidogenesis, and the histone modification H3K4me3, whose stress-related changes represent a novel mechanism to modulate protein homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) is a serious, debilitating illness whose molecular basis is not understood, preventing development of simple diagnostic tests and endpoints for evaluating therapies in clinical trials. This Center will bring together a multidisciplinary team with expertise in immunology, muscle biology, gene expression, cell-free RNA, extracellular vesicles, plasma protein characterization, and computational analysis of large data sets. By assessing biospecimens from subjects at baseline and following symptom exacerbation, the team will seek to understand the underlying pathophysiology of ME/CFS and enhance knowledge of the lay public, patients, and health professionals concerning the disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - CENTER OVERVIEW The Proposed North Carolina Diabetes Research Center (NCDRC) seeks to foster diabetes-related research among investigators – whether established, early-career, or new to the field – at and among 4 premier research institutions in the state (Duke, University of NC at Chapel Hill, NC A&T, and Wake Forest). The Pilot and Feasibility Core will provide funding for the most promising ideas among NCDRC scientists; the Core services will provide access to unique resources and expertise among all 4 campuses, and their cadre of Research Navigators will enable the studies’ efficient completion; and the Enrichment Program will plan and sponsor an annual symposium, to which NIH-supported trainees and investigators whose work could inform the future of diabetes research will be especially invited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Ion therapy concentrates dose in a small treatment “spot” and can minimize collateral damage to nearby healthy tissue – if dose is targeted accurately. Therefore, verifying that dose is delivered to the tumor, rather than nearby healthy tissue is critical, but not yet well addressed by today’s ion therapy systems. During Phase II, Acoustic Range Estimates will finalize design and validate a wireless thermoacoustic range verification system that computes range estimates and acquires ultrasound images of the patient during treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Narcolepsy results from the immune-mediated loss of about 70,000 neurons that produce the wake-promoting, REM sleep-reducing brain chemical "hypocretin" (also called "orexin"), specifically, the immune system mistakenly targets parts of hypocretin neurons that are similar to portions of a flu virus. This misdirected immune response could explain why a particular pandemic flu vaccine used in Europe in 2009-2010 increased the risk of developing narcolepsy in Europe but not the United States. The goal of this project is to isolate flu-reactive immune cells of individuals with and without narcolepsy, characterize any differences in these cells, and study how those differences contribute to the immune-mediated death of hypocretin neurons and producing narcolepsy, this high impact research will lead to blood diagnostic tests, preventive measures, and new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The major diseases of pediatric and adult gastroenterology and hepatology suffer from a lack of safe and effective therapeutics. This need can best be addressed by developing a cadre of well-trained researchers devoted to discovering disease causes and developing new approaches to disease prevention or treatment. This T32 Training Grant prepares highly-motivated and talented post-doctoral MD, MD/PhD and PhD researchers with the multi-faceted tools in cutting edge research techniques, education, and practical career advice to address current and future unmet needs in gastroenterology and hepatology.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Translational Gastroenterology and Hepatology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene regulation and metabolism are among the most important processes driving health. While each of these processes has been mechanistically studied for individual molecules and pathways, little is known about how they influence each other at a systems level. In this project, we will continue our studies of the interplay between metabolism and gene expression using the nematode C. elegans as a model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All complex organisms have a smaller mitochondrial genome in addition to the larger nuclear genome. Many human diseases are caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA, but the causes of mitochondrial mutations and their roles in physiology, health, and aging are poorly understood. The proposed work will characterize the properties of mitochondrial mutations, their physiological consequences, and their roles in aging using diverse eukaryotic model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Critical processes in cells are carried out through protein interactions that mediate function. This project will develop and apply quantitative in vivo cross-linking and novel mass spectrometry array technologies to gain greater insight on cellular interactome dynamics. These studies will enable improved understanding of human diseases such as cancer, molecular details of how cells alter function during drug treatment, including heat shock response that serves to limit many potential therapies and how cells alter functional pathways to confer chemoresistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Sepsis is a very dangerous whole-body response to infection or trauma that often leads to death due to overwhelming inflammatory and metabolic stress in critical organs such as the heart. In this project, using genetically-modified mouse models and blood samples from sepsis patients, we will test the hypothesis that a protein called PHB1 is released from the liver during sepsis and circulates throughout the body to protect the heart from tissue damage caused by this stress. This work will lay groundwork for new clinical tests and drugs that target sepsis-induced heart failure and other inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Copper (Cu) is necessary for growth, development and metabolism in humans. Abnormal Cu absorption, excretion or distribution results in health conditions, such as Menkes and Wilson diseases, and mitochondrial, neurological and cardiac pathologies. This project will characterize novel molecular mechanisms by which Cu and Cu-binding transcription factors regulate lineage-specific gene expression and muscle development, and will establish a basis to understand muscular phenotypes observed in multiple diseases related to Cu deficiencies at a transcriptional level.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) in Benin have difficulty adjusting their diet to reach their target glycated hemoglobin level (HbA1c), increasing their risk of complications. Through training and research activities, a culturally tailored medical nutrition therapy (MNT) will be used to improve dietary adherence and health outcomes, thus reducing the disease burden of this high-risk population. If successful, this study may be included in future multi-component self-management interventions and be of immediate benefit to clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: REGULATION OF SKIN HOMEOSTASIS BY RNA-BINDING PROTEINS  Project Narrative The maintenance of epithelial tissue is orchestrated by an interplay of regulatory factors that control transcription, RNA processing, translation and protein modification that together balance the decisions to divide, differentiate or enter senescence. Breakdowns in this regulatory system lead to skin diseases, such as psoriasis or cancer. This proposal aims to understand the roles of RNA-binding proteins and their modification in epidermal homeostasis in mechanistic detail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2 infection can cause extensive and lasting damage to the lungs and heart. We are investigating the mechanisms by which the noncanonical inflammasome promotes excessive inflammation and thrombosis in these organs, including in the context of specific immunodeficiencies linked to severe COVID-19. Our work will provide new fundamental understanding of COVID-19 disease pathogenesis, and will identify new host- directed therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The heart rhythm disorders of ventricular arrhythmias affect hundreds of thousands of individuals in the U.S. alone and are substantial causes of mortality, yet their therapy is suboptimal. A major problem is that it is difficult to identify which patient will respond to drug or ablation therapy. This project will develop a computer-based framework to personalize therapy for ventricular tachycardia, using machine learning and personalized computer models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the properties of generalization in neural networks, using abstract sequence representation. These results will provide a foundation for explicating and addressing the neural mechanisms behind impaired sequence processing and generalization in conditions such as Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The communication between gene promoters and distal enhancers is essential for proper cell function, while often aberrant enhancer function leads to transcription deregulation and disease, however how enhancers target specific promoters remains unknown. This project will leverage new optical imaging technologies to directly visualize, with molecular detail, the dynamics of enhancer-promoter communication and downstream gene transcription control, in the nucleus of single live mammalian cells. A better understanding of the relation between genome organization and gene expression regulation will provide new opportunities for therapeutic and preventive interventions.

Upon completion, we will understand the role of interleukin-6 trans-signaling in older stroke subjects, and this discovery will stimulate the development of efficacious therapies to improve long-term functional recovery in older women after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Obesity and type 2 diabetes remain unmet medical needs that exact enormous human and monetary costs. While we know that many organ systems are involved in the pathology of these conditions, the gastrointestinal tract has become the source of our best treatment tools and this includes surgical manipulation of the gastrointestinal tract. This proposal aims to reverse engineer the potent benefits of surgical treatments for obesity and type 2 diabetes to identify treatment strategies that are less invasive and more scaleable so as to be able to better treat and/or prevent these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative The proposed study will use a randomized controlled trial design to evaluate the potential of incorporating physical therapy exercises (primary prevention strategy) within an evidence-based intervention called Walk with Ease to reduce falls and fall risk in older, community-dwelling older adults. The integrated process and outcome evaluation will determine the relative effectiveness of individually prescribed exercises (compared to standardized exercises) as well as the potential of formalized ‘habit training’ to improve compliance with exercises in this population. The study, conducted through a local clinical / community partnership will advance both science and practice while also informing implementation strategies needed to promote broader dissemination in collaboration with the CHPcommunity and the Iowa Falls Prevention Coalition.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE-22-006 Process and Outcome Evaluation of the Walk with Ease program for Fall Prevention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is highly relevant to public health due to its potential to advance research and prevention efforts by documenting risk and protective factors associated with indirect (witnessing) and direct (gun carrying and perpetration and victimization) firearm violence experienced by youth and young adults in the United States, increasing our ability to understand and interrupt the cycle of firearm violence and decrease the risk of injury and death. Importantly, the study’s three-wave longitudinal design will allow for the identification of modifiable risk and protective factors for firearm violence at the individual, family, peer, school/work, and community levels. We expect results from this study to inform prevention work which will, in turn, reduce mortality, improve quality of life, and reduce medical costs associated with firearm violence.
PI_NAMEs: MITCHELL LEMA, KIMBERLY J;TAYLOR, BRUCE GREGORY (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-004, Firearm Violence Perpetration: A Nationally Representative Multi-Wave Survey of Youth and Young Adults Across the United States

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Drowning is a leading cause of unintentional injury death with significantly higher drowning rates occurring in persons belonging to minority groups. The proposed project will identify gender and ethnic subpopulations that experience higher rates of unintentional drowning, investigate the causes and outcomes for these disparities and compute the economic costs arising from unintentional drowning. Our research will help understand conditions affecting morbidity and mortality from unintentional drowning, especially in subpopulations that experience higher rates of drowning.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE-22-008 ASTRAL (Aquatic Safety Through Research, Association, and Linkage of Data)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will examine the short- and long-term effects of vacant lot reuse as a strategy for preventing community violence in Indianapolis, IN, a city with elevated rates of violent crime. The study will test whether higher levels of implementation and community engagement enhance preventive effects of vacant lot reuse on violence through site surveys and in-depth case studies of effective reuse efforts.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Community violence prevention through community-engaged vacant property reuse: Longitudinal application of Busy Streets Theory in Indianapolis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Suicide accounts for 60% of firearm deaths in the U.S. and most people who die by suicide see a health care provider in the year prior to death. Though firearm access is relevant to patients’ health and safety, gun ownership is often a contentious and polarizing issue and there is a dearth of evidence available to guide implementation of clinical practices for identifying and engaging patients at high-risk of firearm suicide. To address this gap, researchers embedded in three healthcare systems, serving sociodemographic diverse communities with high rates of firearm ownership, will partner with leaders, clinicians, and patients to design and test intervention strategies using an innovative Human-Centered Design approach.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-004, Optimizing Firearm Suicide Prevention in Healthcare

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Breast cancer is the world’s most prevalent cancer, with 2.3 million women diagnosed and 685,000 deaths globally in 2021. While breast cancer maintains a chokehold on women’s health, the death rate has declined by about 1% per year over the last decade due in large part to earlier detection. The goal of this work is to develop a new, noninvasive, ultrasound-based imaging technology that expands understanding of breast cancer pathophysiology and improves breast cancer diagnosis and treatment monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative Falls are the leading cause of injury in adults over age 65. Muscle weakness in the foot can lead to foot and toe deformities such as collapsed arches or bunions, which have been found to contribute to falls in adults over age 65. The current research study aims to investigate the effectiveness of two simple and affordable foot strengthening methods that may make a major impact on balance and fall prevention in older adults.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE-22-006 The effects of intrinsic foot muscle strengthening interventions on balance, proprioception, and fall risk in adults over age 65

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: New Opportunities for Health and Resilience Measures for Suicide (NO HARMS) Prevention Project Narrative Suicide is an increasingly urgent public health issue, nationally and in King County, Washington; the risk and protective factors for suicide death and intentional self-harm are complex and vary by life experiences, demographics, and overarching social determinants of health. Using data to understand these complexities and inform effective suicide prevention strategies requires looking across a wide variety of datasets spanning healthcare, mental health and substance use services, the criminal legal system, housing and homelessness, emergency and crisis services, and community-level information sources. We propose an innovative and replicable data linkage project, New Opportunities for Health and Resilience Measures for Suicide (NO HARMS) Prevention, that connects 12 datasets and subject matter experts across these topics and constructs data elements to analyze individual and community risk and protective factors as well as system touchpoints for a comprehensive examination of suicide and intentional self-harm in King County.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE-22-008 Using Data Linkage to Understand Suicide Attempts, Self-Harm and Unintentional Drowning Deaths

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Adults in developed nations are sedentary for nearly two-thirds of the day- often for hours at a time- which greatly increases risk for cardiovascular disease and mortality. The Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans have recently expanded beyond promoting moderate-vigorous intensity physical activity and now also advocate for reductions in sedentary time; however due to a paucity of evidence only general recommendations (“sit less, move more”) have been provided without any specific, quantitative, actionable targets. This adaptive dose finding study will determine how often and for how long people should break up periods of prolonged sedentary time to transiently improve established cardiovascular risk factors; key foundational information critical to the success of future long-term trials and ultimately public health guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The observation that halogen atoms decorate numerous pharmaceuticals and potent environmental pollutants makes advancing halogenation biochemistry critically important for human and environmental health. This proposal takes an integrated biological and chemical approach to discover, characterize, and engineer the biogenetic routes for the construction of bioactive halogenated molecules from marine eukaryotes that are well validated to be the richest resource of halogenated organic molecules. Metagenomic and transcriptomic workflows will be used to identify genes and enzymes responsible for constructing halogenated molecules in complex eukaryotic holobionts, activities of halogenating enzymes characterized, and novel halogenated molecules evaluated for favorable bioactivities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Although our understanding of disease biology as it relates to the central dogma (DNA-RNA-Protein) has been buoyed by rapid technological advances in DNA and RNA sequencing technologies, quantitation of the final and arguably most actionable element of the central dogma, protein, has lagged behind. In this proposal, we will develop cutting-edge, mass spectrometry-based proteomic technologies, and combine them with biochemical, cell biology and animal experiments to study various protein posttranslational modifications (in particular, phosphorylation and ADP-ribosylation) that are related to cell growth control and stress responses. In so doing, we will uncover signaling mechanisms that will lead to better therapeutic intervention strategies for the treatment of relevant human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The study of genetic skin disorders, including disorders of keratinization, has identified many pathways central to the normal function of the skin. We propose to employ exome and genome sequencing technologies to identify the remaining genetic causes of these disorders. This work will benefit public health, as gaining insight into genetic causes of these diseases will provide new information about how the skin maintains and renews itself, and may serve as the basis for creating new approaches to targeted therapy for both these rare disorders and related, more common, disorders within the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer patients have immune cells that potentially can attack the tumor. Knowing if these immune cells are present around the tumor provides a way of predicting the patient’s prognosis – however, there are no standardized ways of determining this information from patient’s biopsies. Our project addresses this challenge through a new computational method that analyzes microscopic images of a patient’s cancer and characterize immune cells in much higher resolution compared to what is done by pathologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pericyte dysfunction results in decreases in cerebral blood flow and disruption of the blood brain barrier, which contribute to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) development. The goals of this proposal are to gain a deep understanding of the role of Fli-1 in regulating pericyte dysfunction in AD and to develop a novel treatment strategy for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: THE NETWORK DATA EXCHANGE – A NETWORK COMMONS FOR BIOLOGISTS NARRATIVE The Network Data Exchange (NDEx) is an online commons where scientists find, share, and publicly distribute biological networks. It also provides ‘omics interpretation tools that leverage its corpus of networks. NDEx plays an essential role in providing investigators with up-to-date knowledge of the molecular networks and pathways that underlie cancer and other major diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several neuropeptides are well known in animal studies to show great promise for controlling seizures and ameliorating behavioral abnormalities; however, they do not readily cross the blood brain barrier and are rapidly metabolized when given systemically, thus limiting clinical application. To overcome this challenge, we developed an approach based on the encapsulation of neuropeptides in nanoparticles. We will determine the ability of nanoparticle encapsulated oxytocin and neuropeptide Y to ameliorate seizures and behavioral deficits in mouse models of severe childhood epilepsy caused by mutations in two sodium channels. The mechanism by which oxytocin increases seizure resistance in the mouse models will also be established.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychoneurological symptoms are the most common co-occurring symptoms causing distress among breast cancer survivors and can significantly compromise quality of life. Better understandings of the effect and mechanism by which effective interventions such as acupuncture mitigate psychoneurological symptoms is urgently needed. This knowledge will advance precision symptom care and improve quality of life for breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Completion of this proposal will establish an experimental system capable of efficiently testing for gene- environment interactions (GxE) that cause differential susceptibility to chemical exposure. By linking experimental and informatics expertise, we will leverage data to make more informed choices in choosing to study chemicals that show strong empirical support for GxE, rather than interrogate the same set of usual suspects. This addresses a critical public health need in the face of a growing chemical exposome, where certain chemicals may elicit severely adverse health effects that differ across populations.
